4. Meet GypHelp BG 973 male (2017). He has some feather problems and is going on a social trip to hopefully start feeling better.

On 26/07/2018, the team from Asters, monitoring the wild bearded vulture breeding pairs, found a young chick at Bargy nord. Probably he flew from the nest, but was now unable to fly again. His parents were feeding him regularly, but after one month the team could see that he was still not able to fly, so he was transferred to the Tichodrome recovery centre to find out what the problem was and help the bird.A feather abnormality was identified, which could be of genetic origin, and we need to transfer him to Guadalentín Specialized Breeding Centre (Cazorla, Spain) to give him the opportunity to have social contact with other birds. We would like to put it together with Rin Ran, a wild bearded vulture female which fell from the nest and had to go through eye surgery recently. In Guadalentín staff will continue to observe his moult process.

About the transferWhen: end SeptemberFrom: Asters specialized captive breeding centre, Sallanches, FranceTo: Guadalentín specialized captive breeding centre, Cazorla, SpainHow: by car to Vallcalent (Spain) + by carrier transport to Guadalentín
5. Meet BG 727 male (2017), he is on the move to be a chaperon to a lone female at the Goldau zoo

This imprinted bird was hand-reared by a private collector, and is now at Pairi Daiza, in Belgium. He will now travel to Goldau zoo (Switzerland) to keep a lone female company until 2019. The female lost her mate and it is important she has company until the next breeding season, while we find a suitable new partner for her. When a new breeding male is found, the chaperon will be transferred to the RFZ center, Austria, by car after next breeding season (2019).
About the transferWhen: end SeptemberFrom: Pairi Daiza, Belgium   To: Goldau Zoo, SwitzerlandHow: by car to Aachener zoo (stopover) + by car from Aachener zoo to RFZ, Austria
6. Meet BG 398 female (2002). She needs artificial incubation for her eggs, so she needs to be at a specialized breeding centre

Born in Almaty zoo, on 13/03/2002, this female was hand-reared by humans. This has resulted in the need to always remove the eggs after being laid, because she is not capable of incubating the eggs and rearing the chicks. She is now at a German private collection. At Richard Faust Zentrum Specialized Breeding Centre, Austria, this female will be paired with another male and specialized artificial incubation is available.
About the transferWhen: end SeptemberFrom: Germany   To: Richard Faust Zentrum Specialized Breeding Centre, AustriaHow: by car from Germany to RFZ
7. Meet BG 726 (founder female, 2008?). She is looking for a new partner and she probably also needs artificial incubation for her eggs

Possibly born in 2008, in an unknown place, this female arrived at the Yerevan Zoo, Armenia, on 05/04/2008. We do not know if she was hand-reared. She was later sold to the Nikolaev zoo, where she lives now.Being a female, if all goes well and we find a suitable partner for her, there is a chance that the new pair produces important descendants for the EEP.
About the transferWhen: late 2018 - beginning 2019From: Nikolaev zoo, Ukraine   To: Richard Faust Zentrum Specialized Breeding Centre, AustriaHow: by plane from Ukraine to Austria
8. Meet BG 844 (2015) and BG 673 (2011). They are a breeding pair looking for a new home in Ukraine

BG 844 male, born at Guadalentín, Spain, on the 26/02/2015. He is a descendant from a very successful breeding pair (16 fledglings in 10 breeding seasons!). Most of them have been released in different reintroduction projects. He is a sibling from the the wild breeding sibling pair Hortelano x Marchena, from Andalusia. He is now at the Richard Faust Zentrum Specialized Breeding Centre, Austria.

BG 673 female, also born at Guadalentín, on the 21/03/2011. She is a descendant from a second very successful breeding pair (14 fledglings in 11 breeding seasons!). Most of them have been also released in different reintroduction projects. She is a sibling from the successful Andalusia wild breeding female Blimunda. She is now at the Richard Faust Zentrum Specialized Breeding Centre, Austria.
This pair will be transferred to Nikolaev zoo, in exchange for founder birds, and to establish a breeding pair there.
About the transferWhen: late 2018 - beginning 2019From: Richard Faust Zentrum Specialized Breeding Centre, Austria   To: Nikolaev zoo, Ukraine   How: by plane from Austria to Ukraine
9. Meet siblings BG 949 (2017), BG 978 (2018) and BG 979 (2018). They are joining the captive breeding programme and hopefully find partners to form 3 pairs in the future

These 3 siblings are all descendants from a founder pair. Genetically they are important for the EEP and they will be added to the captive breeding stock, and form 3 breeding pairs, when they reach sexual maturity.
About the transferWhen: late 2018 - beginning 2019From: Yerevan, Armenia   To: RFZ, Austria   How: by plane from Armenia to Austria
10. Meet BG 847 (2015) and BG 829 (2015). They are a breeding pair looking for a new home in Armenia

BG 847 is a male, born at Guadalentín, on the 04/03/2015. He is a descendant from a very successful breeding pair (14 fledglings in 11 breeding seasons!). Most of them have been also released in different reintroduction projects. He is a sibling from the successful Andalusia wild breeding female Blimunda.
BG 829 is a female, born at the Richard Faust Zentrum, Austria, on 29/01/2015. She was hatched and reared by her own parents.
About the transferWhen: beginning 2019From: RFZ, Austria   To: FPWC foundation, Armenia   How: by plane from Austria to Armenia

11. Meet BG 1006 male (2018) and BG 911 female (2016). They are important birds, descendants of founder birds. They are moving to a centre at a higher altitude to keep them safe from the West Nile Virus

BG 1006 is a male descendant from a new founder male housed at RFZ, Austria. This is an important bird in the EEP. Born on the 06/04/2018, Last year his sibling died due to West Nile Virus, so it is urgent to transfer it to a secure breeding center.

BG 911 female is the first descendant from a new founder female housed at Tallinn zoo. Born on the 23/03/2016, she was transferred by car to RFZ for adoption. She is also being transferred to Guadalentín to assure no West Nile Virus presence and free of aspergillosis infection.
About the transferWhen: as soon as possibleFrom: RFZ, Austria   To: Guadalentín, SpainHow: by plane from Austria to Spain
The whole picture – the story of the bearded vulture reintroduction project (1975-2018)

The reintroduction of the bearded vulture into Europe is one of the world´s greatest wildlife comeback stories of all times, and an ongoing project and adventure that continues to gather stakeholders, members of the public, and general interest, all around. From near extinction in Europe we have managed, in a few decades, to bring back the species to the Alps and Andalusia, and are continuing to work towards restoring the species across the continent.

Bearded vultures were once widely distributed across Eurasia and Africa, with significant populations in most of the main mountain ranges in these continents. The species used to breed in almost all of Europe, from Spain to the Balkans, passing through the Pyrenees and the Alps. This ensured a constant genetic exchange and kept a healthy European meta-population. However, this situation rapidly changed during the 19th century and by the beginning of the last century the species was almost entirely wiped out. Only three populations survived in Western Europe, two small island groups in Corsica and Crete, and the main one in the Pyrenees, none of them self-sustaining without specific actions, and certainly not in large-enough numbers to re-colonize its former distribution range. In these situations, reintroductions seem to be the only viable way of recovering such highly damaged meta-populations.

In 1978, the idea of bringing back the bearded vulture to the Alps started to take form, and the first releases into the wild took place almost a decade later, in 1986. The time in between was used to set up the basis of a coordinated international programme, developed with the intention of establishing a long-lasting and captive-breeding network that would produce offspring for future reintroductions. This concept, which was rather novel at the time, would be used in other breeding plans aimed for conservation, and was also instrumental in the establishment of the European Association of Zoos and Aquaria (EAZA) European Endangered Species Programme (EEP). The bearded vulture breeding programme was thus one of the first EEPs to be accepted and implemented.

The Bearded Vulture EEP nowadays is composed of a network of 42 institutions mainly distributed across Europe, comprising 35 zoos, 3 large (red) and 2 small (green) specialized captive-breeding centres, and 3 private keepers, which in total keep and breed 174 bearded vultures for conservation purposes. This network is managed by the VCF, which also owns 80% of the captive bearded vultures. All partners follow and respect the best practice guidelines for captive-breeding bearded vultures developed over the years.

The goal of this international captive breeding program (EEP) is the conservation in situ of the species, using the produced nestlings as a base basis for reintroduction projects approved by the VCF/EEP. And the VCF’s final goal is to restore the species across its former range in Europe and establish a European Bearded Vulture meta-population, connecting the current extant isolated populations (Pyrenees, Corsica and Crete) with the reintroduced populations (The Alps, The Massif Central, Andalusia, in a continuum that extends from northern Africa (Morocco) to Asia (Turkey & the Caucasus).
The project timeline
The bearded vulture EEP and reintroduction success in numbers
35 zoos
5 specialized captive-breeding centres:
3 large (keeping 15 to 30 birds on average)
Richard Faust Zuchtzentrum, RFZ, Austria
Centro cria de Guadalentin, CCG, Spain
Centre de Fauna Vallcalent, CVF, Spain
2 small (keeping between 3 and 4 pairs)
-    Asters Breeding center, France
-    Tierpark Goldau, Switzerland
3 private keepers
174 captive bearded Vultures for conservation purposesof which 38 form breeding pairs
512 individuals raised successfully in the EEP since 1978of which 301 released into the wildof which 93 fitted with GPS tagsof which 33 with active GPS devices
average of 15-18 young released per year (during the last years)
5 reintroduction areas (Alps, Massif Central, Cazorla, Maestrazgo and Corsica)
52 breeding pairs in the Alps
2 breeding pairs in Cazorla (+ 2 nesting pairs)
300 wild born birds have fledged in the wild (until 2017)
Our strength is our network and strategy

The Bearded vulture European Endangered Species Programme (EEP) is an International captive breeding program which started in 1978. This program is composed by a large number of different types of institutions: private and municipal Zoos, private collectors, NGO’s, and Governmental recovery centers.
The Vulture Conservation Foundation is the leading partner of this group, gives technical support to all organizations, defines the strategy and the guidelines of the EEP.

Since the beginning the objectives of this programme were clear and are still valid today:-    to create and maintain a captive stock as a genetic reserve for the species-    to produce chicks which are able to reproduce as they reach adult age -    to establish a wild population, capable to survive and reproduce independently of human intervention.

Finally, with the VCF working at an European scale, the ultimate aim of the programme is to establish an European meta-population of Bearded Vultures, creating gene flow between the existing isolated autochthonous populations in Europe, linking the Alps, the Pyrenees, Corsica, and Crete to the populations in North Africa and Asia.
My main task as coordinator of the BV EEP is to achieve this established final goal: to create a European meta-population of Bearded Vultures.

To reach this final goal it is necessary to assure the continuity of this captive breeding network and to provide young birds for all running reintroduction projects. We have not only to provide a certain number of chicks per year, we have also to provide the adequate birds for creating a human independent and self-sustainable wild population.

This requires a meticulous planning of pairing of birds and pair distribution inside the EEP, as well as adequately selecting the right nestling for each reintroduction project, following criteria on sex ratio and genetics.

Finally, to make sure that we are fomenting the development of natural behaviour in captive bred birds, we make sure all bearded vulture chicks are natural reared, with absolutely no human intervention in feeding or caring. This is done by adult birds only, either the parents of the chick or adoptive/foster parents.

Thanks to all this work it was possible to increase the captive breeding network step by step and consequently the yearly number of produced chicks, making it possible to start new reintroduction projects.

The key factor of all these successes is to know that pair formation in Bearded Vultures can be complicated and dangerous. That is why it was decided to create a distinction between centres dedicated exclusively to breeding (zoos and private centres) and centres dedicated to breeding and pair formation (Specialized Breeding Centres: SBCs). The role of the first is to house already established pairs and to breed the maximum number of offspring from them, while the specialized centers have specialized staff and are responsible for establishing new pairs, taking in new founders (injured birds from the wild), adopting chicks, housing problematic birds, and creating a genetic reserve by receiving specimens from all of the genetic lineages that make up the EEP.

Additionally a new technical assistance support service was created in 2013, giving all the partners the possibility to request the visit of a specialist on captive breeding of this species to receive suggestions on how to improve the facilities where their Bearded vultures are housed and consequently reduce the mortality of birds and increase breeding success at the zoos. More than half of the zoos have been visited by us during the last 5 years and have improved the aviary following our advice, showing a significantly increase of the average age of death of the birds.

All this effort made by all these partners makes possible that from an initial 40 birds, the captive population now has 174 birds, and a total yearly average production of around 25 chicks, assuring the continuity of all on-going reintroduction projects.
Risks and challenges

If we do not reach the fundraising goal, we will need to postpone some of the transports to another year, and still go through to the most urgent transports, namely the transfer of birds which need protection from disease.
If we exceed our initial fundraising goal, additional funds will go towards the building of new aviaries and improvement of current facilities at the Vallcalent Specialized Breeding Centre.
We hope you join us on this journey to bring the bearded vulture back to the European skies, from Western Spain to the Balkans!
Other Ways You Can Help
Please SHARE this page with all your friends!
Follow us on social media! We will regularly share information on the birds and on what we are doing for the conservation of the bearded vulture! Like us on facebook, follow us on Twitter.
Read more about vulture conservation and what the VCF and its partners are accomplishing all over Europe on our website
Contact us at info@4vultures.org",17.0,0,"1 Campaign

WHY DO WE NEED YOU

THE $25,000 RAISED THROUGH THIS CAMPAIGN WILL BE USED TO DIRECTLY SUPPORT THE KLABONA KEEPERS IN THEIR GRASSROOTS RESISTANCE. PLEASE CONSIDER DONATING HERE TO THEIR VAILANT EFFORTS TO STOP INDUSTRIAL DESTRUCTION OF THEIR LANDS.

The Klabona
Keepers is an organization of Tahltan elders and families who occupy and
use traditional lands near Iskut, British Columbia known as Tl’abāne,
the Sacred Headwaters of the Stikine, Nass and Skeena Rivers. They have been working tirelessly for over a decade to
protect one of the world's most vital ecosystems. They have continued their ancestors
responsibility in protecting the Sacred Headwaters, a place that we all
benefit from.  In
order to continue this resistance, donations are being accepted and
this fundraising campaign is being launched to support those standing on
the front lines.
column3:
/>

Whether it is Imperial Metals, Firesteel and Oz Minerals,

column1: Colorado, or Fortune Minerals - companies continue to compromise and disrespect
the Klabona Keeper’s elders and sacred land. They have no right to jeopardize
the cultural history and assume authority over this sovereign and unceded
territory. This financial support will ensure the future of this place is in the hands
of the people who are most deeply devoted to protecting it and not in the hands
of a CEO whose connection to the land is purely based on the exploitation of it
for their own self interests.
Additionally, the Klabona Keepers and community members are building a cabin on their traditional territory in the location
where previous resistance has taken place. The cabin is a symbol of
unity and strength, and it's history includes the location where elders
were arrested as they stood up to fortune minerals in 2005. The
cabin will provide a cultural learning base for youth and other
community members and will be an integral factor in the current and
future fight to protect their territory. Any remaining funds will be utilized to re-occupy their territory serving as a constant protection of the Sacred Headwaters.
For those of you who have seen Beyond Boarding's documentary, Northern Grease,
you will have witnessed this land, these incredible people and their
continued fight to protect and assert their sovereignty over their
sacred territory.  Please be a part of this journey and contribute to
those sacrificing the most, those on the front lines.

BEYOND BOARDING HAS SET OFF ON ANOTHER ADVENTURE...

CYCLE TO THE SACRED

A 2,000 km bike marathon from Fort Langley to the Sacred Headwaters of BC, of which you can pledge to to generate financial and social support and awareness for The
Klabona Keepers, who are protecting the Sacred Headwaters of British
Columbia from harmful mining development. The tour is taking place over
the course of one and a half months, between July and August. Our goal with this tour is to raise $25,000.
Beyond
Boarding co-founder, Desiree Wallace, and member, Landon Yerex, will be
biking the entirety of the route whilst co-founder, Nicole Kilistoff,
follows in a support vehicle converted to run on waste cooking oil. We
will be raising funds through this Indiegogo campaign and hosting film
screenings of Beyond Boarding’s independent documentary, Northern Grease, which
features the Klabona Keepers to raise awareness and money along the
route. The film features professional level snowboarding,
cinematography, and storytelling, and promises to hold audience attention throughout each evening of the tour. Alongside
the fundraising, the team will be documenting stories of indigenous
land defenders across the province as well as the territories they are protecting through photojournalism and videography.
MORE ABOUT THE SACRED HEADWATERS
Cited as the single, greatest candidate for a climate change sanctuary on the planet, the Sacred Headwaters ecosystem encompasses
the pristine and un-roaded headwater ecosystems of the Skeena, Nass and
Stikine rivers
column2: three of Canada's most valuable wild salmon watersheds.

column1: The integrity of the Sacred Headwaters is essential to the long-term
health of Northwest BC's entire wild salmon ecology and deeply
influences the scope of climate change resiliency and adaptation for the
region into the future. The Sacred Headwaters is rich with cultural heritage.
Every
year, the Tahltan return to Beauty Camp to practice their culture and
to pass on knowledge to children and grandchildren. They come together
to pick berries and to hunt caribou, moose, and other wild game. They
have a deep sense of responsibility to create enduring solutions that
leverage regional ecosystem values, traditional knowledge and resilient
communities to contribute to the global effort to adapt to a changing
climate.
For
11 years the Klabona Keepers have been fighting to protect the Sacred

Headwaters against harmful mining development and once more.

BEYOND BOARDING

Beyond
Boarding is a collective dedicated to spreading interest and passion
for humanitarian and environmental activism within the outdoor
community. Our goal is to encourage snowboarders, surfers and other
self-propelled athletes to channel the positive energy inherent to our
sports in ways that genuinely help the people and environment in our

world.

Please join us to stand in solidarity with the Tahltan Klabona Keepers, to protect the Sacred Headwaters foreve

My name is Nathan Lieske. I am a Life Scout from Troop 15
based in Franklin Connecticut. This campaign’s purpose is to raise funds
for my Eagle Scout project which is building twenty bat boxes for the
Department of Energy and Environmental Protection (DEEP). More information on
the DEEP can be found on their website www.ct.gov/deep/. All of the funds
raised by this campaign will go directly to purchasing tools and materials. The
bat boxes will be donated to the DEEP upon completion.
What are bat boxes and why are they important?
Bat boxes provide
a safe space for bats to roost, and provide a habitat for female bats to raise
their young. Loss of habitat is a common issue facing bats today. Developments
are destroying roosting grounds and interrupting flying routes, and human
activity can interrupt hibernation and the raising of bat pups. Through bat
boxes these creatures have a much higher chance of avoiding human activity.
Also, female bats often give birth to only one pup at a time. This slow
reproduction rate makes it very important to offer bats a safe habitat. One of
my bat boxes can hold up to 400 bats.
How does the DEEP use bat boxes?
The
DEEP uses bat boxes to relocate unwanted colonies. These colonies are located
in people’s homes, garages, barns, or other unwanted areas. After the bats
migrate in the fall, or before they arrive in the spring, the DEEP will install
these bat boxes in the area where a nuisance colony was located. The structure
in which the bats used to live will be sealed so they can’t get back in. This
system creates a perfect situation for the bats and humans. The bats still have
a place to live, and the people don’t have to worry about the bats bothering
them in any way.
What does it take to build a successful bat box?
The
bat box is made out of a combination of plywood and cedar. Each piece of wood
is stained black to retain heat, and the plywood has grooves for
footholds cut into it. The houses are assembled with screws and joints are
sealed with caulk. The interior of the bat boxes has four separate
compartments.
What happens if I go over my goal?
While
the DEEP cannot accept donations they have provided a charity that benefits

bats to donate any extra funds to. 


","My name is Nathan Lieske. I am a Life Scout from Troop 15
based in Franklin Connecticut. This campaign’s purpose is to raise funds
for my Eagle Scout project which is building twenty bat boxes for the
Department of Energy and Environmental Protection (DEEP). More information on
the DEEP can be found on their website www.ct.gov/deep/. All of the funds
raised by this campaign will go directly to purchasing tools and materials. The
bat boxes will be donated to the DEEP upon completion.
What are bat boxes and why are they important?
Bat boxes provide
a safe space for bats to roost, and provide a habitat for female bats to raise
their young. Loss of habitat is a common issue facing bats today. Developments
are destroying roosting grounds and interrupting flying routes, and human
activity can interrupt hibernation and the raising of bat pups. Through bat
boxes these creatures have a much higher chance of avoiding human activity.
Also, female bats often give birth to only one pup at a time. This slow
reproduction rate makes it very important to offer bats a safe habitat. One of
my bat boxes can hold up to 400 bats.
How does the DEEP use bat boxes?
The
DEEP uses bat boxes to relocate unwanted colonies. These colonies are located
in people’s homes, garages, barns, or other unwanted areas. After the bats
migrate in the fall, or before they arrive in the spring, the DEEP will install
these bat boxes in the area where a nuisance colony was located. The structure
in which the bats used to live will be sealed so they can’t get back in. This
system creates a perfect situation for the bats and humans. The bats still have
a place to live, and the people don’t have to worry about the bats bothering
them in any way.
What does it take to build a successful bat box?
The
bat box is made out of a combination of plywood and cedar. Each piece of wood
is stained black to retain heat, and the plywood has grooves for
footholds cut into it. The houses are assembled with screws and joints are
sealed with caulk. The interior of the bat boxes has four separate
compartments.
What happens if I go over my goal?
While
the DEEP cannot accept donations they have provided a charity that benefits
bats to donate any extra funds to.",4.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Franklin, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/bat-box-eagle-project-become-a-bat-hero-today/pica

column2: >Give a Threatened coral a chance to survive!  Nova Southeastern University’s Oceanographic

column1: Center researchers (NSUOC) are currently working to save the Threatened
Staghorn coral from extinction by growing it in an off-shore coral nursery
until it is large enough to be outplanted back to local reefs.

Our goal is to grow enough corals in our nursery to outplant thousands of coral fragments per year back to South Florida reefs so that they may continue to grow, spawn, and help in replenishing the existing Staghorn population.  As a branching coral, Staghorn grows quickly, building reef structure and providing shelter/habitat for many reef fish and critters.  As part of this project, we will continue to study the survivorship and health of our nursery and outplanted corals, along with the best way to grow corals in a nursery.  We will also study the changes in reef fish communities surrounding our newly outplanted corals as we assist in the recovery of Staghorn coral and overall restoration of local reefs.

column2: >Transplanting Staghorn coral to the Nursery
column3: >By helping us to achieve our campaign goal of $10,000, we will be able to create two additional nursery structures that will grow at least 200 more corals.  After just 1.5 years in the nursery each original coral will grow large enough to outplant three new corals to the reef
column4: that’s approximately 600 corals added to south Florida reefs in just 1.5 years from the help of this campaign! AND, a portion of each original coral will be left in the nursery as stock, where it will continue to grow and provide more outplantable material for years to come! Along with creating new structures and adding corals to our nursery, these funds will also assist in supporting a graduate student at NSUOC and boat time to study these corals.
column5: >Growth of nursery corals over 3 Years!
column6: >During our current efforts of growing over 3,000 corals in our nursery we have already been able to learn about how different individuals grow, survive and are even possibly resistant to disease. The addition of more corals to our nursery from this campaign will allow us to increase the capacity of our research on this threatened coral species so we can begin to answer questions like:

column1: <ul>
<li>Which nursery structure is the best for raising (growing)
corals?
<li>
Are our nursery and outplanted corals spawning?
<li>
What is the most beneficial way of outplanting
corals: should we plant them close together in clusters or space them out?

column2: >Outplanting nursery corals to a south Florida reef!
column3: >Staghorn coral is one of two coral species listed as Threatened by the US Endangered Species Act.  It was listed in 2006 after surveys confirmed that the species had not recovered from the massive die-off of the 1970’s and 1980’s.  Only a few populations of this crucial coral remain.  By supporting this coral restoration project you are helping to build local reefs, preserving our valuable beaches, creating new habitat for thousands of reef critters and increasing the chances of Staghorn coral reproduction during their one spawning night a year!

column1: <h4 style=""text-align: center
column2: >Outplanted corals growing over 2 years on a south Florida reef
column3: >More than $2 BILLION of the local economy and more than 36,000 jobs are provided by south Florida coral reefs and Staghorn corals are the necessary foundation to create them – do your part to help today!

column1: By supporting NSU’s Coral Nursery Initiative, you will make a difference in promoting a student’s educational experience, in supporting a valuable and important coral reef ecosystem and in fostering cutting-edge coral reef restoration research.
Each support level comes with unique perks, like a social
media shout out, Coral Nursery Initiative stickers or BCD/bag tags and underwater photos of our coral nursery or outplant site.
(Perks can be declined so your entire donation will go to the Coral
Nursery Initiative)
• Spread the word by using the share tools
<li>
Encourage your friends and family to visit our page and donate
<li>
Follow us on Facebook and Twitter
<li>
For more information visit our website
","Give a Threatened coral a chance to survive!  Nova Southeastern University’s Oceanographic
Center researchers (NSUOC) are currently working to save the Threatened
Staghorn coral from extinction by growing it in an off-shore coral nursery
until it is large enough to be outplanted back to local reefs.

Our goal is to grow enough corals in our nursery to outplant thousands of coral fragments per year back to South Florida reefs so that they may continue to grow, spawn, and help in replenishing the existing Staghorn population.   As a branching coral, Staghorn grows quickly, building reef structure and providing shelter/habitat for many reef fish and critters.   As part of this project, we will continue to study the survivorship and health of our nursery and outplanted corals, along with the best way to grow corals in a nursery.  We will also study the changes in reef fish communities surrounding our newly outplanted corals as we assist in the recovery of Staghorn coral and overall restoration of local reefs.

Transplanting Staghorn coral to the NurseryBy helping us to achieve our campaign goal of $10,000, we will be able to create two additional nursery structures that will grow at least 200 more corals.  After just 1.5 years in the nursery each original coral will grow large enough to outplant three new corals to the reef

Along with creating new structures and adding corals to our nursery, these funds will also assist in supporting a graduate student at NSUOC and boat time to study these corals.Growth of nursery corals over 3 Years!During our current efforts of growing over 3,000 corals in our nursery we have already been able to learn about how different individuals grow, survive and are even possibly resistant to disease.  The addition of more corals to our nursery from this campaign will allow us to increase the capacity of our research on this threatened coral species so we can begin to answer questions like:

corals: should we plant them close together in clusters or space them out?

Outplanting nursery corals to a south Florida reef!Staghorn coral is one of two coral species listed as Threatened by the US Endangered Species Act.   It was listed in 2006 after surveys confirmed that the species had not recovered from the massive die-off of the 1970’s and 1980’s.   Only a few populations of this crucial coral remain.  By supporting this coral restoration project you are helping to build local reefs, preserving our valuable beaches, creating new habitat for thousands of reef critters and increasing the chances of Staghorn coral reproduction during their one spawning night a year!

Outplanted corals growing over 2 years on a south Florida reefMore than $2 BILLION of the local economy and more than 36,000 jobs are provided by south Florida coral reefs and Staghorn corals are the necessary foundation to create them – do your part to help today!

Vea Nuestro Video de Paraguay Verde en Español
Located in the heart of South America, Paraguay rests at the
meeting point of some of the continent's most diverse and ecologically striking
regions.  Home to over 700 bird species, impressive wetlands, tropical
forests, and great swaths of the Gran Chaco, the country faces a unique set of
challenges in preserving its incredible biodiversity and working toward a
sustainable future.
During the last decade, Paraguay has had the second-highest deforestation rate in the world, with millions of hectares of habitat converted for human use, threatening
many native species with extinction.  Air pollution and mismanagement of
waste are also among the environmental problems that the country faces.
Protecting the country's vast natural wealth and promoting environmental responsibility

will be great challenges for the next generation.

El
Desafío:
Situado en el corazón de América del Sur, Paraguay está ubicado en el punto de encuentro de unas de las regiones más
diversas y ecológicas más impresionantes del continente. El hogar de más de 700
especies de aves, humedales, bosques tropicales, y andanas grandes del Gran
Chaco, el país se enfrente a una serie de desafíos en la preservación de su increíble biodiversidad y trabajando hacia un futuro sostenible.

Durante la última década, Paraguay tenía la segunda tasa más alta de deforestación en el mundo, millones de hectáreas de hábitats han sido convertidos para el uso humano, amenazando especies nativas en peligro de
extinción. Contaminación del aire a gran escala y el mal manejo de residuos
han disminuido aún más la calidad de vida y han creado un estado de

desequilibrio para los biomas naturales. La protección de la casta riqueza del país y la promoción de la responsabilidad ambiental serán grandes retos para la próxima generación. 


The
Opportunity:
Paraguay is an environmentally rich nation, and perhaps one of its
best resources is its young people. With over half of the population under the
age of 25, Paraguayan youth are shaping the future of their country and its
impact on the world. Through education focused on environmental consciousness
and responsibility, tangible skills, and project-building tools, Paraguay's next generation can be inspired to address the

environmental challenges both present and future.


La
Oportunidad:
Paraguay es un país rico
con el medio ambiente, y quizás uno de sus mejores recursos es su gente joven.
Con más de la mitad de la población menor de 25 años, la juventud paraguaya
están dando forma al futuro de su país y su impacto en el mundo. A través de la
educación centrada en la conciencia ambiental y la responsabilidad, habilidades
tangibles, y las herramientas de creación de proyecto, la próxima generación de
Paraguay puede estar inspirada para hacer frente a los retos ambientales
actuales y futuros.
Plan:
This February, A Todo Pulmón Paraguay Respira, in partnership with Peace Corps/Paraguay, will host the

fifth ""Paraguay Verde"" National Youth Camp. A Todo Pulmón, a Paraguayan non-profit organization, operates on a national level, raising environmental awareness and facilitating local reforestation projects to improve Paraguayan quality of life.
Paraguay Verde will bring together over 100 participants from across the nation, giving them the opportunity to learn about
environmental challenges, share ideas and experiences, and collaborate on
solutions for each of their communities. The camp provides a national platform
for young Paraguayans to discuss local issues and share strategies for
addressing them in a fun and <span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5: >empowering atmosphere. Youth then return to their communities capable of initiating or enhancing environmental youth groups and implementing sustainable action plans.

column1: El
Plan:
A Todo Pulmón: Paraguay Respira junto

con Cuerpo de Paz Paraguay organizará el quinto Campamento Juvenil Nacional ""Paraguay Verde"" en febrero del 2015. A Todo Pulmón, una asociación paraguaya sin fines de lucro, opera a nivel nacional concienciando sobre temas ambientales y facilitando proyectos de reforestación locales para mejorar la calidad de vida Paraguaya.
Paraguay Verde juntará más de 100 participantes de todo el país dando a paraguayos jóvenes la oportunidad de aprender
sobre los desafíos ambientales, compartir ideas y experiencias, y colaborar en
soluciones para cada una de sus comunidades. El campamento ofrece una
plataforma nacional para paraguayos jóvenes para discutir sobre cuestiones locales y
compartir estrategias y soluciones en un ambiente divertido y empoderado. Luego, los jóvenes vuelven a
sus comunidades siendo capaces de iniciar o mejorar grupos ambientales de jóvenes e
implementar planes de acción sostenibles.
<div>
Successes:
The overwhelming success of the past four
Paraguay Verde youth camps has helped build a network of young leaders already
hard at work across Paraguay.  Over 150 Paraguayan youth have attended the past four camps, where they <span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >planted over 100 native trees, participated in youth leadership panels, practiced worm composting, and completed projects with ""eco-bricks"" (plastic bottles filled with inorganic waste and used as building material) to learn about more creative and sustainable waste management practices.

>Among many other community projects carried out by particpants since attending a Paraguay Verde camp, one youth led his community group in a campaign to collect 220 pounds of batteries in their schools and educate their peers about the contamination caused by the improper disposal of the batteries in a nearby wetland. Another youth led a group to construct a mural outside their community’s health post, using eco-brick building techniques. Many other participants have formed new youth groups and coordinated reforestation projects, community clean-ups, environmental education workshops, and other intiatives in their communities.

column1: Éxitos:
El éxito enorme de los cuatro
Campamentos de Paraguay Verde pasados ha creado una red de líderes jóvenes que ya
están trabajando por todo el Paraguay. Más de 150 paraguayos jóvenes asistieron a los campamentos pasados donde
column2: >plantaron más de 100 árboles nativos, participaron en grupos de liderazgo juvenil, practicaron en vermicultura, e hicieron “eco-ladrillos” (botellas de plástico llenas de residuos inorgánicos y usados como materiales de construcción) para demonstrar más métodos sostenibles y económicamente beneficiosos de manejo de residuos y recursos.

>Después de asistir a un Campamento  de Paraguay Verde, un participante guió a su grupo a llevar a cabo una campaña para juntar 100 kilos de baterías en sus colegios y educar a sus compañeros sobre la contaminación causada por arrojar baterías en los humedales cercanos. Otro joven guió a su grupo a utilizar técnicas de  construcción con eco-ladrillos para hacer un mural decorativo en el puesto de salud de su comunidad. Varios otros participantes han organizado grupos juveniles nuevos y han coordinado proyectos de reforestación, limpiezas de la comunidad, talleres de educación ambiental, y otras iniciativas en sus comunidades.

column1: <div>
How
you can help:
We need your support to make Paraguay Verde
happen! Your contribution will go directly towards funding the fifth Paraguay
Verde Camp for the 100+ participants expected to attend in 2015. It only takes $75
to sponsor the food, lodging, and educational materials for one youth for the duration of the camp, allowing young environmental
leaders who may otherwise be unable to attend, to participate in this
transformative experience! The youths themselves will also fundraise locally to cover transportation costs to the camp.
Even if you are unable to donate at this time, we need your help sharing this campaign through
social media outlets and with your family and friends.
Thank you for your support and for helping to
promote the growth of young leaders and a sustainable future in Paraguay.
De
qué manera usted puede ayudar:
¡Necesitamos su
apoyo para realizar Paraguay Verde! Su contribución irá directamente a los
fondos para financiar el quinto Campamento Nacional Paraguay Verde para los más
de 100 participantes que son esperados a asistir en 2015. Con sólo $75 (USD) se
puede patrocinar a un joven durante toda la duración del campamento, cubriendo su comida, alojamiento, y materiales educativos, dando la oportunidad
de participar a líderes jóvenes ambientales quienes de otra manera no podrían
asistir. Los jóvenes mismos también estarán recaudando fondos a nivel local
para cubrir los gastos del transporte al campamento.
Igualmente si no puede donar en este momento, necesitamos su ayuda por compartir esta campaña en las redes sociales, con sus amigos y su familia.
Gracias por su
apoyo y por ayudar a promover el desarrollo de líderes jóvenes y un futuro sostenible en Paraguay.

Other Ways You Can Help

column1: ","Short Summary music and the sea are both important to me
I'm sure they are to you too
an album to support
the ocean of course
and musicians creating something true
50 to the big blue and 50 more to us
so we can make more music
and you can swim without a fuss

What We Need:  We need money to buy recording time and cover the production cost of t-shirts, buttons and CD's. Without the funds to do these things the album can't accomplish all of it's goals and reach it's full potential.

& Why: I created this campaign so that local musicians could get their music out for people to hear, and at the same time raise support for organizations dedicated to preserving our ocean ecosystems. Your support is very important to us. Half of the money will be donated to the Surfrider Foundation:)
Other Ways You Can Help If you aren't able to donate money but you still want to support this campaign, please just get the word out there! Post it on instagram, facebook,tumblr,and twitter, hashtag
column2: BCT, beachculturetribute, IE2thesea, just get other people here to see what we are all about!:)",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

What is El Zota?

In 1989, my father bought a big piece of land in the northeast part of Costa Rica, to invest in the wood market: 2000 acres of tropical rainforest, including 1400 of primary forest. Little by little, he and my mother started to build a ranch, some rooms, a kitchen... until it became my family's vacation property.

In 2001, with the help of biologist friends of the family, Jill Prutz and Thomas LaDuke, it became what is now, a biology field station, preserving more than 2000 acres of authentic tropical forest and all of its wildlife.
We named it El Zota Biological Field Station.

Throughout the years, the station has been growing, receiving students from universities all around the world, who help to research native plants, various species of insects, monkeys (we have howler monkey, spider monkey and white-faced monkey) and all kinds of scientific investigations and biology research.

El Zota shelters more than 400 species of birds, 116 species of bats, 40 different rodents, more than 25 mammals, including the jaguar and the tapir, and uncountable species of trees and flowers. El Zota is located in a very important spot for the Costa Rica's biology research, located next to Barra del Colorado National Park and Tortuguero National Park.

The thing is, my family can't managed to handle the economic expenses that the station requires anymore. Having the facilities in good condition, the trails clean, hiring professional services, making it more accessible for the community among other needs, have a cost that is impossible for our family to pay at this point, and the station is not able to produce enough income to stand for itself. My family's situation is not good, and there is a big chance of losing the property and the immense potential that El Zota offers along with all of the work we've been doing.
<h3>What We Need &amp

We want capital to invest. We want El Zota to be a more attractive destiny for the international and national tourists, an important spot for the scientific community from all around the world. We want people to have the experience of being inmeserse on the real tropical forest, with all its commodities, helping create consciousness about the importance of preservation. You not only will be part of El Zota, you'll contribute to the preservation and education of the forest and it's wildlife.
We want to attract more people to our station by:
<ul>
<li>
Renovating the facilities: New group and individuals rooms for guests. New fully equipped classrooms. Expand the dining room and common areas for meditation and communing with nature.
<li>
Building elevated walking trails on 3 of our main trails,  save for all people with special conditions, children and elderly people.
<li>

Making the lake's dock safer and accessible, replacing the wood for a more water resistant and humidity friendly material, and making  access ramps to the lake. We also want to add kayaks and safety equipment.
<li>
Building an organic garden to teach people about self-sufficiency. We want to plant vegetables like lettuce, peppers, carrots, potato and more.
<li>

Building recreational new areas: a climbing wall (rocodrome) of 114 ft (35 mts) for exercise and observation towers in certain parts of the forest for birdwatching and photography. We have more than 400 species of birds, including very exotic species like the agami agamia, pipra mentalis, great potoo, barred antshrike and hundreds of more species... This will attract tourism from all over the world.
The Impact
<ul>
• 2019 is a year that begs for ecological awareness, and supporting projects like ours is a great way to help the scientific community and spread the importance of preserving the environment.

• If this project takes off, you will be giving jobs to the communities around El Zota. Construction workers, cooks, farmers... will benefit from this project. Around here, jobs are limited, but El Zota could become a jobs source for the community.
• This is really important for us. We want not only to keep El Zota but to make it a very special place for you, for us, and for Costa Rica.
<h3>Risks &amp
Our family already has built what we have now, but we are close to losing it all.
<ul>
• The station will be lost if we don't take action. Our family is experiencing economic trouble and if we don't have the money we need, the bank will take the station and the surrounding lands.
• We have experience, and we understand the challenge of planning, building, working with deadlines, and get the work done, you can trust us.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't donate to our campaign, you can help us by:
<ul>
<li>
Spreading the word: help us by sharing our project with others, people who you think might be interested on being part of El Zota's family and could contribute with us.
• Posting on your social media: click on the share button so we can reach more people!
<li>
<u>Visiting El Zota:</u> by visiting us you contribute to maintain the station going. Come visit El Zota, and you'll understand why is so important to save the station
Every single dollar you donate and every share you click is helping the scientific community, my family and the rainforest. You have my word.

Our Story

Focusing on a corner lot in one of North Philadelphia's poorest neighborhoods, we are working towards building and maintaining a mini-farm to serve the community. It will not only provide fresh crops for the surrounding residents, but will also beautify the neglected land. We are focusing on potatoes because of the simplicity in maintaining these crops.
The Impact
The development of a mini-farm will provide:
-Members of the community with a food source
-Clean community green space
-Youth agricultural education opportunities
<h3>What We Need &amp
So far we have received:
-Permission to use the land
-Lumber for the garden beds
-Partial fencing
-Bricks for fire pit
-Birdhouses
The $500 dollars will go towards:
-Hardware (Shovels, Wheelbarrels, Etc.)
-Soil
-Fencing
Other Ways You Can Help

We are always looking for volunteers to help out with the development and maintenance of our soon to be mini-farm.  Groups and organizations are welcomed to come out and support.  If you are interested in volunteering with us please contact: Andrew.Deussing@temple.edu

About Me Three years ago I landed in Bangkok, tired from a really long flight from Canada, worried about how I was going to get out of the airport with all my baggage/field equipment, and feeling very aware of the fact that I was completely alone on the other side of the world. Armed with some research equipment, a video camera, and a solid pair of hiking boots, I had arrived in Thailand to begin my PhD research and was moving into the jungle to study primates at UNESCO World Heritage Site, Khao Yai National Park. It was the start of my biggest adventure to date.
The for next two years I would live with Thai locals as the only foreign researcher in one of Thailand’s largest, and most celebrated, protected rainforests. And relying only on the kindness of strangers, I had to learn the local language fast and figure out how things worked to make new friends in order to survive so far away from home.
I documented my journey in this blog (www.prime-jm.blogspot.com) for my friends and family to read, but soon the blog grew into a more meaningful enterprise. An audience was building of students and interested readers looking to learn more about the animals I study, my relationships with the Thai locals in a foreign culture, and my experiences with nature.

In a nutshell: it was the best experience of my life and I'm so thankful so many people were interested to hear about my adventures!!
When I finished my research and returned home from Thailand at the end of 2011, I knew things couldn’t end there. I had to do more. More people need experiences like mine to gain perspective of themselves and find their place in the world
column2:
more opportunities needed to be available for young adults to experience other ways of life and consider the essential interrelatedness of humans and nature. And most importantly, I had to find a way to give back to the local communities and people who, though they had very little themselves to give, enriched my life and shared with me all that they had, taking care of me while I lived so very far away from home for so long.
And so, I initiated the Jackie Prime Project (www.jackieprime.org).

column1:
The Project The main purpose of the Jackie Prime Project is to create opportunities for young adults to experience other cultures and live in nature, developing their skills of compassion, self-value/confidence and empathy, and to educate people about the interconnectedness of humans and nature.
With the help of a few of my friends and dedicated student volunteers, I have created an enthusiastic group of peers to help me build my vision and share it with others. We believe that knowledge of the connections between humans and nature through active participation in the world fosters harmony, empathy for others, and globally responsible individuals.

We're still a small group, but with your support we can create opportunities for other students to venture outside the classroom and experience the world first hand in a fun, safe, and educational way.
The purpose of this fundraising campaign is to help us raise funds to initiate our prospective core programs:
<ul>
• provide a public platform for students in anthropological, biological, environmental studies/work to showcase their work on our website

• create a mentorship network to mediate opportunities for high school and undergraduate students to connect with graduate students in their prospective area of interest and gain hands on fieldwork experience for future careers/higher education
• promote activities that teach global responsibility through experiential education trips abroad
• provide educational materials, resources and supplies to underprivileged youth living in rural Thailand in the Nakon Ratchasima Province of North-Eastern Thailand where Khao Yai is located

• produce educational videos that highlight ongoing JPP activities and humanitarian work, showcase current academic fieldwork by graduate students and professors around the globe, and detail conservation and environmental topics to keep viewers informed
We need money to:
<ul>
• continue to build and maintain an interactive website for our project

• cover printing and translation costs for posters we made to educate park visitors and staff about the dangers of human-wildlife contact, promoting appropriate activities for nature appreciation  (e.g.: Don’t feed the monkeys, put garbage in provided dispensers, etc.)
• cover distribution costs for our humanitarian efforts to provide clothing and school supplies to young kids living in the Khao Yai area
• purchase additional video equipment to produce our educational videos
• cover travel expenses for our volunteer staff trial-expedition before opening these trips to the general public through our website

Your contribution will help us cover the our development costs allowing us to create opportunities for students to find their passion and connect with nature, AND help underprivileged kids in rural Thailand go to school with the right equipment to get the most out of their education.

Who are we?
CDS
(Conservation and sustainable development) belong to a small non-governmental
organization that facilitates environmental education and research in the
Amazonian cloud forest of Peru. Our team is collaboration between international
scientists, including three Ph.D biologists and a Mg. Educator, people from the
local town of Oxapampa and volunteers from around the globe
committed to the regeneration the natural environment using clean and
sustainable energy. The day to day running of the center is overseen by our Director
Dr. Florencia Trama, accompanied by her 2 year old son Lorenzo.
Where are we?
The CDS center is located in the buffer zone
of the Oxapampa, Ashaninka, and Yanesha UNESCO Biosphere Reserve. CDS is
surrounded by 15.5 hectares of cloud forest, two streams, riparian forest, a
reforested area, and cultivation areas with local fruit crops. The Oxapampa,
Ashaninka, Yanesha UNESCO Biosphere Reserve encompasses 18,673.79 hectares
(4,614,394 Acres) of primary and secondary forest from 300 – 4500 meters above
sea level (984-14,763 feet above sea level).
What do we do?
With the
help of our national and international volunteers we have founded an
environmental education center in the high cloud forest of the Amazonian (Conservation
and Sustainable Development/Conservación y Desarrollo Sostenible CDS), where we
are implementing a range of sustainable projects in order to teach and lead by
example.
There are a
number of projects at the center:
-
Environmental
education courses for university students
-
Education
and practical training for volunteers
-
Replanting
and reforesting native flora
-
Exotic
and invasive species management
-
Recycling
and collecting plastic bottles from local town to construct a greenhouse with
-
In Vitro production of native plant species
-
Production
of compost tea to create organic fertilizer
-
Vegetable
garden using only organic pesticides
-
Production
of non-toxic pesticides using natural ingredients
-
Monitoring
water quality using macroinvertebrates, insects, lichens plants etc. as
bioindicators
-
Water
collection, treatment and irrigation design
-
Using
discarded wood to produce edible fungus
-
Using
recycled materials to construct facilities at the center
Our volunteers
Our
national and international volunteers are a vital part of the center. A diverse
range of people from all around the world travel to the center to become a part
of our team.
Our
volunteers both live and work in the center. We endeavour to make all aspects
of life at <u>CDS</u> as sustainable as possible, as such we have dry
composting toilets, all food waste is used to form compost, and all packaging
is used around the center wherever practical. In addition to the greenhouse, we
are also planning to make a new set of bathrooms using plastic bottles and recycled
materials.
Currently a
gasoline powered generator is used to fulfil the basic energy requirements of
our volunteers whilst they are living at the center – such as charging laptops
on which to complete reports or charging batteries for flashlights. With access
to the necessary funds, we aim to eradicate the need to use gasoline. The small
hydroelectric generator will sufficiently provide clean and sustainable energy
that we can generate ourselves.
Courses at the center
Education
courses are held at the center for groups of up to 35 students from Universidad
Peruana Cayetano Heredia and other institutions. Our team lectures and provides
practical sessions on a number of important topics including: plants,
amphibians, insects, birds, mammals and sampling methods, all of which are
crucial for the continued preservation of the area. We also have to rely upon
the gasoline generator during the course in order to facilitate the needs of 35
students.
How can we improve CDS and how can you help?
To maximise
the efficiency and sustainability of our efforts at the CDS centre, we must
produce our own clean energy
column2: renewable energy that will power the basic needs

column1: of the volunteers and the projects. In order to go completely off-grid and be
independently sustainable, we need to implement a small, localised
hydroelectric power system. By utilizing one of the rivers existent at the center,
the natural flow of the water can be transformed in to clean energy with
minimal impact on our environment. The total cost of the hydroelectric project
is $26,500 USD. A small amount compared with the invaluable worth of the forest,
but unfortunately a sum that is currently out of reach, as the center is
personally funded by the CDS team.
If we are
able to successfully implement this project we will be the first “energetically
sustainable” education and practical training center for conservation and
sustainable development in the Oxapampa, Ashaninka, Yanesha, UNESCO biosphere
reserve.
Access to
these funds would greatly aid our efforts to regenerate the cloud forest and
implement our projects in the most environmentally friendly and sustainable way
possible.
Renewable energy
The process
of becoming energetically independent requires four steps:
1.  Request a government permit to
legally sequester water from the river
Cost of permit = $1,400
2.  Evaluate the property to establish
the most suitable catchment site in the river
Cost of evaluation = $7,500
3.  Design a hydroelectric system with
maximum efficiency
Designing the system will cost $3,700
4.  Construct the hydroelectric system
Constructing the system requires several separate pieces of equipment.
Firstly, we must construct a water channel with a length of 1000 m to lead
water from the river to the CDS site.
The channel will be made using cement and stones, the cost of materials
and labour amounting to $2,500 USD
Secondly, it is necessary to construct a reservoir where the water will
pool. We will create the reservoir with concrete and the cost for materials and
labour is $ 4,500 USD. Lastly, we will install the system including the turbine
($ 5700) and the generator ($ 1,200). The turbine will be moved by the water

and produce clean energy for the center using a generator.


Our recompenses

All contributions will help us to reach our goal. For $1 contribution you will also help to conserve the cloud forest. We will plant one tree on your name.

For a contribution

of $ 5 you will get one tree on your name and an update on your email once a year with our  progress at the center.

For a contribution

of $15 you will get one tree on your name and updates on your email twice a year with our  progress at the center and plans for future development.

For a contribution
of $25 you will receive a digital progress report including photos and videos
of the entire process of the hydroelectrical design and implementation project.
For a
contribution of $50 you will receive the aforementioned progress report and a
full year membership which includes four quarterly newsletters detailing the
progress in the center and plans for future development
you will receive the aforementioned plus a unique book published by our team,
on the macroinvertebrates present in the area. These macroinvertebrates can be
used to assess the water quality and are an indication of the river’s health. (Manual de identificación de
macroinvertebrados acuáticos de la microcuenca San Alberto, Provincia de
Oxapampa, Perú. By Stefany Salcedo and Florencia Trama). The manual was
produced after two years of intensive research in the Oxapampa, Ashaninka,
Yanesha UNESCO Biosphere Reserve. It has more than 200 HQ pictures of aquatic
macroinvertebrates and information on their habitat, natural history and how they
can be of use as bio-indicators of riparian forest conditions.
For $250 you will receive a digital progress report plus a large A3 High quality poster
of native orchids of the Oxapampa, Ashaninka, Yanesha UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.
The poster was produced by the Missouri Botanical Garden office that is located
in the local town of Oxapampa, the town closest to CDS. We will also send you a
handcrafted bag from Tsachopen, the local indigenous community.
For $500
you will receive a digital progress report plus a book of the fruits of the
Amazon produced by the Missouri Botanical Garden. <span>We will also send you your choice of a handcrafted product
from Tsachopen, the local indigenous community.
For $ 1000 you will receive a digital progress report
and your name will be placed on a plaque in one of the five trails at the CDS´s
property.
For $ 2500 you will receive a digital progress report
and will be greatly contributing to the reforestation of the cloud forest. The team will plant 100 native
trees in your honour and your name will be displayed at the entrance of the
reforestation plot in the CDS property, as an official sponsor. 100 trees will
go a long way in helping to restore the beautiful cloud forest to its natural
state.
For $7500 you will receive an exclusive three
days tour of the Biosphere reserve of Oxapampa, visit our CDS center, the
Yanachaga Chemillén National Park which contains an abundance of flora and
fauna, and experience some of the local Oxapampa culture. The tour, which will
not include your ticket to and from Lima, will begin upon your arrival to Oxapampa
and will include: lodging at a traditional German (colonos) style lodge, locally produced and Food for the
duration of your stay, local transportation, and a visit to the renowned indigenous
community of Tsachopen, to explore their native style of living.
With the
generosity of our benefactors, our education center has the potential to create
a huge positive impact on our unique environment. By Leading and teaching by
example, we aim to use an entirely clean and sustainable source of energy, that
will allow us to be self-sufficient and carry out our regeneration activities
with minimal detrimental effects on the environment. Our pioneering education center
will be the first sustainable project of its kind in the biosphere reserve and
in the country.
We are
deeply grateful for all the support we receive, without which CDS would be
unable to have a positive impact on our much loved environment. Each
contribution will help us to preserve the magnificent cloud forest of Peru in a
sustainable way, and also allow us to teach the next generation of people how

to care for their environment.

","Who are we?
CDS
(Conservation and sustainable development) belong to a small non-governmental
organization that facilitates environmental education and research in the
Amazonian cloud forest of Peru. Our team is collaboration between international
scientists, including three Ph.D biologists and a Mg. Educator, people from the
local town of Oxapampa and volunteers from around the globe
committed to the regeneration the natural environment using clean and
sustainable energy. The day to day running of the center is overseen by our Director
Dr. Florencia Trama, accompanied by her 2 year old son Lorenzo.
Where are we?
The CDS center is located in the buffer zone
of the Oxapampa, Ashaninka, and Yanesha UNESCO Biosphere Reserve. CDS is
surrounded by 15.5 hectares of cloud forest, two streams, riparian forest, a
reforested area, and cultivation areas with local fruit crops. The Oxapampa,
Ashaninka, Yanesha UNESCO Biosphere Reserve encompasses 18,673.79 hectares
(4,614,394 Acres) of primary and secondary forest from 300 – 4500 meters above
sea level (984-14,763 feet above sea level).
What do we do?
With the
help of our national and international volunteers we have founded an
environmental education center in the high cloud forest of the Amazonian (Conservation
and Sustainable Development/Conservación y Desarrollo Sostenible CDS), where we
are implementing a range of sustainable projects in order to teach and lead by
example.
There are a
number of projects at the center:
Environmental
education courses for university students
Education
and practical training for volunteers
Replanting
and reforesting native flora
Exotic
and invasive species management
Recycling
and collecting plastic bottles from local town to construct a greenhouse with
In Vitro production of native plant species
Production
of compost tea to create organic fertilizer
Vegetable
garden using only organic pesticides
Production
of non-toxic pesticides using natural ingredients
Monitoring
water quality using macroinvertebrates, insects, lichens plants etc. as
bioindicators
Water
collection, treatment and irrigation design
Using
discarded wood to produce edible fungus
Using
recycled materials to construct facilities at the center
Our volunteers
Our
national and international volunteers are a vital part of the center. A diverse
range of people from all around the world travel to the center to become a part
of our team.
Our
volunteers both live and work in the center. We endeavour to make all aspects
of life at CDS as sustainable as possible, as such we have dry
composting toilets, all food waste is used to form compost, and all packaging
is used around the center wherever practical. In addition to the greenhouse, we
are also planning to make a new set of bathrooms using plastic bottles and recycled
materials.
Currently a
gasoline powered generator is used to fulfil the basic energy requirements of
our volunteers whilst they are living at the center – such as charging laptops
on which to complete reports or charging batteries for flashlights. With access
to the necessary funds, we aim to eradicate the need to use gasoline. The small
hydroelectric generator will sufficiently provide clean and sustainable energy
that we can generate ourselves.
Courses at the center
Education
courses are held at the center for groups of up to 35 students from Universidad
Peruana Cayetano Heredia and other institutions. Our team lectures and provides
practical sessions on a number of important topics including: plants,
amphibians, insects, birds, mammals and sampling methods, all of which are
crucial for the continued preservation of the area. We also have to rely upon
the gasoline generator during the course in order to facilitate the needs of 35
students.
How can we improve CDS and how can you help?
To maximise
the efficiency and sustainability of our efforts at the CDS centre, we must
produce our own clean energy
column2: renewable energy that will power the basic needs

column1: of the volunteers and the projects. In order to go completely off-grid and be
independently sustainable, we need to implement a small, localised
hydroelectric power system. By utilizing one of the rivers existent at the center,
the natural flow of the water can be transformed in to clean energy with
minimal impact on our environment. The total cost of the hydroelectric project
is $26,500 USD. A small amount compared with the invaluable worth of the forest,
but unfortunately a sum that is currently out of reach, as the center is
personally funded by the CDS team.
If we are
able to successfully implement this project we will be the first “energetically
sustainable” education and practical training center for conservation and
sustainable development in the Oxapampa, Ashaninka, Yanesha, UNESCO biosphere
reserve.
Access to
these funds would greatly aid our efforts to regenerate the cloud forest and
implement our projects in the most environmentally friendly and sustainable way
possible.
Renewable energy
The process
of becoming energetically independent requires four steps:
1.  Request a government permit to
legally sequester water from the river
Cost of permit = $1,400
2.  Evaluate the property to establish
the most suitable catchment site in the river
Cost of evaluation = $7,500
3.  Design a hydroelectric system with
maximum efficiency
Designing the system will cost $3,700
4.  Construct the hydroelectric system
Constructing the system requires several separate pieces of equipment.
Firstly, we must construct a water channel with a length of 1000 m to lead
water from the river to the CDS site.
The channel will be made using cement and stones, the cost of materials
and labour amounting to $2,500 USD
Secondly, it is necessary to construct a reservoir where the water will
pool. We will create the reservoir with concrete and the cost for materials and
labour is $ 4,500 USD. Lastly, we will install the system including the turbine
($ 5700) and the generator ($ 1,200). The turbine will be moved by the water
and produce clean energy for the center using a generator.Our recompenses
All contributions will help us to reach our goal. For $1 contribution you will also help to conserve the cloud forest. We will plant one tree on your name.For a contribution
of $ 5 you will get one tree on your name and an update on your email once a year with our  progress at the center.For a contribution
of $15 you will get one tree on your name and updates on your email twice a year with our  progress at the center and plans for future development.For a contribution
of $25 you will receive a digital progress report including photos and videos
of the entire process of the hydroelectrical design and implementation project.
For a
contribution of $50 you will receive the aforementioned progress report and a
full year membership which includes four quarterly newsletters detailing the
progress in the center and plans for future development
you will receive the aforementioned plus a unique book published by our team,
on the macroinvertebrates present in the area. These macroinvertebrates can be
used to assess the water quality and are an indication of the river’s health. (Manual de identificación de
macroinvertebrados acuáticos de la microcuenca San Alberto, Provincia de
Oxapampa, Perú. By Stefany Salcedo and Florencia Trama). The manual was
produced after two years of intensive research in the Oxapampa, Ashaninka,
Yanesha UNESCO Biosphere Reserve. It has more than 200 HQ pictures of aquatic
macroinvertebrates and information on their habitat, natural history and how they
can be of use as bio-indicators of riparian forest conditions.
For $250 you will receive a digital progress report plus a large A3 High quality poster
of native orchids of the Oxapampa, Ashaninka, Yanesha UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.
The poster was produced by the Missouri Botanical Garden office that is located
in the local town of Oxapampa, the town closest to CDS. We will also send you a
handcrafted bag from Tsachopen, the local indigenous community.
For $500
you will receive a digital progress report plus a book of the fruits of the
Amazon produced by the Missouri Botanical Garden. We will also send you your choice of a handcrafted product
from Tsachopen, the local indigenous community.
For $ 1000 you will receive a digital progress report
and your name will be placed on a plaque in one of the five trails at the CDS´s
property.
For $ 2500 you will receive a digital progress report
and will be greatly contributing to the reforestation of the cloud forest. The team will plant 100 native
trees in your honour and your name will be displayed at the entrance of the
reforestation plot in the CDS property, as an official sponsor. 100 trees will
go a long way in helping to restore the beautiful cloud forest to its natural
state.
For $7500 you will receive an exclusive three
days tour of the Biosphere reserve of Oxapampa, visit our CDS center, the
Yanachaga Chemillén National Park which contains an abundance of flora and
fauna, and experience some of the local Oxapampa culture. The tour, which will
not include your ticket to and from Lima, will begin upon your arrival to Oxapampa
and will include: lodging at a traditional German (colonos) style lodge, locally produced and Food for the
duration of your stay, local transportation, and a visit to the renowned indigenous
community of Tsachopen, to explore their native style of living.
With the
generosity of our benefactors, our education center has the potential to create
a huge positive impact on our unique environment. By Leading and teaching by
example, we aim to use an entirely clean and sustainable source of energy, that
will allow us to be self-sufficient and carry out our regeneration activities
with minimal detrimental effects on the environment. Our pioneering education center
will be the first sustainable project of its kind in the biosphere reserve and
in the country.
We are
deeply grateful for all the support we receive, without which CDS would be
unable to have a positive impact on our much loved environment. Each
contribution will help us to preserve the magnificent cloud forest of Peru in a
sustainable way, and also allow us to teach the next generation of people how
to care for their environment.Credits of the video: 3D animation for pelton turbine https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jd5BN7SPkqI",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns
