How we came to be….

Bob Elliott, 35 years a commercial fisherman, now an inventor, entrepreneur and environmentalist was compelled to take action as he witnessed the sinking of a commercial vessel at Ladysmith Harbour, Vancouver Island in 2007. Although most of the thick sludge of oil was soaked up using booms and large “diapers”, an unsightly sheen of diesel remained in the harbour, causing untold damage to marine life.

Every year, catastrophic oil disasters hit the headlines……..the explosion of BP’s Deepwater Horizon platform in the Gulf of Mexico released millions of litres of oil per day…the Exxon Valdez spilled over 40 million litres of oil into Prince William Sound, off the Alaska coast and we have seen oil spewed into our oceans from dozens of collisions, explosions, storms and blowouts. Each incident has been devastating both for marine wildlife and those coastal communities whose livelihoods depend on the bounty of the ocean ( Suzuki, Moola, “Oil addictions” June 2010)

BUT DID YOU KNOW…..??? Each year the equivalent amount of oil as the Exxon Valdez disaster is spilled into our oceans, marinas, streams and waterways from every day runoff from our infrastructures, dirty bilges of commercial vessels, spills at fuel docks, badly maintained boats and ships and accidental sinking of vessels. ( Suzuki, Moola, “Oil addictions” June 2010)

JUST IMAGINE…….if you dripped a quarter of a teaspoon of oil into a five gallon bucket of water each day for a year …..how dirty do you think that water would be after 365 days?

BC’s waters are pristine and productive. They support Canada’s west coast seafood industry, and tourism sector, so the current oil spill and pollution prevention and
response systems are unacceptable…not only for First Nation’s culture and
heritage, but for all of us who are dependent economically on our waterways,
and who care deeply about our environment, and preserving it for future
generations.

In 2013, the Provincial government commissioned a U.S. consultant company, Nuka Research and Planning Group, to review the current oil spill prevention and response regime on the west coast of British Columbia.  The three reports outline
recommendations and considerations for BC to move towards a “World Class
System”.  Reviewing these documents, we were struck by the observation that most of the major progress that has been made in oil spill prevention, preparedness and response, in North America and worldwide, has been catalyzed by a major oil spill.

The oil spill response capacity for British Columbia is heavily focused on the Southern BC area mainly in Vancouver and Juan de Fuca Strait. The report highlighted that other areas of BC coast are extremely vulnerable to oil spills and pollution, not only from a major disaster, but from the type of “minor” incident that Bob
Elliott witnessed at Ladysmith Harbour, seven years ago.

Bob Elliott is a member of Cowichan Tribes, and for generations, fish and other seafood have been the mainstay of his family and community’s existence and culture. In all aspects of his life, the connection to BC’s waterways has been Bob Elliott’s passion – from his heritage and culture to his career as a commercial fisherman.

 

What we have done so far….

The efforts of Bob Elliott (operating as Bob Elliott Sustainable Technologies - B.E.S.T) and his small team has been to develop small oil retrieval units that deal with all types of oil, are easy to manoeuvre, easy to deploy, easy to maintain and are affordable……and can be used for every day “minor” spills or oil retrieval tasks. They can also be stationed at “high risk” sites, such as the remote coastal communities of British Columbia, which cannot be reached over 75% of the time by existing oil response vessels in the event of a disaster, due to the inclement weather.

First Nations and their individual culture are linked with the resources along our vast coastline and across our lands.  They are a people linked to the water and the land and have the experience to work on it.  The ocean is their highway to their fishing
grounds, to their neighbours, and to connect to other coastal cities and
towns.  They also play a role in dealing with at sea incidents by towing boats back to port and assisting at sea rescues, such as the grounding of the BC Ferry “Queen of the North”, by tending to the passengers in the lifeboats immediately after the incident, and later assisting Canadian Coast Guard.  Because of their proximity to the ocean they can respond more quickly to any incident that may occur. The same is true for the Nations living in the remote territories across Canada where they can respond quickly to any accident on land and in the fresh waterways.

We believe First Nations can play a much larger role in the
protection of our marine environment and keeping our waterways clean and safe.

Our campaign is to devise a program to support a First Nations Coastal
Community in developing their own oil spill response capacity in their own
territory.  This proposal is designed initially as a pilot project, which will be the basis of a “blueprint” for oil response systems for all Coastal communities.

Our approach in developing this pilot project is to follow the Norwegian contingency system.  Basically the regions or communities are empowered with equipment (see
below) and training to respond immediately to an oil spill, rather than wait
for a company to respond.  The Canadian federal response planning standard of 72 hours for a spill up to 10,000t for Vancouver and much longer to reach remote areas is not acceptable.

The advantages for using B.E.S.T equipment are:

Ø The equipment is portable and easy to use. 

Ø Can be towed to either marine or inland freshwater systems.

Ø Because of portability difficult coastal inlets can be reached.

Ø Very effective to retrieve various grades of oil and including sheen.

Ø Coastal communities will be able to work independently on inland waterways pollution with the same equipment across all territories.

Ø  Communities working together with a Marine Oil Response Company and
CCG on ocean and coastal spills.

Our proposed response capacity (number of units and their response time) for the pilot community will consist of the provision of oil recovery units, the coordination an oil response team in the community, training to operate the units and additional training for vessel operation and at sea rescue, and coordination with Canada Coast
Guard.  The community’s oil response team will monitor vessel traffic and report any incidence in their territory to a command centre.

There will be an immediate response to any type of spill, large or small.

The Equipment

Over the last three years, Bob Elliott has invested over $100,000 and countless hours into the research and development of the Ace Curtain skimmer and other configurations of the same technology (patent pending)


 

The Ace Curtain Skimmer is a light oil sheen oil skimmer
with 40 rotating heads and carbon fiber skimmer belting. It is designed to be a
fully automatic oil recovery device for up to 2 barrels of light oil per hour.
It can be used for different types of oil kerosene, diesel and light motor
oils. It acts like a curtain in the water.

The Ace Curtain Skimmer is easy to deploy with 316 stainless
steel lifting eye. It is remotely controlled, waterproof and chemical/acid
resistant.

Reclaimed oil is automatically pumped out through a 100ft
discharge hose.

The 40 rotating stainless steel heads on stainless steel
shafts with carbon fiber belting, remove the oil which is “wiped” into a trough,
and then pumped from the Ace Curtain Skimmer.

In this video, you can see the Ace Curtain Skimmer at work.
The same type of technology can be used in all types of situations where oil
retrieval is required…from freighter bilges to storm drains to the tailing
ponds of the mining industry.
column6:
schema=youtube"" width=""580"">

Bob’s focus has been to develop equipment that can deal with
light oils, the kind that leave a “rainbow” sheen on the water, and can also
deal with heavier oil as it starts to sink. Many types of units exist that can
scrape or “slurp up” heavy crude oil as it sits on the top of the water, but
after time the oil will start to sink, and these response units become less
efficient, and start to pick up water.

The beauty of the Ace Curtain skimmer is that it will wick ALL types of oil from the water, with less than 1% water content. This allows the recovered oil to be recycled.

 

What Lies Ahead…..

We need to raise funds to make this Pilot Project a reality. The funds will be used to

1. Identify the coastal community to take part in the pilot project.

2. With key members of the community, identify the oil spill response equipment and training requirement, and establish the necessary protocols, coordinating with agencies such as the Canadian Coastguard, Transport Canada and DFO.

3. Make available the required B.E.S.T equipment

4. Produce a “blueprint” for corporations and government agencies to have communities engaged in Oil Spill  Response Protocols throughout Canada, for
coastal and inland

5. Raise public awareness of the need to overhaul oil spill and disaster response programmes. 

Why create this campaign....?


Why did we choose the crowdsourcing platform? We have achieved so much in the last few years with the help of our family and friends who have believed in this project as much as we have. We believe that there are many more concerned people out there who wish to conserve our environment as passionately as we do. We have attracted interest from “traditional” investors, but the crowdsourcing path will enable us to retain equity and ownership of the products and business and ensure that the passion and vision of this project is always focussed on the end goal…….the protection and enhancement of our waterways.

What do you get……? 

Well first of all, our extreme gratitude for helping with this dream. We will thank
each and every one of you on our social media sites.

For those that fund specific amounts, our perks range from T-shirts with embroidery of our famous duck logo. The logo depicts a native representation of a duck,
salmon and whale. The salmon is the provider of life, and symbol of dependability and prosperity, the whale is a symbol of good guardianship and traveller, and overall the logo shows that our mission is to protect mammals, fish and fowl – all wildlife that depend on clean water environments.

For larger donations, our perks are carvings of our duck logo by a local West Coast artist.

Finally, should your budgets extend to very large amounts, we would love to offer you the opportunity to visit the staggering beautiful coastlines that you are helping protect. 

Whatever the level of your help, it is gratefully received, and even if you are unable to contribute, just helping this project by “sharing” with your social media networks, would be phenomenal.

It’s now time for action….with your help, we can save our waterways…….one drop at a time !!

 

Thank you all for reading this !

 


 

Bob &
column7:
Jackie Elliot and team.

We believe that there are many more concerned people out there who wish to conserve our environment as passionately as we do. We have attracted interest from “traditional” investors, but the crowdsourcing path will enable us to retain equity and ownership of the products and business and ensure that the passion and vision of this project is always focussed on the end goal…….the protection and enhancement of our waterways.What do you get……? Well first of all, our extreme gratitude for helping with this dream. We will thankeach and every one of you on our social media sites.For those that fund specific amounts, our perks range from T-shirts with embroidery of our famous duck logo. The logo depicts a native representation of a duck,salmon and whale. The salmon is the provider of life, and symbol of dependability and prosperity, the whale is a symbol of good guardianship and traveller, and overall the logo shows that our mission is to protect mammals, fish and fowl – all wildlife that depend on clean water environments.For larger donations, our perks are carvings of our duck logo by a local West Coast artist.Finally, should your budgets extend to very large amounts, we would love to offer you the opportunity to visit the staggering beautiful coastlines that you are helping protect. Whatever the level of your help, it is gratefully received, and even if you are unable to contribute, just helping this project by “sharing” with your social media networks, would be phenomenal.It’s now time for action….with your help, we can save our waterways…….one drop at a time !! Thank you all for reading this !  Bob & Jackie Elliot and team.",2.0,1,"1 Campaign

The Low Down

column2: >We intend to use our marathon as a platform to gather eyeballs and hearts to raise awareness and further donations for both Save The Rhino, an organisation dedicated to global Rhino conservation and Cool Earth, a global company dedicated to protecting the Amazon rain forest. When we say our ""marathon"" we're referring to the Rickshaw Run, a massive event held in India every year where teams from around the world travel the length of the country in a tuk tuk in support of various causes. Every team participating in the marathon has been given a donation target to reach for Cool Earth and another charity/cause of their choosing.
>We chose Rhino conservation because we see it as an urgent global issue needing our immediate attention and support. The more people know about it, the more change we can hope spark.

>The video carries a fun tone because we do intend to have fun. But that isn't our only intention. All three of us believe that our talents and efforts are best used when contributing to a better world.
>Your support for our adventure will help us get to India to participate in the race and begin making noise about the need to save our Rhinos.

column1: The perks!

The perks are simple. For your donation of 5 to 10 dollars you get our love and eternal gratitude. And ,of course, you will have the peace of mind knowing you helped efforts to protect a dying species and earth's largest rain forest.
Higher perks buy you a special message sticker on our Tuk Tuk. Include the message in your comments when buying the perk, or send us your logo. Make your mark and show your support on Jemima!
If you prefer to have just your logo without our team name crowding the sticker that can be arranged too.
This is what the sticker looks like:
*All Artwork to be provided by the perk buyer.
We can't promise brand reach, but we will do our best to promote this adventure and your brand.
Rhino Conservation
In 2012, 668 rhinos were killed for their horns in South Africa alone. The horns are sold on the black market for utterly useless medicinal purposes.
This year alone more than 500 South African Rhinos have been murdered - many of them mothers with calves or even unborn babies.

column2: >We’re doing the marathon in an effort to raise awareness about rhino conservation.

column1: But in India? Really? How do our intentions to
raise funds for the protection of South Africa's Rhinos align with
anything to do with India? Well protection of any species is of
global concern when you think about it. We all represent the same
species now don't we? And if we can't protect one species then
all are at threat.
Sure, but how does going to India help
this cause? India once had indigenous Rhino's of it's own which are
now totally wiped out in their country. East Asian countries are the

biggest culprits for the illegal trade in Rhino horns - the number one contributing factor for the decimation of all Rhino species. Being in India puts us in a country that has lost their Rhinos and more importantly close to the countries that are responsible for this atrocity.

Our presence there will also reach the hundreds of other participants on the event who are cause conscious by default and the event will attract massive attention from local, travelers and anyone watching our youtube channel.
The Amazon - CoolEarth.org

Every minute 100 acres of forest are cleared. the amazon provides 20% of the world’s fresh water and oxygen. rain forest destruction cause as much carbon emmissions as the entire USA - some six billion tonnes per year. in 24 hours deforestation will create as much co2 gas as 8 million people flying from london to new york.

So, what Cool Earth does is protect the rainforest by placing donated money into local trusts to ensure that local people living in the rainforest become legal custodians of the land,protect the forest form any illegal logging via ground rangers and satellite imagery, and strategic placement of people and protection plans to prevent loggers, oil miners and cattle farmers from breaching into larger areas.
The Vehicle

column2: >This, taken from the initiative’s website, says it all: “With a pounding heart of 145.45cc pushing 7hp of raw power to three tiny wheels, the humble auto-Rickshaw is a feat of non-engineerance.

>Loud, uncomfortable, prone to breaking down a lot  and completely useless at protecting you from the elements, rickshaws are undoubtedly the ultimate long distance, off-road machine. Despite being designed for short distances, on roads. Possibly the least suitable vehicle on the planet for covering the entire subcontinent in two weeks.”

column5:
>How else can you help?

Spread the word, of course. Any publicity we can get will help get us their and raise awareness. Please share and like our facebook page and use IndieGogo's sharing tools. Feel free to use the comment button to offer any suggestions.

column1: Where is your money going?
Rhino conservation is our number one concern. Save The Rhino will be the recipient of all our donations - http://www.savetherhino.org/

column2:
>Once we've covered expense of getting into the race, the remainder will all go to charity. The deposit we get back from the race will also be donated to charity.

The Vehicle
This, taken from the initiative’s website, says it all: “With a pounding heart of 145.45cc pushing 7hp of raw power to three tiny wheels, the humble auto-Rickshaw is a feat of non-engineerance.

Loud, uncomfortable, prone to breaking down a lot  and completely useless at protecting you from the elements, rickshaws are undoubtedly the ultimate long distance, off-road machine. Despite being designed for short distances, on roads. Possibly the least suitable vehicle on the planet for covering the entire subcontinent in two weeks.”
We’re still game.

How else can you help?Spread the word, of course. Any publicity we can get will help get us their and raise awareness. Please share and like our facebook page and use IndieGogo's sharing tools. Feel free to use the comment button to offer any suggestions.
Where is your money going?
Rhino conservation is our number one concern. Save The Rhino will be the recipient of all our donations - http://www.savetherhino.org/
Once we've covered expense of getting into the race, the remainder will all go to charity. The deposit we get back from the race will also be donated to charity.",4.0,0,"1 Campaign

WHAT: Help raise a salary for Jose, a Punta Banco local trained by NGOs in the protection of sea turtle eggs, who is passionate about continuing his work as a steward of the nesting beaches.

WHY: Visiting poachers walk the beach most nights, digging up nests, or taking the eggs from right under a mother turtle as she lays them.  The eggs are taken to the nearby city of Golfito and sold to the black market.  Three internationally red listed species use these beaches for nesting, and their populations are further diminished by the poaching.

WHERE: Punta Banco, Costa Rica.  An area on the Pacific coast that is hard to get to from the city of San Jose, and thus cannot attract the volunteers needed to support lucrative voluntourism projects that keep other Costa Rican turtle projects going.

The Project: Jose patrols the beach twice every night.  Also on the beach are visiting poachers, ready to snatch up eggs to sell in the nearby city of Golfito.  When Jose finds a nest, he relocates it to a protected hatchery, where the turtle eggs will be left to develop in peace, until he helps them reach the ocean when they hatch.

In my time in Punta Banco, I was able to help Jose with his nightly patrols.  I saw the pride he took in his work, and the danger to teh turtles of letting the poachers take over the beach.  In response, I organized a way to support him, when the NGO that had previously worked in the area left.

A local small business owner now helps with project logistics on the ground, and future years will be sustained by a new model of voluntourism, designed to be successful in this remote area of Costa Rica.  The new plan partners Jose with local small hotel owners, working to save the sea turtles and sustain the community.
But this season, we need your help.

With $500, we will be able to pay Jose's salary through the height of the current nesting season, while helping organize the community-based initiative to make his work self-sustaining in the future, through ecotourism and support of researchers.
Every dollar counts.  Just $7 pays for one night of patrol, protecting up to 350 eggs.

Short Summary

My name Is Romane Simon i am from Haiti, as haitian i know how it feels to be hungry, to need clean water or place to live, i was born in a politic family, my grandfather is a former president of haiti, his name was (Antoine Simon) i always love helping kids, when i was 13 years old i would go out to the street and find kids on the street bring them home to my parents, years later i moved to florida  then move to Hollywood Ca to become a filmmaker, after the Tragic earthquake, i cried like baby to see all these people died, not forget parents left their kids on the street in need of food, clean water and place to live, i feel like i have to do something about it, but i will not be able to do it without you, please help me bring a smile to these kids face,
<div>
<h3>What We Need &amp

When you donate, you dont just donate. You create a future for a child that is less fortunate then you and you show those children that there is someone out there that cares very much for them. You have help build a children’s life!
we set up different perks, only God can repay you for helping these kids, below are few things we have to offer
T-shirt, Jacket, Hats, Letters, and access to communicate with the kids via skype

The goal is to raise 20k, even if we don't reach the Goal, whatever i raise will still be able to help the kids every dollar count, they need our help and support, i know we can''t help all of them i wish i could, but we can do what we can, well let do our part, thank you may God bless you
about my Grandfather
François C. Antoine Simon (aka Antoine Simon) was President of Haiti  He led a rebellion against Pierre Nord Alexis and succeeded him as president.[2]

about my campaign and how your contribution will make a difference:
i never done this before raising money on indiegogo to help the kids, i always do it alone, a friend of mine told me to try indiegogo, well here i am,

i am trying to raise 20,000 dollars, with that money i will be able to help a group of kids by providing them with food, clean water, and Tent to stay, i really really need you help to help this kids,
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help
if you can't contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:
please help to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
you can share this Indiegogo link, thank you for you help
may God bless you

A quick introduction to the desert kit fox project

I'm Dipika Kadaba, a graduate student at Duke University. During my internship at the Center for Biological Diversity in the Summer of 2012, I worked on a petition to list the desert kit fox as threatened under the California Endangered Species Act. While writing the petition, I realised there were large gaps in the literature - specifically, baseline information about numbers of foxes. These gaps led to the petition being rejected by California state authorities. The Desert Kit Fox Project was born of the need for baseline data about this population, and ideas sparked by graduate coursework in innovative non-invasive wildlife monitoring techniques.

Desert kit foxes (Vulpes macrotis arsipus), are a diminutive subspecies of kit fox that are found in arid regions. Very little is known about their population in California, and their desert habitat in the state is facing numerous growing threats from human development. In 2012, foxes in and around a solar energy project began dying from a stress-induced disease outbreak.

A desert kit fox, by Ben Smith
Source
This summer I aim to study where desert kit foxes occupy available habitat, and how the landscape, vegetation, prey species, and human disturbance affects them.

The two things that set this study apart from a conventional survey is the use of a low-cost quadcopter drone to perform rapid aerial surveys, and the recording of desert kit fox footprints for the purpose of developing an identification algorithm for the species. All the techniques we develop are designed to be adaptable to other desert species, and we will also generate data that is informative about the entire desert ecosystem.

Another motivating factor behind my decision to involve crowdfunding and social media in my research was to share this experience with people in my life, connect with new people who share my love for the natural world, and finally, to make full use of being a scientist who lives and works in the age of the internet. Thank you for being a part of this project.
<h3>What We Need and What You Get<span style=""font-size: 10px

1) We need help buying equipment! If you sponsor a specific item by claiming it as a perk, we will send it to you after we use it (as gently as possible!) through the summer. The cost of sponsoring equipment is calculated by adding the cost of the unit, tax, shipping costs to us and to you, and indiegogo's fees. GPS Units, a GoPro, and a terrifyingly awesome quadcopter drone can be claimed in this way. Who doesn't already have drones on their shopping list? Buy one and support a great cause! (Or, if you have used equipment that you can lend us for the duration of the project, get in touch!)
EQUIPMENT DISCLAIMER: Equipment will be used as carefully as possible, and they might bear some signs of use in their line of duty. On the off chance that the equipment fails and becomes non-functional, we will send you a new unit.
<div>

2) We also need money for non-returnable expenses like scent bait, materials to build track plate stations, camping equipment, and a 4WD rental + gas for difficult terrain. This is where the main perks come in.
Wristbands: A 100% silicone eco-friendly wristband that reads ""The Desert Kit Fox Project"". Sport your support for the project, and start conversations about the desert's most charming canine.

Postcards: We'll post you a desert themed postcard with a handwritten message of thanks, to remind you of that time you supported desert kit fox research and how your biologist buddies fended off heatstroke in the desert summer.

Photo prints: As we survey and make our way through the Sonoran desert landscape, we'll be photographing the landscape, our exploits, and desert critters - including aerial shots taken from the drone, and discrete camera trap stills. We'll put up a gallery of all our best shots, and we'll send you a photo print of your favorite one. Don't forget to include your e-mail address!
T-shirts: (My personal favorite!) A gray cotton t-shirt with the official project logo.
Project logo, designed by graphic artist chackosan.blogspot.in
Access this chart to choose your size: Size Chart (XXLs and larger are available too, they just don't show up on the chart)
Wear your love for desert kit foxes, and if you run into one of us, we'll be t-shirt buddies.

Track casts and plates: We'll be laying out powdered contact paper and sanded track plates to capture desert critter footprints to enumerate them and record the prints. We'll also be stumbling across footprints in the wild.
Desert Tracks

We'll send you a plaster cast and track paper pair so you can keep a piece of the wild with you, without taking anything from it. If you're familiar with the Sonoran desert and have a species you're fond of, let us know and we'll reserve it for you if we find it!
Camping trips: Come spend time with us! We want to spend time with you. Spot desert critters with us as we work, and at night, lie back under the desert sky and watch the universe expand.

Funder recognition: Be a Desert Kit Fox Project godparent. We'll love you for it and acknowledge your contribution in all publications that the project generates. Plus everything else we can give you.
All contributions earn our undying gratitude.
<div>
The Impact

Current management of the desert kit fox is entirely inadequate to monitor and prevent population declines due to the range of current and emerging threats to this subspecies. The listing petition discusses the threats in detail for 30 pages.
The expected results of the study are:
<ul>
• Desert kit fox occupancy levels, i.e. how frequently they occupy habitat that is available to them.

• How landscape features, vegetation communities and cover, prey species numbers and compositions, and human disturbance like signs of vehicles and debris affects desert kit fox occupancy levels, as well as the correlations between all these elements themselves.

These ecological data provide an important baseline for further studies on the species, and also aids evidence-based decisions about the management and conservation of desert kit foxes and their habitat.

The desert kit fox can serve as an important umbrella species in their desert ecosystem as they are wide-ranging and their habitat requirements include those of many other species, i.e. creosote scrub bush dwelling animals such as the desert tortoise, burrowing owl, mohave ground squirrel, and others.
The broader impacts of this study include:
<ul>

<li>Development of a low cost, low altitude, quadcopter drone for aerial surveys. The use of drones for conservation is ripe for development as technology comes of age. The quadcopter that we will use can autonomously follow waypoints that are programmed using autopilot software, while it carries a video camera payload. This involves many firsts - the use of drones for this species and this ecosystem, and the first use of a quadcopter for wildlife conservation research to the best of our knowledge. Drones are not often used for conservation in the US due to FAA regulations, so the system that we develop within the regulations can serve as a useful reference for other researchers. The manufacturer of the drone, 3D robotics, maintain open source technology which allows us to keep the cost of the drone as low as possible.
<ul>
<li>

Autopilot software
Source
<li>

Quadcopter by 3d Robotics
Source

<li>The development of an identification algorithm for desert kit foxes based on the sand and paper tracks we capture, with the use of FIT - Footprint Identification Technology - by WildTrack.  FIT provides high levels of accuracy in identifying at the species, individual, age-class and sex levels. The creation of this algorithm will enable low cost non invasive population monitoring in the future. There's a lot of exciting things going on in the world of wildlife footprints
column2: visit WildTrack at http://www.wildtrack.org/.

column1: <div>
Schedule

The project takes place June through August. If we do not reach our funding goal to purchase all the equipment, we will survey smaller areas with whatever methods are available to us (e.g. physical surveys, track plates, spotlighting.)
Other Ways You Can Help
Please share, share, share this page with people who care about conservation, and then share some more.

Stay in touch by connecting with us on facebook (https://www.facebook.com/TheDesertKitFoxProject)
and our blog (http://sites.dukei.edu/thedkfproject/).
If you have questions or suggestions for us, please feel free to let us know on facebook or our blog. You could also shoot me an email at thedfkproject@gmail.com.
If you'd like more information on desert kit foxes, here's a link to the petition: http://www.biologicaldiversity.org/species/mammals/desert_kit_fox/pdfs/Desert-kit-fox-CESA-petition-3-10-13.pdf
Thank you and much love for being a part of the desert kit fox project!

A desert kit fox, by Ben Smith
Source
PS: Here are links to the talented people involved/sourced in the project's video:
Adarsh Raju (Photography and Editing): http://wanderingcanvas.net/home/
Greg Joder (Opening desert kit fox video clip): http://gregjoder.wordpress.com/
Gomer Pyle (Background music): https://www.facebook.com/gomerpylerocks

1) We need help buying equipment! If you sponsor a specific item by claiming it as a perk, we will send it to you after we use it (as gently as possible!) through the summer. The cost of sponsoring equipment is calculated by adding the cost of the unit, tax, shipping costs to us and to you, and indiegogo's fees. GPS Units, a GoPro, and a terrifyingly awesome quadcopter drone can be claimed in this way. Who doesn't already have drones on their shopping list? Buy one and support a great cause! (Or, if you have used equipment that you can lend us for the duration of the project, get in touch!)EQUIPMENT DISCLAIMER: Equipment will be used as carefully as possible, and they might bear some signs of use in their line of duty. On the off chance that the equipment fails and becomes non-functional, we will send you a new unit.

2) We also need money for non-returnable expenses like scent bait, materials to build track plate stations, camping equipment, and a 4WD rental + gas for difficult terrain. This is where the main perks come in.
Wristbands: A 100% silicone eco-friendly wristband that reads ""The Desert Kit Fox Project"". Sport your support for the project, and start conversations about the desert's most charming canine.

Postcards: We'll post you a desert themed postcard with a handwritten message of thanks, to remind you of that time you supported desert kit fox research and how your biologist buddies fended off heatstroke in the desert summer.

Photo prints: As we survey and make our way through the Sonoran desert landscape, we'll be photographing the landscape, our exploits, and desert critters - including aerial shots taken from the drone, and discrete camera trap stills. We'll put up a gallery of all our best shots, and we'll send you a photo print of your favorite one. Don't forget to include your e-mail address!
T-shirts: (My personal favorite!) A gray cotton t-shirt with the official project logo.
Project logo, designed by graphic artist chackosan.blogspot.in
Access this chart to choose your size: Size Chart (XXLs and larger are available too, they just don't show up on the chart)
Wear your love for desert kit foxes, and if you run into one of us, we'll be t-shirt buddies.

Track casts and plates: We'll be laying out powdered contact paper and sanded track plates to capture desert critter footprints to enumerate them and record the prints. We'll also be stumbling across footprints in the wild.
Desert Tracks

We'll send you a plaster cast and track paper pair so you can keep a piece of the wild with you, without taking anything from it. If you're familiar with the Sonoran desert and have a species you're fond of, let us know and we'll reserve it for you if we find it!
Camping trips: Come spend time with us! We want to spend time with you. Spot desert critters with us as we work, and at night, lie back under the desert sky and watch the universe expand.

Funder recognition: Be a Desert Kit Fox Project godparent. We'll love you for it and acknowledge your contribution in all publications that the project generates. Plus everything else we can give you.
All contributions earn our undying gratitude.
The Impact

Current management of the desert kit fox is entirely inadequate to monitor and prevent population declines due to the range of current and emerging threats to this subspecies. The listing petition discusses the threats in detail for 30 pages.
The expected results of the study are:
Desert kit fox occupancy levels, i.e. how frequently they occupy habitat that is available to them.

How landscape features, vegetation communities and cover, prey species numbers and compositions, and human disturbance like signs of vehicles and debris affects desert kit fox occupancy levels, as well as the correlations between all these elements themselves.

These ecological data provide an important baseline for further studies on the species, and also aids evidence-based decisions about the management and conservation of desert kit foxes and their habitat.

The desert kit fox can serve as an important umbrella species in their desert ecosystem as they are wide-ranging and their habitat requirements include those of many other species, i.e. creosote scrub bush dwelling animals such as the desert tortoise, burrowing owl, mohave ground squirrel, and others.
The broader impacts of this study include:

Development of a low cost, low altitude, quadcopter drone for aerial surveys. The use of drones for conservation is ripe for development as technology comes of age. The quadcopter that we will use can autonomously follow waypoints that are programmed using autopilot software, while it carries a video camera payload. This involves many firsts - the use of drones for this species and this ecosystem, and the first use of a quadcopter for wildlife conservation research to the best of our knowledge. Drones are not often used for conservation in the US due to FAA regulations, so the system that we develop within the regulations can serve as a useful reference for other researchers. The manufacturer of the drone, 3D robotics, maintain open source technology which allows us to keep the cost of the drone as low as possible.
Autopilot softwareSource
Quadcopter by 3d RoboticsSource

The development of an identification algorithm for desert kit foxes based on the sand and paper tracks we capture, with the use of FIT - Footprint Identification Technology - by WildTrack.  FIT provides high levels of accuracy in identifying at the species, individual, age-class and sex levels. The creation of this algorithm will enable low cost non invasive population monitoring in the future. There's a lot of exciting things going on in the world of wildlife footprints
Schedule

The project takes place June through August. If we do not reach our funding goal to purchase all the equipment, we will survey smaller areas with whatever methods are available to us (e.g. physical surveys, track plates, spotlighting.)
Other Ways You Can Help
Please share, share, share this page with people who care about conservation, and then share some more.

Stay in touch by connecting with us on facebook (https://www.facebook.com/TheDesertKitFoxProject)and our blog (http://sites.dukei.edu/thedkfproject/). If you have questions or suggestions for us, please feel free to let us know on facebook or our blog. You could also shoot me an email at thedfkproject@gmail.com.
If you'd like more information on desert kit foxes, here's a link to the petition: http://www.biologicaldiversity.org/species/mammals/desert_kit_fox/pdfs/Desert-kit-fox-CESA-petition-3-10-13.pdf
Thank you and much love for being a part of the desert kit fox project!
A desert kit fox, by Ben SmithSource
PS: Here are links to the talented people involved/sourced in the project's video:
Adarsh Raju (Photography and Editing): http://wanderingcanvas.net/home/
Greg Joder (Opening desert kit fox video clip): http://gregjoder.wordpress.com/
Gomer Pyle (Background music): https://www.facebook.com/gomerpylerocks",6.0,0,"1 Campaign

Habitat ID

Has been involved in Cambodia's Virachey National Park since 2012. Since that time we have been involved in exploratory expeditions to remote areas where tourists have never been taken before (the Yak Yeuk Grasslands in January 2013), and earlier this we set up 11 motion-triggered camera-traps in the Veal Thom Grasslands-Upper Gan Yu River area (you can have a look at some of the amazing results that were produced in under 2 months of filming here). 


Furthermore, in order to make servicing our cameras a sustainable operation, we have cooperated with Virachey National Park staff to establish a new form of tourism that we call ""camera-trap ecotourism"" which you can read about here. We want to launch a double-pronged project in January with one group of field staff and park rangers bringing camera-traps to the Yak Yeuk Grasslands and the other checking on our most remote cameras along the Laos border by the sacred Haling-Halang Mountains, an area in which we would like to install several more cameras. 


What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

column1: • We will be hosting a fundraising party in Chicago on June 21st, and this online Indiegogo campaign is for those who would like to make a donation but who cannot attend the Chicago event.

• All funds that we raise will go directly toward field equipment and expenses, including: camera-traps, protective cases, python cables, locks, memory cards, batteries, as well as guide fees and provisions.
• People who donate can receive personal copies of our camera-trap images as well as updates about our project and stories from the field.

The Impact

We have already proven in a very short time that Virachey NP is still brimming with wildlife, some of it very rare and endangered.

• We are currently working on contacting the large and long-established conservation NGOs to have a look at our early camera trap results in an effort to bring them back to the Park to join us in protecting this rich tropical forest and its wildlife.

• With more photos from Yak Yeuk and Haling-Halang, we will be able to make a stronger case for government support for the Park and for international groups to invest in protection programs for it as well.

• Habitat ID is currently doing what other conservation groups and the government either cannot or will not do -putting boots on the ground in the most remote sections of the Park to survey for wildlife.The photo below shows what is very likely an animal that is new to science, caught in one of our camera traps: a civet cat with a single white band near the tip of its tail:
<li>

Other Ways You Can Help

If you would like to contribute cameras or equipment such as protective cases, cables, memory cards, batteries, or other field supplies, please email me at gregmccann1@yahoo.com and I can let you know what you can do.

VIET NAM GREEN VILLAGE SUMMARY
<ul>
<li>
Be A Part of History by helping us raise $150,000 to produce the Viet Nam Green Village Expo &
column2: Green Village Documentary hosted by 3RockD, and the project's Master Architect, Eric Lloyd Wright, grandson of Frank Lloyd Wright.  This broadband streamed event will take place in Los Angeles, California, this November 2013.

column1: <li>On January 22, 2010, the People's Committee of Quy Nhon, Viet Nam
column2: the Urban Development Department of the Ministry of Construction of Viet Nam
column3: Globalization Research Center University of Hawaii-Manoa
column4: and 3rd Rock Development LLC (‘3RockD’), signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) outlining development plans for the first organically designed and developed Green Village in Viet Nam.

column1: • Over the last four years, 3RockD, Eric Lloyd Wright and Associates, five American universities (University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill, University of Hawaii-Manoa, Columbia Univeristy, University of Oregan, Cal Poly SLO), development partners, the city of Quy Nhon, and the Viet Nam Ministry of Construction, have joined in a historic collaboration to design the Master Plan for the creation of the 3RockD Economic Green Zone, Quy Nhon, Viet Nam--the first truely organically designed and developed green city on earth.

column3: WHAT YOU GET (SEE PERKS TO THE RIGHT)

column1: <div>

The purpose of this campaign is to raise $150,000 to fund the project documentary, and to fund the Viet Nam Green Village Expo Fall 2013 hosted by Eric Lloyd Wright, to be held in Los Angeles November 2013.  The Green Village Expo brings students from the universities involved in the planning and design process, together with Vietnamese government representatives, global media partners, green thought leaders, renowned architects and planners, and global development partners for the formal introduction of Viet Nam's Green Village Master Plan.

The Viet Nam Green Village Expo Fall 2013 will feature exhibition space to showcase sustainable products, services, and techology.  This outdoor event will also feature live music, sustainable food vendors, and networking opportunities to learn how to take part in the building of Viet Nam’s first green organic city.  Your contribution helps make history, and will help us build a greener future.
<div>
THE IMPACT
3RockD draws upon the experience and legacy of organic architecture from its Master Architect, Eric Lloyd Wright
column3: and his grandfather, Frank Lloyd Wright
column4: to design, build, and manage the model for, and example of, Organic Architecture applied to the creation of a nascent city--the Economic Green Zone, Quy Nhon, Viet Nam.

column1: <div>
<h3 class=""_mce_tagged_br"">OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP &amp

We are looking for volunteers that want to help with this project.  We are actively seeking business leaders and green entreprenuers that want to showcase their sustainable techonology using our project.  3RockD serves as a gateway to the Vietnamese &
column2: Asian Green Economy.  We invite you to walk through this historic open door.

THE GROUND RULES (TGR), a community action and research project in Chicago, proposes a timely and highly visible model to re-imagine the waste streams and biological infrastructures of a city. Process-focused and committed to observation, learning, and productivity, THE GROUND RULES is a living experiment in rediscovering the wealth we already possess as communities – and in coaxing its re-emergence into new being.

Radical Mycology podcast


What THE GROUND RULES does:

column1: • Run a fee-based organic waste collection service for institutions, organizations, restaurants and other food purveyors
• Create top-notch, quality compost to be shared with our garden partners for their food production and our bioremediation projects
• Train and educate citizens in:
<ul>
• Building compost systems and practices that meet their needs as well as meet City code
• soil biology, structure, and chemistry
• compost technologies
• community bioremediation
Our current Community Soil Center locations:
• Humboldt Park (Demonstration Remediation Site)
• Logan Square
• Back of the Yards
• Garfield Park
• North Lawndale
Your financial support helps us complete our five 2015 Commitments:
• Build out Community Soil Centers at our two locations (beginning March/April)
• Continue work on our Demonstration Remediation Site
• Publication of The Ground Rules Manual: Healing our Urban Soils Together, a manual on advanced composting techniques and urban bioremediation (due out Summer)
• Hold hands-on workshops on “Mushroom Cultivation” and “Urban Bioremediation” (late Summer/early Fall)
• Organize and hold a Town Hall Meeting concerning local soils (early Winter)
Other Ways You Can Help:
• Come volunteer at one of our Community Soil Centers.
• Tell your local restaurants, especially ""farm-to-table"" restaurants, about us and our composting services.
• Share our campaign with your friends.

column2: >Attend our workshops and/or town hall meeting.

column1: Abstract
Budget
Rewards
What are we doing now?
Main Challenges
How can I help if I can't donate?
ABSTRACT
We are a Colombian non-profit organization that
aims to protect an ancient forest that used to be an ecosystem full of life.
The oil exploitations, large-scale livestock and
monocultures have destroyed at least the 70% of the Colombian forest.
Local communities have realized the damage, but
their efforts seem not to be enough.
The government considers mining and oil
exploitation as part of the economic growth of the country. The Colombian
environmental laws are very flexible and in this regions represent a major risk
to the water and forest.
The negative impact on the environment is
overwhelming. Rivers have dried up, hundred of species have disappeared and the
problem goes on (recent Colombian related news).
With your help we will protect the forest for
the further generations.
This project seeks to protect and restore 121
hectares (298.9 acres) of forest.
However, if we raise more funds, we will
purchase the surrounding land that used to be part of the forest. In this way
we can restore what used to be a 1500 hectares (3700 acres) forest.
We deeply believe that human health depends on
the planet wellbeing.
Medicines, food and water depend on biodiversity.  Without the vastness biodiversity human’s
health will be condemned.
Literature has shown that vector transmitted diseases
like Malaria, Chagas, Dengue and Chikinguña have become endemic because of the
lost of the mosquito natural habitat and their natural predators such as frogs
and spiders.
New medicines development also depends on plants
and animals availability. Because of plants and animals extinction we have lost
the opportunity to find new medicine.
If we do not save this forest, it will be
extinguish.

Help us to give the forest one last chance. 

Up
BUDGET
This project seeks to protect and restore 121
hectares (298.9 acres) of forest.
However, if we raise more funds, we will purchase
the surrounding land that used to be part of the forest. In this way we can
restore what used to be a 1500 hectares (3700 acres) forest.
The funds will go to plant and restore 121
hectares (298.9 acres) of forest, purchase the lands that belong to private landowners,
and pay the fee to become a protected natural reserve.
80% of the budget will be committed to purchase
the land where the remaining forest, the river and the water sources are
located.
16% of the budget will be committed to plant and
restore 121 hectares (298.9 acres) with native flora.
2% of the budget will be committed to educational
purposes. We will build a small place base on permaculture principles (10
hectares, 25 acres) for workshops and community meetings.
2% remaining of the budget will be used to pay
taxes, protection licenses and the first year maintenance of the natural
reserve.
Up
REWARDS
We have planed 10 different rewards for our
donors:

WHAT
WE ARE DOING NOW?
To make the Reserve comes true it will take at least five years, but we have
already started.
Today the reserve has 10 hectares (24 acres). Two hectares (4,94 acres) are
part of the remaining forest.
During
the past two years we had developed the ElCampus.org
project. El Campus is the first step for the reserve. We did the flora and
fauna inventory in order to show the world the species that lives in the
forest. We installed a ram (air pump, ariete) that uses the energy of the river
for water distribution. We delivered clean energy and biodiversity workshops
among the local community. We had planted many trees in order to protect the
water sources and restore the forest. We have received several volunteers who
have helped us to care for the land and build the seed house. We have done
advocacy in order to support the local community to promote laws that regulated
oil exploitation in the region. Please take a look of the ElCampus.org website to learn more about us and see
pictures.
Currently, we are now increasingly involving the community and local
authorities in the project so they can understand the benefits of protecting
the forest and natural resources.
Up
MAIN
CHALLENGES
In Colombia the environmental laws are very flexible and in this regions
represent a major risk to the water and forest. The main challenge is to
purchase the surrounding lands in order to protect the all water sources and
forest.
Currently, we are now increasingly involving the community and local
authorities in the project so they can understand the benefits of protecting
the forest and natural resources.
The second challenge is sustainability. We have developed a network with
local schools and markets in order to establish a plan to sustain the reserve.
The main goal is to include the local government to protect and support the
area.
One of the main risk is that we cannot buy all the land where are the water
sources.  If we cannot protect the
surrounding land, we may face water pollution from distant sources that could affect
the animals in the reserve.
At
the moment, the community and landowners have agreed to sell 121 hectares (298
acres) to the project.

RESUMEN DEL PROYECTO
Somos una organización sin ánimo de lucro con sede en
Colombia que busca proteger un bosque antiguo que alberga diversos nacederos de
agua, cientos de animales y especies vegetales pero que se encuentra en
peligro.
La explotación petrolera, la ganadería y los cultivos a
gran escala han destruido por lo menos el 70% del bosque del oriente
Colombiano.
Las comunidades locales, en especial los abuelos que
conocieron los grandes ríos, se han dado cuenta del daño que se ha causado,
pero su lucha por detenerlo parece no ser suficiente.
Actualmente el Gobierno considera a la explotación
petrolera y la minería como parte del crecimiento económico del País y las
leyes Colombianas son demasiado flexibles, lo que representa un riesgo altísimo
para el agua y el bosque de esta región.
El impacto negativo en el ambiente de esta situación ha
sido contundente. Los ríos se han secado, miles de especies han desaparecido y
el problema continua (ver noticias recientes).
Lo que antes era un corredor de bosque lleno de vida, es
ahora un ecosistema que agoniza.
Con tu ayuda estaremos protegiendo este corredor de
bosque, logrando así que las futuras generaciones y que la humanidad cuente con
un territorio más lleno de vida que estará protegido por siempre.
Este proyecto busca proteger y restaurar 121 hectáreas de
bosque. No obstante si logramos recoger más fondos, compraremos las tierras
vecinas que hacían parte de las 1500 hectáreas del bosque original.
Creemos profundamente que la salud del hombre depende del
bienestar del planeta así que debemos cuidarlo.
Las medicinas, la comida y el agua dependen de la
biodiversidad. Sin la vasta de biodiversidad la salud del hombre está
condenada.
Varios estudios han mostrado que la aparición de
epidemias de enfermedades trasmitidas por vectores como la Malaria, el Dengue,
la enfermedad de Chagas y la fiebre del Chikunguña, así como su aparición en
nuevas regiones, se debe a la pérdida del hábitat natural del mosquito y a la
desaparición de sus predadores naturales como las ranas y las arañas.
Del mismo modo el desarrollo de nuevos medicamentos, como
por ejemplo, la vincristina para el cáncer, depende de la biodiversidad y de la
supervivencia de especies animales y vegetales que hoy están amenazadas de
extinción.
No intentar salvar este bosque significaría condenarlo a
muerte. Sus especies, como el armadillo que vive en esta zona, se extinguirán y
las fuentes de agua restantes, como ha sucedido en esta misma región con otros
ríos, pronto se secaran.
Ayúdanos a darle al bosque una última oportunidad.
Volver
PRESUPUESTO DEL PROYECTO
Este proyecto busca proteger y restaurar 121 hectáreas de
bosque. No obstante, si logramos recoger más fondos, compraremos las tierras
vecinas que hacían parte de las 1500 hectáreas del bosque original.
Los fondos recolectados serán destinados para plantar y
restaurar 121 hectáreas de bosque, comprar las tierras que son parte del bosque
y pagar los impuestos para declarar la zona como reserva natural.
El 80% del presupuesto será dedicado a comprar las
tierras vecinas que tienen bosque y los nacimientos de agua.
El 16% del presupuesto será dedicado a la restauración
con árboles nativos y originarios de la zona.
El 2% del presupuesto será dedicado a educación. Con base
en principios permaculturales construiremos salones para talleres. Estos
espacios se dedicaran a generar redes con la comunidad local y fomentar la
protección ambiental.
El 2% restante se destinará a las licencias de
protección, impuestos, cuidado y mantenimiento de la reserva durante su primer
año.
Volver

Volver
¿QUÉ HEMOS HECHO Y QUÉ ESTAMOS HACIENDO?
Hacer realidad la reserva natural y proteger la tierra
tomará por lo menos 5 años. No obstante, ya hemos empezado.
Actualmente la reserva cuenta con 10 hectáreas (24 acres)
de terrero, de las cuales 2 corresponden al núcleo del bosque. Tenemos dos
nacederos de agua, una porción de la quebrada y un terreno que corresponde a un
corredor natural de paso para animales como la nutria, los micos, los
armadillos y diversas aves.
Desde hace dos años hemos venido trabajando en
desarrollar el proyecto llamado ElCampus.org. El Campus es el primer paso para
la reserva. Durante este tiempo realizamos el inventario de flora y fauna del
bosque para poder mostrarle al mundo las especies que viven en él.
Instalamos un ariete o bomba hidráulica que usa la energía de la quebrada para
distribuir el agua sin tener que usar gasolina. Dictamos talleres de energías
limpias y biodiversidad a las comunidades locales. Hemos plantado muchos
árboles para proteger los nacimientos de agua y restaurar el bosque. Hemos
recibido varios voluntarios que nos han ayudado a cuidar la tierra y construir
el semillero. Hemos apoyado a la comunidad local en la lucha para regular la

explotación petrolera en la región. 

Te invitamos a visitar la pagina web ElCampus.org
para que conozcas más del proyecto y puedas ver las fotos.
Actualmente estamos involucrando más a la comunidad y a
las autoridades locales para que puedan entender los beneficios de proteger el

bosque y los recursos naturales. 

Volver
LOS PRINCIPALES RETOS
En Colombia las leyes ambientales son muy flexibles, lo que representa un gran riesgo para el agua y los bosques de esta región. El
reto principal es la compra de las tierras circundantes con el fin de proteger
a la todas las fuentes de agua y los bosques. <span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column2: >En ese sentido estamos involucrando cada vez más a la

column1: comunidad y a las autoridades locales en el proyecto, para que puedan entender los
beneficios de la protección de los bosques y los recursos naturales.
El segundo reto es la sostenibilidad. Actualmente hemos
desarrollado una red con las escuelas y los mercados locales con el fin de
establecer un plan para mantener la reserva. El objetivo principal consiste en
incluir al gobierno local para proteger y apoyar a la zona.
Uno de los principales riesgos es que no podamos comprar
todos los terrenos donde están las fuentes de agua. Si no podemos proteger
estas tierras circundantes, será difícil enfrentar los riesgos de contaminación del agua de
fuentes distantes que pueden afectar a los animales en la reserva.
Por el momento, la comunidad y los propietarios han
acordado la venta de 121 hectáreas (298 acres) al proyecto.
Volver
¿DE QUÉ OTRAS
FORMAS PUEDO AYUDAR?
Si quieres ayudar pero no puedes donar, no te preocupes,
existen muchas otras formas de colaborar con el proyecto.
<li>
<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
nuestra campaña a través de las herramientas para compartir de Indiegogo.
<li>
<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
amigos y contactos a que nos ayuden.
<li>
<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
voluntario. Visita la pagina del proyecto para ser voluntario
¡Gracias por colaborarnos! No olvides compartir nuestra campaña.
Volver

ABSTRACT
We are a Colombian non-profit organization that
aims to protect an ancient forest that used to be an ecosystem full of life.
The oil exploitations, large-scale livestock and
monocultures have destroyed at least the 70% of the Colombian forest.
Local communities have realized the damage, but
their efforts seem not to be enough.
The government considers mining and oil
exploitation as part of the economic growth of the country. The Colombian
environmental laws are very flexible and in this regions represent a major risk
to the water and forest.
The negative impact on the environment is
overwhelming. Rivers have dried up, hundred of species have disappeared and the
problem goes on (recent Colombian related news).
With your help we will protect the forest for
the further generations.
This project seeks to protect and restore 121
hectares (298.9 acres) of forest.
However, if we raise more funds, we will
purchase the surrounding land that used to be part of the forest. In this way
we can restore what used to be a 1500 hectares (3700 acres) forest.
We deeply believe that human health depends on
the planet wellbeing.
Medicines, food and water depend on biodiversity.  Without the vastness biodiversity human’s
health will be condemned.
Literature has shown that vector transmitted diseases
like Malaria, Chagas, Dengue and Chikinguña have become endemic because of the
lost of the mosquito natural habitat and their natural predators such as frogs
and spiders.
New medicines development also depends on plants
and animals availability. Because of plants and animals extinction we have lost
the opportunity to find new medicine.
If we do not save this forest, it will be
extinguish.
Help us to give the forest one last chance. Up
BUDGET
This project seeks to protect and restore 121
hectares (298.9 acres) of forest.
However, if we raise more funds, we will purchase
the surrounding land that used to be part of the forest. In this way we can
restore what used to be a 1500 hectares (3700 acres) forest.
The funds will go to plant and restore 121
hectares (298.9 acres) of forest, purchase the lands that belong to private landowners,
and pay the fee to become a protected natural reserve.
80% of the budget will be committed to purchase
the land where the remaining forest, the river and the water sources are
located.
16% of the budget will be committed to plant and
restore 121 hectares (298.9 acres) with native flora.
2% of the budget will be committed to educational
purposes. We will build a small place base on permaculture principles (10
hectares, 25 acres) for workshops and community meetings.
2% remaining of the budget will be used to pay
taxes, protection licenses and the first year maintenance of the natural
reserve.
Up

Up
WHAT
WE ARE DOING NOW?
To make the Reserve comes true it will take at least five years, but we have
already started.
Today the reserve has 10 hectares (24 acres). Two hectares (4,94 acres) are
part of the remaining forest.
During
the past two years we had developed the ElCampus.org
project. El Campus is the first step for the reserve. We did the flora and
fauna inventory in order to show the world the species that lives in the
forest. We installed a ram (air pump, ariete) that uses the energy of the river
for water distribution. We delivered clean energy and biodiversity workshops
among the local community. We had planted many trees in order to protect the
water sources and restore the forest. We have received several volunteers who
have helped us to care for the land and build the seed house. We have done
advocacy in order to support the local community to promote laws that regulated
oil exploitation in the region. Please take a look of the ElCampus.org website to learn more about us and see
pictures.
Currently, we are now increasingly involving the community and local
authorities in the project so they can understand the benefits of protecting
the forest and natural resources.
Up
MAIN
CHALLENGES
In Colombia the environmental laws are very flexible and in this regions
represent a major risk to the water and forest. The main challenge is to
purchase the surrounding lands in order to protect the all water sources and
forest.
Currently, we are now increasingly involving the community and local
authorities in the project so they can understand the benefits of protecting
the forest and natural resources.
The second challenge is sustainability. We have developed a network with
local schools and markets in order to establish a plan to sustain the reserve.
The main goal is to include the local government to protect and support the
area.
One of the main risk is that we cannot buy all the land where are the water
sources.  If we cannot protect the
surrounding land, we may face water pollution from distant sources that could affect
the animals in the reserve.
At
the moment, the community and landowners have agreed to sell 121 hectares (298
acres) to the project.

RESUMEN DEL PROYECTO
Somos una organización sin ánimo de lucro con sede en
Colombia que busca proteger un bosque antiguo que alberga diversos nacederos de
agua, cientos de animales y especies vegetales pero que se encuentra en
peligro.
La explotación petrolera, la ganadería y los cultivos a
gran escala han destruido por lo menos el 70% del bosque del oriente
Colombiano.
Las comunidades locales, en especial los abuelos que
conocieron los grandes ríos, se han dado cuenta del daño que se ha causado,
pero su lucha por detenerlo parece no ser suficiente.
Actualmente el Gobierno considera a la explotación
petrolera y la minería como parte del crecimiento económico del País y las
leyes Colombianas son demasiado flexibles, lo que representa un riesgo altísimo
para el agua y el bosque de esta región.
El impacto negativo en el ambiente de esta situación ha
sido contundente. Los ríos se han secado, miles de especies han desaparecido y
el problema continua (ver noticias recientes).
Lo que antes era un corredor de bosque lleno de vida, es
ahora un ecosistema que agoniza.
Con tu ayuda estaremos protegiendo este corredor de
bosque, logrando así que las futuras generaciones y que la humanidad cuente con
un territorio más lleno de vida que estará protegido por siempre.
Este proyecto busca proteger y restaurar 121 hectáreas de
bosque. No obstante si logramos recoger más fondos, compraremos las tierras
vecinas que hacían parte de las 1500 hectáreas del bosque original.
Creemos profundamente que la salud del hombre depende del
bienestar del planeta así que debemos cuidarlo.
Las medicinas, la comida y el agua dependen de la
biodiversidad. Sin la vasta de biodiversidad la salud del hombre está
condenada.
Varios estudios han mostrado que la aparición de
epidemias de enfermedades trasmitidas por vectores como la Malaria, el Dengue,
la enfermedad de Chagas y la fiebre del Chikunguña, así como su aparición en
nuevas regiones, se debe a la pérdida del hábitat natural del mosquito y a la
desaparición de sus predadores naturales como las ranas y las arañas.
Del mismo modo el desarrollo de nuevos medicamentos, como
por ejemplo, la vincristina para el cáncer, depende de la biodiversidad y de la
supervivencia de especies animales y vegetales que hoy están amenazadas de
extinción.
No intentar salvar este bosque significaría condenarlo a
muerte. Sus especies, como el armadillo que vive en esta zona, se extinguirán y
las fuentes de agua restantes, como ha sucedido en esta misma región con otros
ríos, pronto se secaran.
Ayúdanos a darle al bosque una última oportunidad.
Volver
PRESUPUESTO DEL PROYECTO
Este proyecto busca proteger y restaurar 121 hectáreas de
bosque. No obstante, si logramos recoger más fondos, compraremos las tierras
vecinas que hacían parte de las 1500 hectáreas del bosque original.
Los fondos recolectados serán destinados para plantar y
restaurar 121 hectáreas de bosque, comprar las tierras que son parte del bosque
y pagar los impuestos para declarar la zona como reserva natural.
El 80% del presupuesto será dedicado a comprar las
tierras vecinas que tienen bosque y los nacimientos de agua.
El 16% del presupuesto será dedicado a la restauración
con árboles nativos y originarios de la zona.
El 2% del presupuesto será dedicado a educación. Con base
en principios permaculturales construiremos salones para talleres. Estos
espacios se dedicaran a generar redes con la comunidad local y fomentar la
protección ambiental.
El 2% restante se destinará a las licencias de
protección, impuestos, cuidado y mantenimiento de la reserva durante su primer
año.

¿QUÉ HEMOS HECHO Y QUÉ ESTAMOS HACIENDO?
Hacer realidad la reserva natural y proteger la tierra
tomará por lo menos 5 años. No obstante, ya hemos empezado.
Actualmente la reserva cuenta con 10 hectáreas (24 acres)
de terrero, de las cuales 2 corresponden al núcleo del bosque. Tenemos dos
nacederos de agua, una porción de la quebrada y un terreno que corresponde a un
corredor natural de paso para animales como la nutria, los micos, los
armadillos y diversas aves.
Desde hace dos años hemos venido trabajando en
desarrollar el proyecto llamado ElCampus.org. El Campus es el primer paso para
la reserva. Durante este tiempo realizamos el inventario de flora y fauna del
bosque para poder mostrarle al mundo las especies que viven en él.
Instalamos un ariete o bomba hidráulica que usa la energía de la quebrada para
distribuir el agua sin tener que usar gasolina. Dictamos talleres de energías
limpias y biodiversidad a las comunidades locales. Hemos plantado muchos
árboles para proteger los nacimientos de agua y restaurar el bosque. Hemos
recibido varios voluntarios que nos han ayudado a cuidar la tierra y construir
el semillero. Hemos apoyado a la comunidad local en la lucha para regular la
explotación petrolera en la región. Te invitamos a visitar la pagina web ElCampus.org
para que conozcas más del proyecto y puedas ver las fotos.
Actualmente estamos involucrando más a la comunidad y a
las autoridades locales para que puedan entender los beneficios de proteger el
bosque y los recursos naturales. Volver
LOS PRINCIPALES RETOS
En Colombia las leyes ambientales son muy flexibles, lo que representa un gran riesgo para el agua y los bosques de esta región. El
reto principal es la compra de las tierras circundantes con el fin de proteger
a la todas las fuentes de agua y los bosques. En ese sentido estamos involucrando cada vez más a la
comunidad y a las autoridades locales en el proyecto, para que puedan entender los
beneficios de la protección de los bosques y los recursos naturales.
El segundo reto es la sostenibilidad. Actualmente hemos
desarrollado una red con las escuelas y los mercados locales con el fin de
establecer un plan para mantener la reserva. El objetivo principal consiste en
incluir al gobierno local para proteger y apoyar a la zona.
Uno de los principales riesgos es que no podamos comprar
todos los terrenos donde están las fuentes de agua. Si no podemos proteger
estas tierras circundantes, será difícil enfrentar los riesgos de contaminación del agua de
fuentes distantes que pueden afectar a los animales en la reserva.
Por el momento, la comunidad y los propietarios han
acordado la venta de 121 hectáreas (298 acres) al proyecto.
Volver
¿DE QUÉ OTRAS
FORMAS PUEDO AYUDAR?
Si quieres ayudar pero no puedes donar, no te preocupes,
existen muchas otras formas de colaborar con el proyecto.
Puedes compartir
nuestra campaña a través de las herramientas para compartir de Indiegogo.
Puedes invitar a tus
amigos y contactos a que nos ayuden.
Puedes ser
voluntario. Visita la pagina del proyecto para ser voluntario ElCampus.org
¡Gracias por colaborarnos! No olvides compartir nuestra campaña.
