Permaculture, spirit, and activism
- three very potent tools to regenerate our world.  I'm Starhawk, and I’m
the author of twelve books on the intersections of earth-based spirituality and
social change organizing, including my visionary novel The Fifth Sacred Thing.
But I don’t just write about them, I try to practice them in my life and
in what I teach.
I started Earth Activist Training
because I wanted a program that could combine them all.  Permaculture is a
holistic ecological design system that includes powerful tools that can help us
heal damaged land, rebuild communities, and create truly sustainable
abundance.  We teach it with a
grounding in spirit—personal regeneration--and a focus on organizing and
activism.  In our permaculture
design course, students learn how to heal damaged soil, grow food organically,
bioremediate toxins, harvest water and re-use graywater, build low-cost,
low-carbon housing, and so many other skills.  And most of all, they learn how all the aspects of
sustainability can fit together so that we can meet our human needs while
caring for the natural systems around us. Permaculture offers solutions to some
of our most grave ecological problems.
The communities that most need
these tools are those who are on the front lines of environmental and social
struggles – our depressed inner cities, indigenous reserves where jobs and
resources are scarce, desertifying drylands and war-torn lands in the developing
world.  To share this knowledge, we
need to train people who come from those communities.  They are the best ambassadors and most effective teachers!
So Earth Activist Training offers
Diversity Scholarships to people of color who are working in environmental and
food justice.  From the urban food
deserts to the deserts of African, our students are doing amazing work!  They’re people like Menhuam Ayele, an
architecture student who is training former gang members to build a greenhouse
in San Francisco’s most depressed neighborhood.  Or Brandy Mack, who works with young girls who live in
public housing and helps them grow both food and self-esteem.  Or Tesfaye Johanson, who was born in
the Afar region of Ethiopia and now works to bring land and water programs in
his ancestral village.  Or David
Ortiz, a Blackfoot Nation permaculture designer who works for tribal water
rights.  Carmen Shorter helps women
make the transition from addiction and homelessness to treatment and next
steps.  Eighteen-year-old Ruby
Avila is developing gardens in her community.  Rushelle Frazier is an accomplished poet who is developing a
permaculture retreat center for Veterans.
You can meet them all in the video,
and by contributing to our campaign you can be part of their work, and others
like them.
These are the leaders and
visionaries who give me hope. I feel so honored to have skills and tools to
share that I know can boost their efforts, help them regenerate their spirit
and enthusiasm after hard times, and empower communities.
If you could do something to help heal the world, would you
plant rain gardens on the Paiute reserve in Nevada, or camp out in the path of
an oil pipeline, or inspire inner city youth to make environmental art, or
research the potential to sequester carbon with compost, or start rooftop
gardens in the South Bronx?  No one
of us can do it all, but all of us can be part of weaving this network of
support for all the visionaries who are turning problems into solutions.
Earth Activist Training offers
two-week residential permaculture design certificate courses, which are the
gateway into the global permaculture movement and a strong foundation for a
career in sustainability.  We hope
to raise $10,000 or more with this campaign, to cover our costs for ten or more Diversity Scholarship recipients.
Any additional money we raise will seed scholarships and work trade
opportunities for upcoming short courses in natural building, a Spring Equinox
retreat, and a second permaculture design course in May.
In 2013, we were able to offer
Diversity Scholarships to nineteen students over three courses, and to mentor
two African American women as assistant teachers.  In 2014, we hope to do even more!
One-third to one-half of our
students are on work trade or scholarships.  We offer work trade and fee
reductions to activists of all backgrounds.  In addition, we actively support three inner-city gardens in
San Francisco’s most stressed neighborhood of Bayview Hunters Point, providing
mentoring and training for the Girls2000 gardens and the Emerald City Green
Jobs Programs run by Hunters Point Family, which serves at-risk youth.  And we’ve helped support the Marda
Permaculture Farm in Palestine, where Starhawk taught a permaculture design
course in October.  We have a
strong track record of building trust in a wide spectrum of communities.
A small investment in Earth
Activist Training has a huge ripple effect. Any amount you can donate will help
diversify the environmental justice movement, bring new perspectives and
insights into the permaculture movement, and give activists and community
leaders the tools they need to build that beautiful world of the future we know
is possible!
Other ways to help:
Even small amounts of money add
up, so please feel free to donate whatever you can!  But there are many other ways to help:
Share this campaign with your
friends and social networks.  Help
us spread it far and wide!  You can use the Share tools here on this page.
Come take our course
yourself!  There’s no better way to
launch a career in sustainability, or discover a new life direction, or deepen
your own spiritual connection to the earth, or learn how to organize and make

changes on a wide scale!  You can find all the information on our courses and organization at http://www.earthactivisttraining.org/.

Gratitude!
We’re so thankful for all the
help we’ve gotten from the community of those who share the permaculture
ethics: care for the earth, care for the people and care for the future!  And we're deeply grateful for your support!
Special thanks to Antibalas
for letting us use their piece “Nesta” as the music in our video!  http://www.antibalas.com/
And thanks to producer Philip Wood
of The Fifth Sacred Thing movie
project for making the video look and sound good!  http://thefifthsacredthing.com

To view the video with closed captions, please visit the following link:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u1ldZvW8j3s
Our Teaching Team:
Starhawk is the author of twelve books on Goddess religion, earth based
spirituality and activism, including <i>The
Spiral Dance, The Fifth Sacred Thing,
The Earth Path and The Empowerment Manual: A Guide for
Collaborative Groups, on power, process and group dynamics.  She is currently working with Yerba
Buena Films on a feature production of her novel, The Fifth Sacred Thing. http://fifthsacredthing.com/
Starhawk
directs Earth Activist Training and has been teaching permaculture since
2001.  Her website is www.starhawk.org/
Charles Williams is a
permaculture designer, teacher, skilled facilitator and mediator who brings to
the work a love of the wild and experience as an instructor and guide in
wilderness skills, tracking and primitive skills.  He is the land manager of Golden Rabbit Ranch in the
Cazadero Hills, implementing a permaculture design including holistic
management rotational grazing of sheep and goats, carbon farming, sustainable
forestry, and Mediterranean forest gardens.
Pandora Thomas Pandora
co-founded Earthseed Consulting LLC, a holistic consulting firm whose work
expands the opportunities for sustainable living for diverse communities. Her
clients include Toyota and UC Berkeley. She has worked with groups as diverse
as Iraqi and Indonesian youth to men serving in San Quentin creating inspiring
and hands on programs around permaculture, sustainability, and outdoor and
environmental education. She is the founder of the Black Permaculture Network.
Guest Teacher Erik Ohlsen is a licensed
contractor and founder/owner of Permaculture Artisans, an ecological farm and
landscape company. Erik has extensive experience with design and implementation
of projects that range from small urban lots to 100+ broad acres. His
understanding of ecology and his many years of observation, listening, and
experience with landscape patterns and design teams make Erik a leader in the
field. Erik’s design and field experience comprise of a huge variety of skills,
including: farm design and implementation, water harvesting/storm water
management, erosion control, extensive earthwork operations, heavy machine operation,
irrigation systems, ponds, food forests/orchard systems, native plant systems,
wildlife habitat enhancement, integrated pest management, microclimate
moderation, roof water catchment systems, sustainable forestry, soil building,
vermiculture, hardscape design and implementation, client relations, project
management, and much more.
Erik has taught courses in permaculture and
related subjects throughout the US, Canada, and the UK.  He is the founder of the Permaculture
Skill Center in Sebastopol, CA.
His website is www.permacultureartisans.com
","Permaculture, spirit, and activism
- three very potent tools to regenerate our world.  I'm Starhawk, and I’m
the author of twelve books on the intersections of earth-based spirituality and
social change organizing, including my visionary novel The Fifth Sacred Thing.
But I don’t just write about them, I try to practice them in my life and
in what I teach.
I started Earth Activist Training
because I wanted a program that could combine them all.  Permaculture is a
holistic ecological design system that includes powerful tools that can help us
heal damaged land, rebuild communities, and create truly sustainable
abundance.  We teach it with a
grounding in spirit—personal regeneration--and a focus on organizing and
activism.  In our permaculture
design course, students learn how to heal damaged soil, grow food organically,
bioremediate toxins, harvest water and re-use graywater, build low-cost,
low-carbon housing, and so many other skills.  And most of all, they learn how all the aspects of
sustainability can fit together so that we can meet our human needs while
caring for the natural systems around us. Permaculture offers solutions to some
of our most grave ecological problems.
The communities that most need
these tools are those who are on the front lines of environmental and social
struggles – our depressed inner cities, indigenous reserves where jobs and
resources are scarce, desertifying drylands and war-torn lands in the developing
world.  To share this knowledge, we
need to train people who come from those communities.  They are the best ambassadors and most effective teachers!
So Earth Activist Training offers
Diversity Scholarships to people of color who are working in environmental and
food justice.  From the urban food
deserts to the deserts of African, our students are doing amazing work!  They’re people like Menhuam Ayele, an
architecture student who is training former gang members to build a greenhouse
in San Francisco’s most depressed neighborhood.  Or Brandy Mack, who works with young girls who live in
public housing and helps them grow both food and self-esteem.  Or Tesfaye Johanson, who was born in
the Afar region of Ethiopia and now works to bring land and water programs in
his ancestral village.  Or David
Ortiz, a Blackfoot Nation permaculture designer who works for tribal water
rights.  Carmen Shorter helps women
make the transition from addiction and homelessness to treatment and next
steps.  Eighteen-year-old Ruby
Avila is developing gardens in her community.  Rushelle Frazier is an accomplished poet who is developing a
permaculture retreat center for Veterans.
You can meet them all in the video,
and by contributing to our campaign you can be part of their work, and others
like them.
These are the leaders and
visionaries who give me hope. I feel so honored to have skills and tools to
share that I know can boost their efforts, help them regenerate their spirit
and enthusiasm after hard times, and empower communities.
If you could do something to help heal the world, would you
plant rain gardens on the Paiute reserve in Nevada, or camp out in the path of
an oil pipeline, or inspire inner city youth to make environmental art, or
research the potential to sequester carbon with compost, or start rooftop
gardens in the South Bronx?  No one
of us can do it all, but all of us can be part of weaving this network of
support for all the visionaries who are turning problems into solutions.
Earth Activist Training offers
two-week residential permaculture design certificate courses, which are the
gateway into the global permaculture movement and a strong foundation for a
career in sustainability.  We hope
to raise $10,000 or more with this campaign, to cover our costs for ten or more Diversity Scholarship recipients.
Any additional money we raise will seed scholarships and work trade
opportunities for upcoming short courses in natural building, a Spring Equinox
retreat, and a second permaculture design course in May.
In 2013, we were able to offer
Diversity Scholarships to nineteen students over three courses, and to mentor

One-third to one-half of our
students are on work trade or scholarships.  We offer work trade and fee

San Francisco’s most stressed neighborhood of Bayview Hunters Point, providing

Permaculture Farm in Palestine, where Starhawk taught a permaculture design

column2: >Yippee! We've reached our initial goal but if we can raise a few more thousand dollars, we can place ads like this one in airports or around Sacramento. Please continue to give generously to support this campaign. Thank you!
column14: >Protect our Precious ForestsMy name is Juliette Beck. I'm the mother of two young girls, an environmental advocate, and a fourth generation Californian. My family (pictured below) loves to spend time exploring the wonders of California's magnificent forests.
column17:
/>Last summer,  we went camping in Crystal Basin Recreation Area near Lake Tahoe. We played on the shores of Union Valley Reservoir, hiked in Eldorado National Forest and slept under the big, grand trees.

I was shocked when I learned that state agencies are allowing private timber companies to clearcut log all throughout this beautiful recreation area, right up to the reservoir itself and its camping area.

Industrial-scale clearcut logging is rapidly happening across nearly two million acres of rich Sierra Nevada forests, threatening not only majestic recreation areas like Crystal Basin but the vital watersheds that supply the majority of California's water.
column19:
/>


Forests sustain life -- we can not afford to let them be trashed.

Forests are the lungs of the earth. They stabilize our climate and generate fresh oxygen.  Forests collect, filter, store and gradually release pure water. Over 75% of California's water comes from forests. A wide and amazing array of animals, fish and plants live in forests. 

Clearcutting is the most environmentally destructive form of logging that destroys wildlife habitat and puts our water, climate, biodiversity, economy and recreation areas at risk. 

As a mother, I teach my children to leave natural places better than we found them. Yet timber companies are trashing our forests. We need your help to put an end to this destructive practice. 

Hiding behind a thin row of trees -or “beauty strips” –, clearcuts are now slicing up our forested watersheds at a shocking pace and scale.  Google Earth satellite imagery reveals how widespread this destructive practice is.  No longer permitted on federal lands, the State of California is allowing more than 65,000 acres a year to be clearcut logged and replaced with highly-flammable tree plantations. 


Support our campaign to end clearcutting in Crystal Basin and beyond

To take action, I have been working with the Sierra Club and a coalition of frontline communities to end clearcut logging in California's forests, starting with the Crystal Basin Recreation Area.

Together, we are challenging a logging plan submitted by Sierra Pacific Industries (SPI) that would allow additional areas of bio-diverse forests to be clearcut, sprayed with herbicides and replanted as factory farm-style tree plantations.  

SPI is the state's #1 clearcutting company and California’s largest private landowner. While the Union Valley reservoir is owned and operated by Sacramento Municipal Utility District (SMUD) for hydropower, SPI owns property all throughout Crystal Basin and the American River watershed.  The electricity generated during the summer helps keep utility rates low for thousands of Sacramento area residents, who also get their drinking water from the American River. There is much at stake.

Over the past decade, SPI has converted thousands of acres of naturally maturing forests to industrial tree plantations in this area.  In December, SPI submitted a plan to the California Department of Forests and Fire Protection (CALFIRE) that would permit logging up to 300 feet from popular campgrounds and all throughout an area proposed for a bike trail.

The Sierra Club's Mother Lode Chapter has submitted comments opposing the “Notned Timber Harvest Plan” and are now preparing a public campaign to pressure CALFIRE – the state agency in charge of reviewing logging plans to ensure they comply with state laws such as CEQA - to prohibit clearcut logging in the Crystal Basin Recreation Area.

We need your support!

We have made a great start in building a powerful coalition against clearcutting, but we are also up against some of the most powerful and wealthy interests in the state of California. Archie Eldis 'Red' Emerson, owner of SPI is among the top richest Americans, and the money spent by timber corporations such as SPI is able to buy a lot of influence in Sacramento.

What we lack in money though, we make up for with passion and people power. But we won't start to really left the veil on clearcutting unless we have some basic resources to win more public support. Which is where you come in!

With your support we can advance the campaign to protect California's forested watersheds from clearcutting. A successful campaign to stop clearcut logging in Crystal Basin can be where we draw the line to stop clearcutting across the Sierra Nevada.

Specifically, your donation will help us:

1) Release a powerful new video showing the cumulative toll of clearcut logging in Crystal Basin

2) Build a broad base of public opposition in the seat of state power

3) Collect petitions signatures at Crystal Basin campgrounds 

4) Launch a media campaign to expose the threats to our water supply, climate, wildlife and natural beauty 

5) Engage the Sacramento City Council, SMUD and other potential allies in calling for greater protections for our forested watersheds 

6) Expand our volunteer base and train the next generation of forest advocates 


Why fund this campaign?

Sierra Club has been a leading champion for our forests for over a hundred years. We have an unparalleled track record of success.  We have long opposed ecologically destructive logging practices – namely clearcutting – that harms wildlife habitat, water quality, forest health and degrades our outdoor recreational experience. 

Thanks to the hard work of generations of Sierra Club volunteers – starting with our founder John Muir – much of our national forestland is now protected from industrial clearcutting. Unfortunately, the pressure has shifted to forestlands managed by the State of California which is negligently allowing private logging companies to clearcut across the water producing backbone of California.

We can stop this logging plan and challenge the way that cumulative impacts of clearcutting are evaluated. 

Help us reach our goal of raising $8,000 to draw the line against more clearcutting in California's forests near magnificent outdoor recreation areas such as Crystal Basin.  

Every dollar you contribute will go directly to support this critical effort to protect California's forests for our kids, and for future generations. The public deserves to enjoy and experience the beauties of real forests, not tree plantations, when they visit our National Forests and recreation areas.

Thank you big time for your support!

Other Ways You Can Help

column1: Please share this appeal with your friends and family.
Help us reach our fundraising goal and launch our campaign to protect

our forests and recreation areas from clearcut logging.

Join our Facebook page: StopClearcuttingCA
Send
a comment to CALFIRE opposing the Notned THP Email your comment, with the logging plan number 4-13-027ELD  included to fresnopubliccomment@fire.ca.gov
and email a copy to us at stopsierraclearcutting@gmail.com
Enjoy
our forests, speak for the trees!
Join our kick-butt volunteer team! Help us collect petition
signatures, expand our voice and rally public support for our
forests. Email stopsierraclearcutting@gmail.com

to get involved in this critical campaign.

Inspired by
the actions of the Idle No More
movement and deeply outraged by Prime Minister Harper’s silence, Beau begins to
engage in a broader form of activism, using his recognition in the world to
spread awareness and rally people to attention. Even after suffering a heart
attack, Beau lead a 10-day, 475 km walk from Alert Bay to Victoria, where he
and his community of supporters engage in a symbolic copper-breaking ceremony
on the grounds of the Legislature to shame and challenge the Canadian government
on the grounds of cultural genocide and environmental neglect. People travelled
from far and wide to meet Beau and the other walkers on the legislature
grounds. The act of copper breaking had profound meaning for all those in
attendance and garnered international attention. However, Prime Minister Harper

remained silent.

Now one year later, Beau plans to take Idle
No More and the symbolic copper-breaking
ceremony to the next level. Taking the journey across Canada from British Columbia to Ottawa and right to the steps of the Parliament of Canada.

Vist us on the web at www.citizengreen.co

Citizen Green Coalition is spearheading the movement for solar energy in our communities. Every year millions of our hard earned dollars are spent on foreign oil and dirty fossil fuels, harming our economy, environment and security. Solar gardens instead generate electricity right in our backyards, bringing dollars back to the community, creating local jobs, clean air and revenue for government services instead of taxing businesses and hard working people.

The City of Richmond, across the bay from San Francisco, suffers from some of the highest rates of pollution, crime, and unemployment in the country. Using formerly polluted, damaged, or rundown sites and transforming them into solar gardens cleans up the city and jumpstarts the local economy with new opportunities for young people.

All contributions will go into a “Clean Seed Fund” which will be used to finance solar gardens throughout Richmond. Citizen Green will reinvest the principal and the revenues from each garden into additional gardens, in a positive feedback loop.
The Impact

Solar gardens allows citizens to take charge of their economy, environment and community. It cuts dependence on dirty fossil fuels and start generating their own energy, creating jobs, investment and revenues for essential services.
By making a donation, you are planting a seed for a clean energy future in communities around the world. You’re helping to build a new, decentralized, distributed, clean &
column2: local way of generating energy that benefits our communities.

column1: Abandoned or unused sites bring down property values and are unproductive. Many unused lands cannot be developed due to contamination unsafe for people. Solar is perfect for these otherwise unusable areas. Solar gardens return that land to productive use, fuel the economy and increase property values.
<div>
<div>
What We Need &
Citizen Green needs $5,000 to finance the first solar garden, and to establish the clean seed fund. This one installation will generate enough revenue to fund additional gardens.

We estimate each project will create at least 15 local jobs. The more we raise, the more we can scale and return to the seed fund - a multiplying effect that can eventually help more communities around the world.

As a thank you for supporting this campaign, you will have access to great perks such as access to special events, a certificate or photo of the solar you helped install or even you name or organizations name on a plaque dedicating the commitment to clean local energy.
Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute right now, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help. Share a link on Facebook and Twitter and promote our cause to your friends, colleagues and family. Support clean energy in our communities.

Our Story

TAP Bottles, Together Against Plastic Bottles, is a youth initiative in North Vancouver, with the mission to eliminate plastic bottles from our school and local community. We have now been working on this project for almost three years and have become very knowledgable and passionate about the issue. We are determined to make a difference.
The first step in our action plan is Awareness. In order to educate others about this issue we have presented to many different schools, and organizations including
column2: Highlands, Ross Road and Brooksbank Elementary, Carson Graham Secondary, NVSD44 PAC, Surfrider Vancouver Chapter, Justice High, Change Pilotz and Ep!c: Vancouver's Sustainable Living Expo. We have been awarded a Civic Youth Award for ""Outstanding Youth Team."" And have received two $1000 grants
column3: one from Change Pilotz, a program run by Capilano University. The second from the BC Green Games sponsored by Telus World of Science.

column1: Our second step is to Provide an Alternative. We are doing this by selling our ""This makes one less"" reusable stainless steel water bottles.  We have already made three partnership orders of bottles with Sacre-Davey Engineering, King Marketing and Onedance Creative Arts Centre.

Our current goal is to fundraise enough money to install an outdoor water fountain and water bottle refill station in our community at Confederation Field. Thus providing a convenient alternative to single-use plastic bottles in our community.
<h3>What We Need &amp

• The full installation cost of this refill station is $12000. We have currently raised $3500 from our two grants, selling our bottles, our fundraising and awareness BBQ company partnerships. Our goal is to raise half the money and seek matching funds from local organizations in the city. Raising $2500 would bring us to our goal of $6000.
• For your generous donations we will be offering...
$25 A BIG Thank you! Which will get you a personal thank you letter, and recognition on our website and Facebook page!

$100 TAP Bottles Swag! Which includes a personal thank you letter, and recognition on our website and Facebook page. PLUS a TAP Bottles ""This makes one less"" Water Bottle and magnet shipped directly to you!**

$1000 Partnership and Skype Session! For this AMAZING donation you will receive Personal thank you letter, recognition on our website and Facebook page, a TAP Bottles ""This makes one less""  Water Bottle and magnet shipped directly to you!**  A Skype session to talk to us about our mission, PLUS a discounted price on a partnership order of TAP Bottles reusable stainless steel water bottles water bottles with your companies logo!
** Shipping of water bottles can only be done to those living in Canada. We apologize for any inconvenience

• If we are unable to make this goal all funds will still go towards the refill station and we will continue to raise money through other fundraisers such as another BBQ, a bottle drive and more partnerships and bottle sales. Our goal is to have the $6000 by the new year!
The Impact on Our Community
Installing this refill station will greatly enhance our community. Confederation field is used on a daily basis: for the students of Carson Graham Secondary School
column2: local sports clubs, including North Vancouver Football Club, West Vancouver Field Hockey Club, as well as the general public. Having a refill station at the field would reduce and eliminate the need for single-use plastic bottles which are used by players or spectators.

column1: Eliminating the use of plastic bottles would have a great impact on the world! Both in the categories of health, the environment and social/economic. The polycarbonate plastic contains Bisphenal-A (BPA) which is very harmful and has been linked to various health problems including different types of cancer. It also increases health care and insurance costs as a result of incineration polluting the air, water and food. Plastic bottles are typically made from domestic natural gas or oil, which are non-renewable fuel resource found within the earth. Only 27% of plastic bottles are recycled, with the remaining percentage ending up in landfills. Canadians drank an average of 66L of bottled water EACH in 2006, more than double the amount just 8 years earlier. Having water bottle refill stations available in the community will make it much easier for people to not use plastic water bottles.
Other Ways You Can Help
You can also help us out by sharing our campaign and our story with your friends and family. The best way to complete our mission is to raise awareness about the issue.
If you are interested in partnering with us and ordering some TAP Bottles""This makes one less"" water bottles with your company's logo, please send us an email at tapbottles@gmail.com!
For more information on our project, upcoming events and our progress towards our goal please check out our:
<ul>
•  Website: tapbottles.wix.com/tapbottles
• Facebook: TAP Bottles
• Twitter: @tap_bottles

Thank you!

<h3 style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
Je joindrai sous peu le Clipperton Project dans le cadre du Floating LAB.
Il s'agit d'une expédition en voilier qui nous mènera de Las Palmas (Espagne),

au Cap Vert et finalement à Fernando de Noronha (Brésil). L'expédition rassemble
des scientifiques et des artistes qui désirent s'engager dans un projet collaboratif
manifestant leur engagement environnemental et social. Chaque participant propose 
un projet personnel hors de son domaine d'expertise. C'est dans cette perspective
que j'ai mis sur pied le projet « Conversations in a suitcase ».

column3: >Monik Paskal Potvin has worked for 20 years in the fields of film, multimedia and event marketing. Her path full of encounters and collaborations saw her working alongside numerous projects, as well as founding two companies in Quebec. She has passions for sailing and travelling in general, and sees the Floating LAB as a natural and logical extension of her multidisciplinary work to date.

column1: <h3 style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
column6:
>Je vais joindre l'équipe du CP,
tout en créant un lien fort avec ma famille, les invitant en voyage.
J'agirai à titre d'émissaire dans un dialogue entre ma famille et le monde.

column1: Avant mon départ, j’invite les membres de ma famille
directe, mon père Grégoire,
ma mère Monique, mes sœurs Julie, Élène, Francine
et mes frères Bruno, Donald
et Hervé, à glisser dans une valise un objet de
leur quotidien qui les caractérisent.
La valise est donc garnie de 8 objets.
Également, ils sont invités à partager un souhait, un voeu environnemental pour lesquelles ils aimeraient voir un changement au sein
notre société.
Les idées de chacun sont notés, puis traduites en anglais, en
espagnol et en portugais.
Des photos seront prises. Le tout est relié sous la forme d’un album de famille.
C’est valise et album en main que j’entreprends ce
voyage qui me mènera aux Îles Canaries, au Cap Vert et au Brésil… en
passant par l’océan Atlantique.
<h3 style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
column6:
>Ma valise devient un lieu de rencontre intime, qui part de moi, de ma famille
pour aller à la rencontre d'inconnus.

column1: Chaque rencontre sera une opportunité de présenter les membres

de ma famille
à partir de l’objet de leur quotidien, de favoriser un dialogue à
partir de leurs souhaits environnementaux. Ma famille et moi, tout autant que les gens rencontrés, y trouverons une
opportunité de s’offrir un nouveau regard sur soi, sur les nôtres, sur notre
communauté. Des photos et des notes seront prises.

Les traces de ces rencontres seront colligées sous la forme d’un mini recueil  « Conversations dans une valise ». Les lecteurs pourront constater comment
des préoccupations environnementales d’une famille

trouvent un écho
dans le monde. Édition limitée.
<h3 style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
column6:
>Transformation sociale : condition indispensable de la prise en compte 
des problématiques environnementales 
par le plus grand nombre.

column1:
Dans un désir du partage de préoccupations environnementales, de dissémination
de nouvelles valeurs, plusieurs individus tentent de changer la société. Pour se faire, ils tentent d’entrer en communication.
<div style=""text-align: center
<i style=""line-height: 1.45em
column2: >- Bonjour, j’aimerais parler à la société s’il-vous-plaît ...

column1: Ce dialogue exagéré nous permet d’admettre que le premier échelon à gravir dans la transformation de la société, est de trouver l’interlocuteur à qui s’adresser.
La famille est l’unité de base de la société.

La famille est en mutation, au même titre que l’écologie. Dans plusieurs cultures, la famille se désintègre, se divisant sous la pression de l’économie, des bouleversements politiques et de la pauvreté des communications.

La famille, en tant qu’unité de base la plus fondamentale de la société doit, dans ce processus, être remodelée et revitalisée selon les principes mêmes qui redonneront forme à la société en tant que telle.
S’ouvrir à sa famille, s’engager dans sa communauté, changer sa société.
column2: >C'est dans cette perspective qu'a été créé <b style=""font-style: italic

column1: <h3 style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
column6:
>Un parcours d'environ 2200 miles nautiques, où nous toucherons
à 3 continents...

column1: <ul>
• Le navire est un ketch à coque d'acier et pont de bois de 20 mètres.

<li>Vous pourrez nous suivre à la trace <a href=""http://www.clippertonproject.com/expeditions/the-floating-laboratory/fl-the-journey-south/route-tracker/"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" style=""line-height: 1.45em
• Le point de rendez-vous est Las Palmas, Espagne.
• Le départ est fixé au 2 octobre 2013.
• Nous serons 10 à bords - 4 marins - 6 explorateurs.
• Tous contribueront aux manoeuvres et à l'entretien.
• Tous s'impliqueront dans les projets de chacun.
• Nous atteindrons nos objectifs.
<h3 style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)

Si je manifeste une certaine démesure 
dans l'envergure de mes rêves...
column2:
>J'ai indéniablement la capacité 
de les réaliser... avec votre aide !

column1: L'argent cumulé contribuera à défrayer les coûts suivants :
<ul>
• Impression des mini recueils ""Conversations dans une valise"" (Édition limitée)
• Frais de postes
• Participation à la caisse de bord (nourriture, frais portuaires, gazole)
• Transports aériens
<h3 style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
Vous n'êtes pas en mesure de contribuer ? Cela ne signifie pas que vous ne pouvez pas m'aider :
<ul>
• Partager mon projet avec les membres de votre famille et vos amis...
• Utilisez le lien de partage sur cette page _ MERCI !
You must be the change
column2: >you wish to see in the world -

column1: ","Je joindrai sous peu le Clipperton Project dans le cadre du Floating LAB.
Il s'agit d'une expédition en voilier qui nous mènera de Las Palmas (Espagne),

au Cap Vert et finalement à Fernando de Noronha (Brésil). L'expédition rassemble des scientifiques et des artistes qui désirent s'engager dans un projet collaboratif manifestant leur engagement environnemental et social. Chaque participant propose un projet personnel hors de son domaine d'expertise. C'est dans cette perspective que j'ai mis sur pied le projet « Conversations in a suitcase ».

Monik Paskal Potvin has worked for 20 years in the fields of film, multimedia and event marketing. Her path full of encounters and collaborations saw her working alongside numerous projects, as well as founding two companies in Quebec. She has passions for sailing and travelling in general, and sees the Floating LAB as a natural and logical extension of her multidisciplinary work to date.
Je vais joindre l'équipe du CP, tout en créant un lien fort avec ma famille, les invitant en voyage. J'agirai à titre d'émissaire dans un dialogue entre ma famille et le monde.
Avant mon départ, j’invite les membres de ma famille
directe, mon père Grégoire,
ma mère Monique, mes sœurs Julie, Élène, Francine
et mes frères Bruno, Donald
et Hervé, à glisser dans une valise un objet de
leur quotidien qui les caractérisent.
La valise est donc garnie de 8 objets.
Également, ils sont invités à partager un souhait, un voeu environnemental pour lesquelles ils aimeraient voir un changement au sein
notre société.
Les idées de chacun sont notés, puis traduites en anglais, en
espagnol et en portugais.
Des photos seront prises. Le tout est relié sous la forme d’un album de famille.
C’est valise et album en main que j’entreprends ce
voyage qui me mènera aux Îles Canaries, au Cap Vert et au Brésil… en
passant par l’océan Atlantique.
Ma valise devient un lieu de rencontre intime, qui part de moi, de ma famille pour aller à la rencontre d'inconnus.
Chaque rencontre sera une opportunité de présenter les membres
de ma famille à partir de l’objet de leur quotidien, de favoriser un dialogue à
partir de leurs souhaits environnementaux. Ma famille et moi, tout autant que les gens rencontrés, y trouverons une
opportunité de s’offrir un nouveau regard sur soi, sur les nôtres, sur notre
communauté. Des photos et des notes seront prises.

Les traces de ces rencontres seront colligées sous la forme d’un mini recueil  « Conversations dans une valise ». Les lecteurs pourront constater comment des préoccupations environnementales d’une famille
trouvent un écho dans le monde. Édition limitée.
Transformation sociale : condition indispensable de la prise en compte des problématiques environnementales par le plus grand nombre.

Dans un désir du partage de préoccupations environnementales, de dissémination de nouvelles valeurs, plusieurs individus tentent de changer la société. Pour se faire, ils tentent d’entrer en communication.
- Bonjour, j’aimerais parler à la société s’il-vous-plaît ...J’ai quelques propositions à lui faire !
Ce dialogue exagéré nous permet d’admettre que le premier échelon à gravir dans la transformation de la société, est de trouver l’interlocuteur à qui s’adresser.
La famille est l’unité de base de la société.

La famille est en mutation, au même titre que l’écologie. Dans plusieurs cultures, la famille se désintègre, se divisant sous la pression de l’économie, des bouleversements politiques et de la pauvreté des communications.

La famille, en tant qu’unité de base la plus fondamentale de la société doit, dans ce processus, être remodelée et revitalisée selon les principes mêmes qui redonneront forme à la société en tant que telle.
S’ouvrir à sa famille, s’engager dans sa communauté, changer sa société. C'est dans cette perspective qu'a été créé « Conversations in a suitcase ».
Un parcours d'environ 2200 miles nautiques, où nous toucherons à 3 continents...
Le navire est un ketch à coque d'acier et pont de bois de 20 mètres.
Vous pourrez nous suivre à la trace ICI.
Le point de rendez-vous est Las Palmas, Espagne.
Le départ est fixé au 2 octobre 2013.
Nous serons 10 à bords - 4 marins - 6 explorateurs.
Tous contribueront aux manoeuvres et à l'entretien.
Tous s'impliqueront dans les projets de chacun.
Nous atteindrons nos objectifs.
Si je manifeste une certaine démesure dans l'envergure de mes rêves...J'ai indéniablement la capacité de les réaliser... avec votre aide !
L'argent cumulé contribuera à défrayer les coûts suivants :
Impression des mini recueils ""Conversations dans une valise"" (Édition limitée)
Frais de postes
Participation à la caisse de bord (nourriture, frais portuaires, gazole)
Transports aériens
D'autres façons d'aider
Vous n'êtes pas en mesure de contribuer ? Cela ne signifie pas que vous ne pouvez pas m'aider :
Partager mon projet avec les membres de votre famille et vos amis...
Utilisez le lien de partage sur cette page _ MERCI !
You must be the change you wish to see in the world - Gandhi",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

Hello Friends,

This June I will be joining a unique
oceanic expedition to study an emerging issue, to find out how much plastic or
marine debris is in our oceans.<span>
Non-biodegradable plastic floating on the sea surface can be a serious
problem to wildlife, ship navigation, and ultimately human health.  I join the 5Gyres Institute as a guest
scientist on a North Atlantic Ocean expedition with advocates, film makers, other
scientists and educators as we raise international awareness and conduct
valuable research on marine debris and its potentially harmful impacts. By engaging with policy makers, scientists, and
advocates upon my return, I will ensure that a clear and understandable message
is being articulated about the global extent of plastic pollution.  I am asking community members, colleagues,
friends, and family for small donations to help offset the steep monetary cost
of this extraordinary voyage, which will ultimately have a notable impact on
scientific knowledge and policy.  If you can not contribute at this time, please help me reach my goal by using the Indiegogo share tools with people you think could chip in.
Here is a link to the expedition: http://5gyres.org/how_to_get_involved/expeditions/
Thank you for your ongoing support!

Carolyn Rosevelt

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><h3>

This October Earthship Biotecture is teaming up with The Kapita Development Committee (KDC) and Empower Malawi Limited- a local not for profit organization, to build a sustainable development epicenter for 38 villages and over 5,000 people in Malawi.
 
Not only will the project include a community bank, a mini library, a dispensary, offices and a food bank, but the peoples of Malawi will be left with an invaluable skill, the ability to build and maintain sustainable autonomous structures that can be used as businesses or homes in order to put the power of their lives, back in their own hands.
To learn more about the project and see their official video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-dKEuFCOhPA

So- in order to raise awareness and money, my goal is around a dollar a mile.. By hitchhiking from my hometown in Vermont to The Greater World Earthship Community outside Taos New Mexico. With a tire.

Why? Its necessary to not only help people in ways that truly benefit their community, but where the real growth continues to happen long after the initial help has gone. To give people the knowledge tools and resources to take their lives back and have their well being subject to no other power besides themselves.
Please Donate. Or Volunteer. A Greater World is Waiting.

","This October Earthship Biotecture is teaming up with The Kapita Development Committee (KDC) and Empower Malawi Limited- a local not for profit organization, to build a sustainable development epicenter for 38 villages and over 5,000 people in Malawi. Not only will the project include a community bank, a mini library, a dispensary, offices and a food bank, but the peoples of Malawi will be left with an invaluable skill, the ability to build and maintain sustainable autonomous structures that can be used as businesses or homes in order to put the power of their lives, back in their own hands.
To learn more about the project and see their official video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-dKEuFCOhPA

So- in order to raise awareness and money, my goal is around a dollar a mile.. By hitchhiking from my hometown in Vermont to The Greater World Earthship Community outside Taos New Mexico. With a tire.

Why? Its necessary to not only help people in ways that truly benefit their community, but where the real growth continues to happen long after the initial help has gone. To give people the knowledge tools and resources to take their lives back and have their well being subject to no other power besides themselves.Please Donate. Or Volunteer. A Greater World is Waiting.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

ABOUT US
Charles &
column2: Lisa met over 10 years ago whilst both working in the world of TV media. At that time they both shared a passion for a more sustainable and self sufficient lifestyle .... and so their dream began!

column1: In 2010 Charles and Lisa planned and set up a beautiful woodland sanctuary called Forest Garden Shovelstrode in Sussex - where people could come and learn different ways of living off the land through the preservation of our craft heritage.
THE STORY SO FAR...

Forest Garden Shovelstrode boasts two beautiful yurts located in a small piece of ancient woodland for people looking for a peaceful retreat. We run many courses including green woodworking, hurdle making, basket willow weaving, clay oven building, vegetable gardening, beekeeping, orchard harvest, sourdough bread making and mushroom foraging. We also a range of holistic and meditative workshops.
The courses are run from a temporary workshop made up from old army tents– and it is now time to build something more permanent!

""Just completed the Intro to Veg Gardening course, fantastic!! Lisa, Mandy and Justin provide an immensely enjoyable and informative day in a beautiful setting. Would thoroughly recommend it to all avid beginners like me. Thanks again.""
Robert Lock (Course participant)
""Had a tremendous time at the course on How to Make Products from Beeswax. I would highly recommend it. Many thanks to Justin, Lisa and Mandy. Great to meet you.""
Mike Palmer (Course participant)
THE PROJECT: TO BUILD A PERMANENT WOODLAND WORKSHOP

Planning permission has been granted for a 120sqm timber framed barn which will be our new permanent woodland workshop. It will be located beside the wildlife pond - in between the new Forest Garden and the ancient woodland. This will allow us to offer a greater range of courses to more people over an extended season.
A free place will be made available on each course to be people with special needs i.e. physical, intellectual or financial.
(See Gallery for plans and a impression of what the proposed woodland workshop will look like)
HOW YOU CAN HELP
By pledging any amount towards our project - every little will help us get a step closer to creating this important facility for the community.
WHAT WE NEED
<ul>
<li>£   8,500          Ground works &amp
<li>£ 36,000          Oak framed building: materials &amp
<li>£   8,500          Shingle roof: materials &amp
• £   8,750          External decked woodworking area
• £   2,500          Internal floor surface
<li>£   2,250          2 x Logburners &amp
<li><span style=""text-decoration: underline
Total needed to complete project = £   69,500
Initial target: £45,500 for ground works and timber frame including £1000 for a temporary canvas cover.

We wish to build a substantial oak framed building that will last for many years as shown in the attached plans (see gallery). However if the inital target is not reached we will look at compromises we could make, such as materials and size of building, so that the project will still proceed.
WHAT WE ARE OFFERING
Every person who pledges a donation of more than £5 towards our new Woodland Workshop will automatically become a ‘Friend of Forest Garden Shovelstrode’. This will entitle you to:
<ul>
• A special ‘Thankyou’ in our newsletter sent to over 2,500 subscribers
• Regular newsletters and updates
• Opportunity to come and be involved in the planting and ongoing creation of the Forest Garden
• Invitations to upcoming events and Fayres
• News of upcoming special offers and discounts
There are also some great rewards available with each level of pledge
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Key to the success of this fundraising project will be in us reaching as many people as possible. Please help us by forwarding this link to anyone you think may be interested in supporting this project.
You can also help by sharing a link to us via social media - see links below
We very much look forward to welcoming you soon at Forest Garden Shovelstrode!
With warm wishes,
Charles &

Hello, Friends of Local Food &
This is Amy Christian and Duncan Hilchey. We are the founders and editors of the Journal of Agriculture, Food Systems, and Community Development, also known as the Food Systems Journal.
The Food Systems Journal promotes strategies to address both hunger and farm loss, shares practical research &
column2: best practices, and provides an opportunity to publish in the emerging field of food systems development.

column1: Our editorial board includes an advisory committee of 25 leading scholars and practitioners, and over 150 peer reviewers from around the world. They all donate their time and expertise at no cost.

The Food Systems Journal is the world's only online, peer-reviewed research publication focused on local and regional food system development. We publish case studies, commentaries, and survey results on the state of the art in agriculture and food systems-based community development. Having our papers reviewed by teams of experts who approve their publication means that we are publishing original and useful research.
Some examples of topics we’ve published over the past 3 years include:
* What it’s like to be on a local food diet.
* What cities are doing to promote livestock production
* How insurance companies are giving rebates to local CSA members
* How large school districts are buying regionally produced foods
* What the capacity is of large North American cities to produce their own food
* African American farmers’ views on land loss and discrimination
* Just how family-farm-friendly is the Obama Administration?

This research is useful not only to university scholars, but also to professionals and volunteers with thousands of groups around the world working on issues like food security, farmland protection, farmworker quality of life, and linking local farms to institutions like restaurants, schools and hospitals.
The Food Systems Journal also has a companion website called
column3: Itemid=65"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" target=""_blank"" title=""AgDevONLINE"">AgDevONLINE that offers lots of tools and resources. At AgDevONLINE you will find a collection of maps of food system infrastructure, our proprietary ranking of every county in the United States by how progressive its farms are, along with a food system news feed and lots of other valuable features.

column1: With your support we are transforming the Food Systems Journal into a nonprofit that can receive grants and donations. But we’ll get to that in a minute. First, a little background.
What We Need &

We are fundraising because we are in the process of transitioning the Food Systems Journal into a nonprofit organization. We boot-strapped the Food Systems Journal three years ago with our own labor and investments, and have continued to subsidize it. Now that we’ve proved the concept of the journal, it’s time to grow and become more sustainable ourselves!

We have recently been accepted as a project of the Center for Transformative Action, an affiliate of Cornell University. The mission of the Journal meshes very well with the Center for Transformative Action’s, which is about making positive change in the world.

Becoming a project within the Center for Transformative Action supports our mission in many ways. It means we’ll be able keep our costs down while supporting a staff and broadening the availability of the Food Systems Journal around the world. Soon we'll be able to receive foundation grants and tax-deductible donations!

With your contribution, we will be able to upgrade our computers and support our work on the Food Systems Journal while we establish some long-term funding sources. Over the long term we would like to eliminate subscriptions altogether and become an “open access” journal — making it available to every public library, community group, or individual working on food systems issues.

Now to what YOU get for your contribution. Alas, we don’t have t-shirts, mugs, and bumper stickers to offer you. Mostly you will be rewarded by knowing you have supported a worthy cause: a more just and sustainable food system! However, we're pleased to provide contributors with FREE access. See the perks at right!
Whichever donation level you choose, you’ll get the latest research and progress in food systems development work. Who knows
column2: you may even be inspired to join a local Slow Food chapter, a crop mob, or even get an advanced degree in food system planning!

column1: The Impact

The local food and agriculture movement is growing by leaps and bounds — from the explosion of farmers’ markets and community supported agriculture farms, to shared-use kitchens and local food hubs. You may have innovations going on right in your own back yard. But the movement is still in its infancy. While there are tremendous opportunities to grow our local food systems, there are also a lot of challenges.

Throughout the world, not enough of us have access to healthy food, precious farmland is being lost forever, and farmworkers continue to bear a great burden for bringing food to our tables. The Food Systems Journal is providing critical support to the growing food movement that is addressing these issues head on. We can be one of the ways in which you take part in this movement yourself!
Other Ways You Can Help
Please use the Indiegogo share tools to get the word out to your colleagues, friends, and family.

Post on your Facebook page, blog about it, send emails and tweets. Every bit of sharing helps, even if you can’t contribute yourself right now. Also, if you’re at a college or university and you know others who are working in food systems, recommend that your library subscribe. That way your entire academic community will have access to the Food Systems Journal.

THANKS FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

","Short Summary:

column1: On July 2nd of this year, in the midst of another record temperature setting steaming-hot summer, I received an invitation to participate in extraordinary gathering of dedicated volunteers, to learn how to inspire and inform people about the alarming new evidence of global warming.

My goal for this campaign is to attend my final 3-day weekend conference of an intensive year-long training program in commuications in Seattle and also to attend the 3-day Climate Reality Leaders Training in San Francisco led in part by Al Gore himself. These (2) 3-day events will happen within the same week, with little time between the two. This week starts on Friday August 17th and ends on Thursday August 23rd.

The advantage of attending both is that the first 3-days is comprised of total-immersion in a team-building network of people practicing a “new model of communications” based on powerful excercises and paradigm shift inquiries. Two days later, taking that experience into a training led by the Nobel Prize and Academy Award winning former vice president Al Gore, who has sought for decades to present the most accurate climate science to the public, would enable me to combine the best of both worlds.

Following this week-long career change point, I will be building teams inside of a new design enterprise and seeking opportunities to present to community groups and organizations anywhere I am a request.
Link to my ad for business partners and co-designers:- http://philadelphia.craigslist.org/cpg/3155625661.html
Link to my presentation request page:- http://presenters.climaterealityproject.org/presenter/jon-ross_418
What We Need & What You get in Return:

This 6-day trip requires airfare for flights from Philadelphia to Seattle, then Seattle to San Francisco, then from San Francisco back to Philadelphia stays in 2-hotels, the site of these conferences. My estimate of what's required is approximately $2,000.00.
For your support, you will receive
- an online 3D wall of videos from YouTube similar to the TED Video Wall:

The TED Video Wall - ""an introduction to the Whole Earth Video Wall"", consists of over 1,200 mind-blowing video talks of speakers from the TED.com web site, embedded in a single 3D side-scrolling interface.- http://oneworldbar.com/TED_video_bar.html

All you need is to select a search term used to find your choice of videos on YouTube, along with your selected contribution and I will deliver your video wall(s) – coded, zipped and emailed or hosted on your web site.This campaign ends on the Sept. 21st, the last day of Summer 2012.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

Jonathan E. McArtor / J.E.T.S.   E-CHOICE
(Electrolysis - Creating Hydrogen Onboard Internal Combustion Engine)
HYDROGEN FUEL SYSTEM - COMMERCIAL VEHICLE APPLICATION

E-CHOICE is a six (6) component system that will replace the fossil fuel systems (gas or diesel) on commercial vehicles (trucks and buses).  95% of this system is based on currently used and accepted technology (software and hardware).  The remaining 5% consists of newly available technology and products that will become marketable with the success of our project.  Examples of the individual component technologies are readily available through simple online searches.
Beginning with the Electrolysis Tank (E-Tank), we have decided to produce the six (6) components in the prototype system one at a time
column2: to help manage the security of our working theories, and to take advantage of a multi-patent process. Since the E-Tank is the lynchpin of the system, we will develop it first.  In the following will provide a basic description of the E-Tank, followed by a brief description of the remaining components, in the order we will produce them.

column1: BRIEF HISTORY
This has been a lifetime endeavor that became this conversion project 12 years ago as the most logical advance for a proposed local transit system plan
column2: developed for my home town (Ridgecrest, CA) in the early 1970s.  Although the initial concept was mine, I had a lot of help along the way.  Patrick Obracken (deceased) helped me develop the plan for a local transit system…a system that would be the only non-government subsidized public transit system in the country (and could still be).  I invited Duane A. Burkey to join the transit project in the mid-1970s.  His mechanical knowledge and an ability to see the potential in combining hardware and technology, in non-conventional configurations, helped lead our research in the right direction.  In the late 1970s, Charles E. Quinlan joined the project as our business and technology consultant.  In addition to more than 20 years of successful small business operation, he has successfully passed the California BAR examination, and has ready access to PhD level electrical and chemical engineering review for our system.  We three: Duane, Charles, and I are the executive team and sole proponents of the JEMSTAR Group E-CHOICE project, and we are asking for your help to begin building our prototype system.

column1: While there is not an existing prototype, there are multiple examples of all the involved technologies available on the internet…all facets of this project are based on existing and proven technologies, which we will combine into an, as yet, untried configuration.
PREMISE

This system is a 95% combination of disparate existing and proven technologies reconfigured into a new, workable, combinative system.  The remaining 5% is new technology (developed but not implemented) which eliminates the dual problems of distribution and storage.  This is not a “Fuel Cell” system
column2: it is a component replacement system that encompasses fuel production and delivery methods for use of hydrogen as the primary fuel source in commercial sized vehicles
column3: with the intent to reduce and eventually eliminate the use of fossil fuels for motive power.  The design parameters are theoretical at present, and funding to develop a working prototype system will allow us to prove (or disprove) the viability of the proposed fuel system.

column1: The E-CHOICE fuel system will use currently unused kinetic energy (created by movement of the vehicle) to produce a majority of the fuel needed to operate the vehicle (static fill-up will be used for initial operation).

The six (6) components that comprise the full system (as configured for commercial sized vehicles) will completely replace most fossil fuel systems in commercial applications.  Listed in the order we hope to develop them in, they are:

1)      Electrolysis Tank (E-Tank):  A baffled, dual chamber design that incorporates 3 separate technologies and a fully biodegradable electrolyzing agent for electrolysis of water.  Using water, every liter of water converts to 1,666 liters of useable gases (2/3 hydrogen, 1/3 oxygen).  This is the lynchpin of the entire system and must produce 1cu.yd. of hydrogen per minute to be viable as a fuel source.  The production will be cyclic
column2: dependent on the levels/pressures needed in the next two components.

column1: 2)      Hydrogen Storage Tank (HST):  25-100 gallon tank (size depends on application
column2: smaller size for buses/local uses) weighing approximately one pound per gallon of capacity.  Using the technology in the 5% category, a 25lb. tank will hold the equivalent of 165 gallons of gasoline…at less than 150psi.

column1: 3)      Oxygen Boost Tank (OBT):  25% of the oxygen produced in the E-Tank will be stored @ 250psi for re-combinative power under high load conditions (uphill, merging acceleration, etc.).  The remaining 75% of the oxygen will be released to atmosphere (replacing free oxygen lost to deforestation will be very good for the environment).

4)      Fuel Delivery System (FDS):  The actual “plumbing” of the system.  This includes all routing of produced gases from the E-Tank(s), through storage, and eventually to the intake on the engine.  Stainless steel, compression fittings, and aircraft grade hoses will be used throughout.

5)      Generator Axle (G-Axle): This will be the source of the DC power needed for the E-Tank(s).  Using the kinetic energy produced by movement of the vehicle will provide a power source that is not dependent on engine RPM, and will give the system constant power regardless of acceleration/deceleration…full power at 5mph or faster.

6)      Computerized Electronic Control Module (CECM): This will be the “brain” of the system and will control all aspects from the G-Axle, through electrolysis cycling, fuel storage, and release to metered intake delivery mixtures/pressures (H/O)

A little known yet interesting fact: Until the Pennsylvania oil strike in the early 1900s, most internal combustion engines (ICE) used hydrogen as the best fuel available.  After Pennsylvania, oil was so much cheaper and easier to use that hydrogen was abandoned…though the technology remained.  With today’s technology, fossil fuel (oil) is no longer the best alternative
column2: neither financially nor environmentally.  If the E-CHOICE fuel system is successful, the benefits are substantial:

column1: Hydrogen will be 75% (or higher) less expensive to produce. ($.25 - $.75 per gallon)
Ultra low to zero pollution: dependent on engine lubricant used (fossil fuel or organic).
The system will remove the need for a separate fueling infrastructure.
70 jobs created for the initial prototype…potentially millions within 10 years.
Environmental repair achieved by increased atmospheric oxygen – decreased pollution.
Energy security: ending our dependence on foreign oil.
There is unlimited crossover potential for other industries.

Hydrogen is an unlimited resource…it is not “consumed” during the combustion process, every molecule is returned as pure water vapor.  The JEMSTAR group believes it is time to leave the fossil fuels of the Industrial Age behind and begin making everyone’s life easier (and healthier) by moving into the Hydrogen Age.

We realize the amount we are asking for seems high, but the reality is we need to acquire the working space, equipment, and personnel for the initial prototype (including paying wages). If the E-Tank prototype is successful, the full prototype system should be ready to begin road testing within 5 years.  In the event our efforts to produce a working E-Tank fail, we will survey our contributors to determine which project(s) on indiegogo.com should receive any of our remaining funds.

If you agree with the premise/promise of this project, we hope you will be generous with your pledges.  We are using 60 days and flexible funding as the best option to achieve the results you would expect…success from start to finish.
Thank you for seeing the same future we do at the JEMSTAR Group.
Want more??? Visit the E-Choice project's FaceBook page @
https://www.facebook.com/ECHOICE4ME
6/4/13 update:
This system is a combination of disparate existing and proven technologies reconfigured into a workable system.  This is not a “Fuel Cell” system
column2: it is a component replacement system that encompasses fuel production and delivery methods for use of hydrogen as the primary fuel source in commercial sized vehicles
column3: with the intent to reduce and eventually eliminate the use of fossil fuels for motive power.  These design parameters are theoretical at present, and funding to develop a working prototype E-Tank will allow us to prove (or disprove) the viability of the proposed fuel system.

column1: ","Jonathan E. McArtor / J.E.T.S.   E-CHOICE
(Electrolysis - Creating Hydrogen Onboard Internal Combustion Engine)
HYDROGEN FUEL SYSTEM - COMMERCIAL VEHICLE APPLICATION

E-CHOICE is a six (6) component system that will replace the fossil fuel systems (gas or diesel) on commercial vehicles (trucks and buses).  95% of this system is based on currently used and accepted technology (software and hardware).  The remaining 5% consists of newly available technology and products that will become marketable with the success of our project.  Examples of the individual component technologies are readily available through simple online searches.
Beginning with the Electrolysis Tank (E-Tank), we have decided to produce the six (6) components in the prototype system one at a time
column2: to help manage the security of our working theories, and to take advantage of a multi-patent process. Since the E-Tank is the lynchpin of the system, we will develop it first.  In the following will provide a basic description of the E-Tank, followed by a brief description of the remaining components, in the order we will produce them.

column1: BRIEF HISTORY
This has been a lifetime endeavor that became this conversion project 12 years ago as the most logical advance for a proposed local transit system plan
column2: developed for my home town (Ridgecrest, CA) in the early 1970s.  Although the initial concept was mine, I had a lot of help along the way.  Patrick Obracken (deceased) helped me develop the plan for a local transit system…a system that would be the only non-government subsidized public transit system in the country (and could still be).  I invited Duane A. Burkey to join the transit project in the mid-1970s.  His mechanical knowledge and an ability to see the potential in combining hardware and technology, in non-conventional configurations, helped lead our research in the right direction.  In the late 1970s, Charles E. Quinlan joined the project as our business and technology consultant.  In addition to more than 20 years of successful small business operation, he has successfully passed the California BAR examination, and has ready access to PhD level electrical and chemical engineering review for our system.  We three: Duane, Charles, and I are the executive team and sole proponents of the JEMSTAR Group E-CHOICE project, and we are asking for your help to begin building our prototype system.

column1: While there is not an existing prototype, there are multiple examples of all the involved technologies available on the internet…all facets of this project are based on existing and proven technologies, which we will combine into an, as yet, untried configuration.
PREMISE

This system is a 95% combination of disparate existing and proven technologies reconfigured into a new, workable, combinative system.  The remaining 5% is new technology (developed but not implemented) which eliminates the dual problems of distribution and storage.  This is not a “Fuel Cell” system
column2: it is a component replacement system that encompasses fuel production and delivery methods for use of hydrogen as the primary fuel source in commercial sized vehicles
column3: with the intent to reduce and eventually eliminate the use of fossil fuels for motive power.  The design parameters are theoretical at present, and funding to develop a working prototype system will allow us to prove (or disprove) the viability of the proposed fuel system.

column1: The E-CHOICE fuel system will use currently unused kinetic energy (created by movement of the vehicle) to produce a majority of the fuel needed to operate the vehicle (static fill-up will be used for initial operation).

The six (6) components that comprise the full system (as configured for commercial sized vehicles) will completely replace most fossil fuel systems in commercial applications.  Listed in the order we hope to develop them in, they are:

1)      Electrolysis Tank (E-Tank):  A baffled, dual chamber design that incorporates 3 separate technologies and a fully biodegradable electrolyzing agent for electrolysis of water.  Using water, every liter of water converts to 1,666 liters of useable gases (2/3 hydrogen, 1/3 oxygen).  This is the lynchpin of the entire system and must produce 1cu.yd. of hydrogen per minute to be viable as a fuel source.  The production will be cyclic
column2: dependent on the levels/pressures needed in the next two components.

column1: 2)      Hydrogen Storage Tank (HST):  25-100 gallon tank (size depends on application
column2: smaller size for buses/local uses) weighing approximately one pound per gallon of capacity.  Using the technology in the 5% category, a 25lb. tank will hold the equivalent of 165 gallons of gasoline…at less than 150psi.

column1: 3)      Oxygen Boost Tank (OBT):  25% of the oxygen produced in the E-Tank will be stored @ 250psi for re-combinative power under high load conditions (uphill, merging acceleration, etc.).  The remaining 75% of the oxygen will be released to atmosphere (replacing free oxygen lost to deforestation will be very good for the environment).

4)      Fuel Delivery System (FDS):  The actual “plumbing” of the system.  This includes all routing of produced gases from the E-Tank(s), through storage, and eventually to the intake on the engine.  Stainless steel, compression fittings, and aircraft grade hoses will be used throughout.

5)      Generator Axle (G-Axle): This will be the source of the DC power needed for the E-Tank(s).  Using the kinetic energy produced by movement of the vehicle will provide a power source that is not dependent on engine RPM, and will give the system constant power regardless of acceleration/deceleration…full power at 5mph or faster.

6)      Computerized Electronic Control Module (CECM): This will be the “brain” of the system and will control all aspects from the G-Axle, through electrolysis cycling, fuel storage, and release to metered intake delivery mixtures/pressures (H/O)

A little known yet interesting fact: Until the Pennsylvania oil strike in the early 1900s, most internal combustion engines (ICE) used hydrogen as the best fuel available.  After Pennsylvania, oil was so much cheaper and easier to use that hydrogen was abandoned…though the technology remained.  With today’s technology, fossil fuel (oil) is no longer the best alternative
column2: neither financially nor environmentally.  If the E-CHOICE fuel system is successful, the benefits are substantial:

column1: Hydrogen will be 75% (or higher) less expensive to produce. ($.25 - $.75 per gallon)
Ultra low to zero pollution: dependent on engine lubricant used (fossil fuel or organic).
The system will remove the need for a separate fueling infrastructure.
70 jobs created for the initial prototype…potentially millions within 10 years.
Environmental repair achieved by increased atmospheric oxygen – decreased pollution.
Energy security: ending our dependence on foreign oil.
There is unlimited crossover potential for other industries.

Hydrogen is an unlimited resource…it is not “consumed” during the combustion process, every molecule is returned as pure water vapor.  The JEMSTAR group believes it is time to leave the fossil fuels of the Industrial Age behind and begin making everyone’s life easier (and healthier) by moving into the Hydrogen Age.

We realize the amount we are asking for seems high, but the reality is we need to acquire the working space, equipment, and personnel for the initial prototype (including paying wages). If the E-Tank prototype is successful, the full prototype system should be ready to begin road testing within 5 years.  In the event our efforts to produce a working E-Tank fail, we will survey our contributors to determine which project(s) on indiegogo.com should receive any of our remaining funds.

If you agree with the premise/promise of this project, we hope you will be generous with your pledges.  We are using 60 days and flexible funding as the best option to achieve the results you would expect…success from start to finish.
Thank you for seeing the same future we do at the JEMSTAR Group.
Want more??? Visit the E-Choice project's FaceBook page @
https://www.facebook.com/ECHOICE4ME

Eco of the Earth - Eco de la Tierra is a newly founded NGO based in Spain dedicated to the protection of biodiversity of the Mediterranean region. The Mediterranean region is a biodiversity hotspot, which is home to 15-20,000 species according the IIUCN.In Europe the incidence of threatened species is highest in the Mediterranean region
column2: 21% of the species in Spain are threatened, 15% in Portugal and 14% in Greece. The region therefore requires urgent conservation measures to try to reduce species loss and preserve the future of the Mediterranean biodiversity.

column1: Our organisation is just starting out and every donation is very welcome! In the present economic crisis funding from governments has dried up and some of the people helping in our NGO are even unemployed.

Our priority is the setting up of a bilingual website, so all donations will go towards this endeavour. This website is essential for us to be able to get our message across to as many stakeholders as possible
column2: decision and policy makers, the general public as well as both private and public institutions.

column1:
Everyone making a donation will become a ""Friend of Eco of the Earth"" and we will send everyone our quarterly newsletter as well as all updates concerning our organisation´s projects and progress.
We would just like to say ""Thank you very much"" and ""Muchas gracias"" in advance :-)!

My name is Kristine England. I am an air scientist and committed to doing what I can to save the atmosphere and stop climate change.

I have been accepted to a climate leadership program and need to make it to training in Chicago, late July. I am a single mother of two and often find it hard to make ends meet but even though I find it challenging, I am driven to save the world's environment. This training opportunity is a life transforming event. It means that I can educate and inspire others to take action and personally be inspired to do more. It will allow me to meet others who have the same goals and network to provide the best solutions for our planet.
I am asking for $1000 to get airfare and hotel accommodations in Chicago for the training.
By helping me achieve this goal, we can move forward together with helping save the world for future generations.
