Food

Food sovereignty

Honouring diversity
<i>For these reasons we are
switching to local growing, storage and milling of NON GMO Grain.
We
need $73 000.00 this year to make this 'correction' to our production

system. It is a one time cost for the farm. 

We are asking you to
consider donating what you can to support our farm in transitioning

to growing, storing and milling NON GMO grain to feed our animals.

Funds rasied will help us to pay for:
<li>Growing grain:
$60,000.00 (directly to farmer Chris to cover his costs of production)
• Feed Storage Tanks: $3,000.00 (2nd hand tank installed)
• Milling cost: $10,000.00
""A just transition process, including
financial and technical support, needs to be established to assist
farmers to shift back to non-GM seed sources and to adopt ecological
agricultural practices"" <a href=""http://foodsecurecanada.org/policy-advocacy/resetting-table"" rel=""noopener nofollow"">Resetting

the Table: A Peoples Food Policy for Canada - Page 25

Back Story

Three years ago at
TapRoot Farms we started raising animals for the purpose of
providing
fertility to the soil for our vegetable crops and tilling of the
soil
by the pigs (working to establish more permaculture
infrastructure).
Up until now we have not been growing our own grains for the
animals
to eat. We have been sourcing certified organic grains for our
hens
(eggs) and non organic, GMO feed for the other animals. This is
not
how we have wanted it to be but because of the cost of certified
organic grain we haven't switched all the animals to this feed and
haven't found a source for non organic non GMO feed as of yet. And

so, this year we decided to do something about it.

This Year

This year we set up an
agreement with a young farmer (in his 30's with a young family) to
contract
grow non GMO corn and soy for us. He is also growing barley and
wheat
for the farm. These crops will provide us with all of the
ingredients
to mix feed for our pigs, chickens, ducks, turkeys, sheep, and
cattle.
The challenge for us
at
TapRoot is that we need to cash flow the grain that the animals
are
eating now, at the same time as paying for the contract growing
and
set-up of the feed for this coming year. We agreed to pay the
farmer $600 per tonne for what we expect to be 100 tonne of feed. The farmer
was very concerned about a possible yield loss (we think this
belief
was based on propaganda) so we agreed to pay $30 000.00 in-advance
to
help with the costs of growing the crop and expect to pay the
additional $30,000.00 when the crop is in storage. In addition to
growing the crop, we also needed to put in storage tanks so that
the non-GMO grains could be stored in isolation of GMO grains.
This cost
was $3000.00. We also expect to pay $100 per tonne for the milling
fee when we take the feed to be turned into mash the animals can
eat.
Basically, in this
fiscal year (2014) we are cash flowing the shift from GMO feed to Non GMO
feed of just over $73,000.00. Now we find ourselves needing to ask for
support in making this shift.
Here is what normally
happens (for farms without their own storage and milling
equipment): A farmer grows a crop
of grain. They hire or own a combine to harvest the grain. The
grain
is then hauled to a common storage (big huge bins that hold
multiple
farmers grains). In this situation, you never get your own grain
back, because it is in one big bin together. You know you have
harvested for example 10 tonnes and then throughout the year as you
need to make feed you go and take out from the storage what you
need.
You let the grain centre know what you need and then they will
mill

the feed for you into the ration you ask for. This system works well if the production systems and quality are all equal. When you want start doing something different,  for example, growing non-gmo grain, then it gets more complicated and expensive.

We are doing this because we trust and honour nature, diversity and our ecosystem. We are now growing the grains that feed our animals close to home in a way that provides opportunities to local farmers, and honours the integrity of organic agriculture systems.   

Why
column6:
schema=youtube"" width=""580"">

Why help us? Because cash is required for taking care of this planet through our agricultural practices and the amount needed in this region of the world is rather tremendous. It is a values based decision, not a monetary return on investment business model. Most farmers we know who are transitioning to a system of agriculture that is based on a deeply held value of taking care of the earth are not getting a return on investment they require, basically they struggle. We need to make this shift as a collective. You may wonder, why not just increase the cost of the meat. If we were to down load the full cost of this transition to the people who purchase our meat via our meat shares, then again, we would be unloading an unfair amount of cost to a few people for a shift that we hope will benefit many. It feels rather complicated and hard to explain, but if you will, consider this a donation in support of a system change - a system change in the Annapolis Valley of Nova Scotia for this farm to grow, store, and feed non GMO feed to our animals and to possibly set in motion a way forward for our friends and neighbours. You are welcome to visit the farm any time, to ask questions and see for yourself what we are all about. 


Some Context

column1:
Resetting the Table A People's Food Policy for Canada  :

""Genetically-Modified Organisms (GMOs) are living pollution that self-replicate. They cannot be recalled or controlled once they have been released and can spread and interbreed with other organisms, thereby contaminating ecosystems and affecting future generations in unforeseeable and uncontrollable ways. Genetically- Modified (GM) crops threaten agro-biodiversity which is fundamental to global food security, as well as threaten the future of organic food and farming through contamination. Existing GM crops should be phased out and there should be no further approvals of GM crops and animals. A just transition process, including financial and technical support, needs to be established to assist farmers to shift back to non-GM seed sources and to adopt ecological agricultural practices."" (http://foodsecurecanada.org/sites/foodsecurecanada.org/files/FSC-resetting2012-8half11-lowres-EN.pdf, page 25)

Non-GMO Project

Lil MacPherson: Earth Hour Tour

National Farmers Union GM Food Policy

More about us at TapRoot

Josh grew up in Hants County Nova Scotia. Patricia grew up in Greenwich Nova Scotia. We met at the Nova Scotia Agricultural College. We started farming in 2004 with the purchase of 144 acres in Canard Nova Scotia. In 2007 we took out another loan to purchase a homestead, 22 acres, certified organic in Port Williams. This began our organic farming journey. Basically, we care a whole lot about growing good food for families, taking care of the soil and ecosystem and respecting and caring for the people who make it all happen. We now have 60 acres in certified organic production and 40 acres in transition to organic. Izaak (12), Lily (8) and Frank (7) are along with us on this journey. We also share this journey with Justine, Nathan, Gilbery, Falicia, Jon, Jocelyn, Louise, Gerald, Calvin, Pheobe, Melvin, Amy, Tim, Teri, Tim, Valarie, Michael, Garfield, Sylvan, Jem, Meagan, Malcolm, Patrick, Betty, Evelyn, Kingsley, Bolo, Wesley, Cournelius, Bobby, Cocotee, Ashley, Martel, Patrick, Aliah, Chris, Steve, Richard, Jillian, Karen and Cecil, Jenn, and all of our families.

<li>
Deep
organic (local production for local consumption)
<li>
Honour
and respect (for our ecosystem (people, animals, land))
<li>
Stewardship
<li>
Financial
sustainability and stability
<li>
Quality
and dependability (of service and production and experience)
<li>
Innovation,
adaptability and education
<li>
Creating
community and sharing, connected to food, family and environment
5-Year Goals (Social, Cultural, Environmental,
Financial)
The big results we are
trying to achieve:
<ol>
<li>
The
farm is a successful and replicable model
<li>
Happy
animals, happy staff, happy CSA members, and happy owners
<li>
Highly
engaged staff and CSA membership
<li>
Increased
number of people accessing local, healthy food
<li>
People
are educated about local and organic farming in Nova Scotia
<li>
organic production and processing
Improved
soil quality (Improved
micro-organism population in soil,Improved organic
matter in soil)
• Reduced
ecological footprint (Reduced dependency on
power and gas, Reduced water usage, &amp
fertility)
<li>
The
farm is financially sustainable

I am a Haitian artist living in the SF Bay area. I started Alternative Ayiti Project to help Ayiti (Haiti) help itself. My goal is to raise the environmental awareness of my fellow Haitians, while providing the means to modify the old practices of cutting trees to cook food and depending on food aid and handouts for survival. I am returning home this summer with my 4 children and several volunteers to share skills and information that will benefit my people and the environment. We are planning to have youth workshops, led mostly by my children, ages 5-10, to teach young Haitians how to construct simple solar ovens like the one they have created and use here, out of newspaper, boxes, plexi-glass/glass remnants and aluminum. These materials can be found there for free or we already have them. The adult volunteers will focus more on composting, which requires no supplies, and introducing aquaponics. We employ individuals to collect non-food waste from the streets, convert that into “eco blocks” that can be used to build fish ponds and drums, buckets, or other reusable materials we find for plant beds in the aquaponics system. Funds will primarily be used to put Haitians back to work cleaning up the country’s waste problem and rebuilding it with the same materials, one recycled block at a time. We plan to use native fruit trees to feed the fish and use the extra fish waste to grow native root plants like yam, manioc etc…Pumps (hand or solar), shade cloth,and ph testing kits will need to be purchased here in US, while gravel, pvc pipes and frames for the beds will have to be gotten there at a higher cost. The system will be a simple flood and drain reducing on the need for expensive maintenance for the long term. The plan is to continue small fundraising efforts to keep a small maintainance team for the aquaponics systems. Volunteers will also supplement the program with reforestation, yoga, leaf medicine and general ecological education. The Haitian Office of the Ombudsman is housing the volunteers and facilitating a Cite Soleil Outreach Plan for the Alternative Ayiti Project from July 1 – August 15, 2010. Fotokonbit will be documenting the work done in August. We are looking for donations of shade cloths, small solar pumps and panels, ph testing supplies (things small enough to travel with.) Monetary donations will also be accepted to pay for the materials in Haiti and to pay for labor, which will, in turn, give a much needed boost to the economy. Any amount is helpful in the rebuilding effort.

","I am a Haitian artist living in the SF Bay area. I started Alternative Ayiti Project to help Ayiti (Haiti) help itself. My goal is to raise the environmental awareness of my fellow Haitians, while providing the means to modify the old practices of cutting trees to cook food and depending on food aid and handouts for survival. I am returning home this summer with my 4 children and several volunteers to share skills and information that will benefit my people and the environment. We are planning to have youth workshops, led mostly by my children, ages 5-10, to teach young Haitians how to construct simple solar ovens like the one they have created and use here, out of newspaper, boxes, plexi-glass/glass remnants and aluminum. Our Story
Our house building efforts with three families began in South Tijuana,
Mexico two years ago through an organization called Esperanza.  Through
tremendous hard work and generous donations we got great  satisfaction
from our efforts â€“ helping those in need by providing them  with a new
home.  The impact made on the lives of others in such a short  time is
tremendous.
The Impact
We would like to continue this event twice a year through donations
from you. Your donations will cover room  and board
expenses for volunteers and for the materials  needed to

build the houses during our time there.  Any additional funding will go to expanding the house building program.  It is important to know Esperanza International has been running short on funds of late and recently laid off three people.  So it is critical we keep them going.  However, they do more than just build houses.  They have hands up, not hand out approach.  Locals are educated on maintaining a healthy community environment through entrepreneurial initiatives, home loans that the new homeowner pays off in four years, recycling programs, and urban gardens.  Volunteers get to experience another culture through the lens of a community member.  Everyone wins!
<h3>What We Need &amp
Of the $6000 collected, $1500
will go to my band five of volunteers who have done this before and would love
to do it again.  It covers their three days of room and board and the
materials needed to build the houses in Tijuana.  Donations that is in
excess of $300 will cover the most generous donors costs if they wish to
volunteer down there.  All remaining cash will go back into the programs
to keep it operating.
Other Ways You Can Help

Please make some noise!!  Share on your Facebook, tweet on Twitter, post on Linkedin, and email your friends and family.  We can expedite our goal with a $25 donation from simply using your immediate circle of friends.  We can't do this without you. Give today!

My Work as an Herbalist

As a locavore, urban farmer and herbalist I am seeking community investors in an upcoming clinical herbalism training with Natural Doctors International at their donation-based clinic in Ometepe, Nicaragua. This training will grow my skills as an herbalist and teacher so I can better connect more people to the land around them and empower them with the herbal skills that can add wellness to their lives.

Working from my urban gardens and wild spaces in Grand Rapids, I connect people to the traditional lifeways of using herbs  -- in my classes people how to forage, cook with whole foods, garden and use local plants and herbs for herbal remedies.

There have been few other times in our current history of the United States when people have been more aware of their health issues, have faced enormous economic challenges, and have had a significant lack of access to conventional health care.

People are turning to traditional lifeways -- tending a garden, cooking in the kitchen, eating meals with their families -- as part of taking care of themselves and keeping themselves well. I believe these skills and traditional lifeways are a basic right and want to make sure my work is accessible to everyone, not just to those who can afford to learn a niche skill. To that end, I always offer my classes with an option for sliding scale depending on ability to pay.

Turning to the community to help support me in this journey is a testament that I, too, am reliant on you to help value these skills and what I am offering to our local community. Thus, helping invest in my skills as a teacher will help ensure that I can most effectively work across cultural borders in our community as well as repond to their personal needs in a more helpful way.
<div>
Clinical Training with Natural Doctors International

It is difficult to find hands-on learning experiences with experienced herbal teachers in my community. I currently travel a great deal-- in addition to reading, working in the outdoors and spending time in my herbal kitchen and apothecary-- to connect with teaching expertise so I can continue to push my understanding and knowledge of the plants and their traditional uses.
In November I seek to study with a few of our country's top herbalists for a clinical training hosted by Natural Doctors International at their donation-based clinic in Ometepe, Nicaragua.

The clinical training with Natural Doctors International will run from Novmember 8-26 in Ometepe, Nicaragua. The training includes a variety of experiences -- shadowing under physicians, herbalists and natural doctors as well as learning the plants that are used in traditional healing in this area - not only in the clinic but by also being in the fields and on the farms where the plants are grown.

Natural Doctors International operates their clinic as a donation based clinic -- they rely on the service of physicians, herbalists, and natural doctors for staff support and donations of herbal formulas and other medicial supplies to help meet the needs of the community that lives on the island of Ometepe in Lake Nicaragua.

The cost of the three week training is $2700.00 plus airfare. I have already invested my own monies for the deposit to Natural Doctors International and have paid for my plane ticket, and am absorbing the costs for my travel visa, necessary shots, scrubs, and the fees hosting this campaign (about 8% of the total money raised). Please consider a small donation to help make this training a reality for me.
<div>
The Impact of this Campaign

The impact of this clinical experience is two fold -- I offer my services to Natural Doctors International to help meet the medical needs of this rural community in Nicaragua AND receive a significant hands-on training experience I feel I need to deepen my own community-based herbalism work in Grand Rapids, MI.

I look forward to fully immersing myself in teaching classes, writing and working with individuals as my grow my practice. Adequate training is a key component to developing my practice and reaching more people so that they, too, can live with more peace and wellness in their lives.
<div>
Help can come in many ways

If many can help in small ways, I will be able to meet my goal. And if you choose to graciously open your wallet, know that you will be investing in someone that will help make significant change with her work.***
And of course, I know there are many that simply can't contribute money to my work at this time. But that doesn't mean that there isn't a way to help.
Making some noise for my campaign -- sharing via social media, writing an article or two, making a statement of support for my work -- all has significant value for helping move my campaign forward.
Thank you for considering being a part of my work, my community and my belief in the value of these traditional skills.

It's about people and wellness. It's about plants and caring for the land. It's about growing a community that has a rich relationship with plants that doesn’t just happen when they are sick, but a relationship that’s a needed — desired — part of their everyday lives.
And if I surpass my goal? Please know that all monies will be reinvested in my herbalism practice to further my community outreach work by teaching more classes.
**Special thanks go out to Alicia VanHeulen and Athomas Birch for belieiving in my work and producing this video as an investment in support of this campaign.

Phase 1
Our Mission

We are dedicated to providing a sanctuary for wolves where they may live in peace, to help people understand their nature, and to save their dying population.. The goal is to build a fully sustainable, earthen cob village, including of course the wolf sanctuary, encourage community involvement through educational workshops and gatherings, and promote a simple, organic lifestyle that is harmonious with the natural flow of creation. At the same time, our mission is to encourage the preservation of some of the world's most ancient mountains, our earth, and the wildlife that seeks to coexist.  Mountaintops in several areas are being removed using explosives for easier access to fossil fuels, coal, etc.  Our self-sustaining community would insure the preservation of the surrounding area, with little to no disturbance of the natural flow of land. Our Blue Wolf Santcuary and Cob Village will contribute to all of these issues..making the world a better place for man, wolf, other creatures, and Mother Earth.
So..Why Wolves?
Wolves/wolfdogs may possibly be some of the most misunderstood creatures
column2: they are intelligent and loyal. They mate for life, have families, and live in packs. It is a common misconception that wolves seek to harm humans. Wolves are actually afraid of humans
column3: their only true predator is man.. Studies have shown that 60-90% of mortailties in wolves are through human causes via trapping, poisoning, and hunting.. These lovely creatures are extinct in many areas of the world
column4: places where they use to run freely and live their life to no avail.. Their population is slowly dwindling down further as we speak.. The world has already lost 7 different species of wolves. Extinction is forever.

column1: Hunting season for the wolves began on October 15 because the wolves are viewed as a threat to farmers and ranchers. In all acutality, wolves help balance the ecosystem.  Wolves are carnivorous, feeding on herbivores (animals that feed on plant life such as moose, elk, deer, rabbit, and mice). Many of these animals tend to eat large amounts of roots, sapplings, shoots, crops, and other plant material. Therefore, crops tend to thrive more lively when the wolves are around.  This is the balance of life, and wolves are a crucial part of this tenuous balance.

The average life expectancy of a wolf in the wild is 6-8 years, but in captivity they enjoy a lifespan of up to 16-18 years.  Blue Wolf plans to provide full housing, rehabilitation and an adoption center for wolves in need.  The sanctuary will rest in the Appalacian Mountains, in a habitat where the wolves will thrive happily, have plenty of room to run, and freely express themselves.  Some wolves will be available for adoption, others will stay for life depending on their individual needs. Blue Wolf is dedicated to help put an end to the wolve's demise through education, rescue efforts, rehabilitation, lobbying, and whatever it takes to help humanity find a way to coexist with them.
The Cob Village

Cob (which means lump) is an efficient use of natural materials (a mixture of clay, sand, straw, and water). Building with cob is simple, inexpensive, and resourceful. Cob is very insulating and durable, with many cob homes lasting over 700 years through many natural disasters, and are even fire resistant! In fact, pizza ovens and fireplaces can be made out of cob simply by taking out the straw. Each cob structure in our village will be equipped with a living roof, (a thick blanket of turf, plants, flowers, and herbs), which is beneficial to the environment and those who live in, under, and around it. Turf roofs keep the home cool in the summer, warm in the winter, decrease the global warming effect, absorb 85% of rainfall, and improve air quality. The plant material absorbs carbon dioxide and excess pollution from the atmosphere, and releases oxygen into the air. This fully self-sustaining earthen project will be powered from natural energy: solar, wind, and hydroelectric power. Approximately 30% of the homes in the world are built of earth, and approximately 50% of people in developing countries live in earthen homes.

Our non-profit organziation will include a fully sustainable bed and breakfast with 7 ""cobins.""  Guests will be able to visit the wolves in their sanctuary and experience their true nature firsthand. Workshops and seminars will be held weekly for people to enjoy during their stay, with a wide range of topics including buliding with cob, soap and candle making, natural healing and herbalism, music instruction, martial arts, and more.  Proceeds will benefit charities and other organizations with common goals, and eventually we hope to be able to travel to places in need and provide them with cob homes and shelters so they too may enjoy a fully self-sustainable lifestyle.
For the Artists

We are convinced that creativity is a healthy, even necessary aspect of life, so the village will also be home to an artist 'cobstel', a cobin that will be available at low to no cost/barter to traveling artists of all kinds, shapes and sizes in need of a warm bed and a home-cooked meal.. It will sleep 8 people at a time so we are able to accomodate the needs of traveling groups or bands.
Thank you so much for you time, support and contributions.
With love, light, and gratitude, Gregg, Jeri, Jaime, and the Wolves of the Wild

Note: The images in our gallery are only a depiction of our vision and can be found on google.com

Thank
you for checking us out! With your help, our growth will create more jobs while preventing all waste from ending up in landfills!
We
are the BullBag - the ONLY reusable dumpster bag for home and job-site cleanup and we are facing a large growth spurt and need your help!
With your help we can create more jobs and help keep 'stuff' out of transfer stations/dumps!
My
name is Paul and I have been in various sectors of the waste industry for 20+
years and learned to listen to customers through the last company I owned:
TrashBEEGone – the Home Depot Dumpster Rental Program. Listening to customers
and hearing their thoughts made me feel I needed to take the Bull by the Horns!
So, I sold TrashBEEGone to Oakleaf Waste Management, who dismantled the program, and I utilized the funds and
time to focus on the BullBag. We have beta tested, proven and patented the BullBag! Yes,
it’s actually proven and patented!
Imagine this…it’s a beautiful Saturday and you wake
up and decide you want to clean out your garage. You call to rent a dumpster (for
$99) but are told it won’t be delivered to Monday. Bummer – not getting the
clean out done this weekend! Monday comes, you fill it up. One week later it
gets picked up and you find out that you have $150 delivery/pickup charge, and
$75 fuel surcharge, AND you now owe the dumpster company $200 for additional
weight that you put in the dumpster because the rental price only included 1
ton of material! WHAT?! You had to wait for the dumpster to be delivered AND
you owe an additional $425 for
what you thought was only costing you $99! That’s $524!!! And to add insult to

injury, everything ended up in the landfill – nothing was recycled! We recycle 65% or more of what we pick up!

The BullBag solves each of these problems! A
patented, multiuse dumpster bag that once purchased, is guaranteed for life.
That Saturday morning, you could have just went to your shelf, got your water
permeable, self standing BullBag, opened, set it up and filled it. Monday it
could have been picked up, emptied it and your bag given right back to you - and
it would have been done for (the same weight as what you put in the dumpster
that cost you an additional $200 in overweight fees), ONLY $229! (an overall
savings of<span>  $295) Plus, 65% of all
contents are recycled so it helps keep the earth green and less ending up in
the landfills! So, to summarize: customers are never without a dumpster, it is

emptied within 48 hours of request, and it is cost effective and green!Even the BullBag can be recycled!

You Fill It! We Dump It! You Keep It!
The
BullBag has obtained a large contract from one of the two largest home improvement
retailers in the United States. We will begin rolling out in the Northeast
corridor stores in May and project to be East of the Mississippi by 2016. This
is such a huge opportunity for us! As a contributor to our project, you will
help us achieve our goals by creating a lot of jobs across New England
initially, and help make the BullBag an even bigger success. We want to be a
household name. We are the original solution to waste removal, remodeling,
cleanouts!
We are growing much faster than our capital can support and truly need your help! Funding
will be solely used for infrastructure, equipment and additional inventory. We
will need to add additional support centers, staffing for them, and trucks with

drivers. All funds received will be utilized for these items.

About the BullBag: we were one of the winners of CT Technology Council and are very active in communities we serve. We donate services to US Marines Toys for Tots, No Vet Left Behind, Jaime Hully Arts Foundation, YMCA summer camp sponsor, March of Dimes, and community Touch a Trucks. With all of the support and help we give voluntarily, would you consider helping us?
Even
if you can’t contribute, would you please pass us along to your friends – who knows?
Maybe they can! Thanks again for helping us keep the Earth clean and green while we generate jobs!
","Thank
you for checking us out! With your help, our growth will create more jobs while preventing all waste from ending up in landfills!
We
are the BullBag - the ONLY reusable dumpster bag for home and job-site cleanup and we are facing a large growth spurt and need your help!
With your help we can create more jobs and help keep 'stuff' out of transfer stations/dumps!
My
name is Paul and I have been in various sectors of the waste industry for 20+
years and learned to listen to customers through the last company I owned:
TrashBEEGone – the Home Depot Dumpster Rental Program. Listening to customers
and hearing their thoughts made me feel I needed to take the Bull by the Horns!
So, I sold TrashBEEGone to Oakleaf Waste Management, who dismantled the program, and I utilized the funds and
time to focus on the BullBag. We have beta tested, proven and patented the BullBag! Yes,
it’s actually proven and patented!
Imagine this…it’s a beautiful Saturday and you wake
up and decide you want to clean out your garage. You call to rent a dumpster (for
$99) but are told it won’t be delivered to Monday. Bummer – not getting the
clean out done this weekend! Monday comes, you fill it up. One week later it
gets picked up and you find out that you have $150 delivery/pickup charge, and
$75 fuel surcharge, AND you now owe the dumpster company $200 for additional
weight that you put in the dumpster because the rental price only included 1
ton of material! WHAT?! You had to wait for the dumpster to be delivered AND
you owe an additional $425 for
what you thought was only costing you $99! That’s $524!!! And to add insult to
injury, everything ended up in the landfill – nothing was recycled! We recycle 65% or more of what we pick up!The BullBag solves each of these problems! A
patented, multiuse dumpster bag that once purchased, is guaranteed for life.
That Saturday morning, you could have just went to your shelf, got your water
permeable, self standing BullBag, opened, set it up and filled it. Monday it
could have been picked up, emptied it and your bag given right back to you - and
it would have been done for (the same weight as what you put in the dumpster
that cost you an additional $200 in overweight fees), ONLY $229! (an overall
savings of  $295) Plus, 65% of all
contents are recycled so it helps keep the earth green and less ending up in
the landfills! So, to summarize: customers are never without a dumpster, it is
emptied within 48 hours of request, and it is cost effective and green!Even the BullBag can be recycled!You Fill It! We Dump It! You Keep It!
The
BullBag has obtained a large contract from one of the two largest home improvement
retailers in the United States. We will begin rolling out in the Northeast
corridor stores in May and project to be East of the Mississippi by 2016. This
is such a huge opportunity for us! As a contributor to our project, you will
help us achieve our goals by creating a lot of jobs across New England
initially, and help make the BullBag an even bigger success. We want to be a
household name. We are the original solution to waste removal, remodeling,
cleanouts!
We are growing much faster than our capital can support and truly need your help! Funding
will be solely used for infrastructure, equipment and additional inventory. We
will need to add additional support centers, staffing for them, and trucks with

drivers. All funds received will be utilized for these items. About the BullBag: we were one of the winners of CT Technology Council and are very active in communities we serve. We donate services to US Marines Toys for Tots, No Vet Left Behind, Jaime Hully Arts Foundation, YMCA summer camp sponsor, March of Dimes, and community Touch a Trucks. With all of the support and help we give voluntarily, would you consider helping us?
Even
if you can’t contribute, would you please pass us along to your friends – who knows?
Maybe they can! Thanks again for helping us keep the Earth clean and green while we generate jobs!",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","New Haven, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-bullbag-helps-save-the-environment-while-creating-new-jobs/pica

What do I get?
Every pledge will be rewarded with one of our bide eco cleaning boxes
column2: a month's supply of zero waste, vegan, toxin-free, eco cleaning products.

column1: Each bide box contains:
<ul>
<li>
Eco Dishwasher Powder - handmade, plant derived powder power which leaves your dishes sparkly clean. Lightly fragranced with peppermint essential oil.
<li>
Eco Washing Up Liquid - vegan, handmade washing up liquid concentrate with lemon essential oil. We don't ship water. Simply pour the concentrate into your bottle and dilute with water.
<li>
Eco Toilet Cleaning Bombs - hand crafted cleaning bombs that fizz your toilet to cleanliness. Featuring eucalyptus, lavender and peppermint essential oils that leave your bowl smelling beautiful.
<li>
<strong>Iron &amp
column2: Velvet Soluble Sachets - 5 x cleaning concentrates to make:

column1: • Anti-bacterial Kitchen Cleaning spray
• Anti-bacterial Bathroom Cleaning Spray
• Oven Cleaner
• Floor Cleaner
<li>Glass &amp
<li>
Compostable Cloths - 3 x compostable cloths that last. Simply pop into your washing machine when they need refreshing.
<li>
Wooden Dishbrush - dishbrush with non-plastic vegan bristles.
<li>
Eco Scourer - biodegradable scrubber to tackle stuck-on  food.
We are raising £20,000
£20,000 will help us grow the home-manufacturer network to support more people rebuild their lives.
The demand created by this crowdfund target will enable us to provide paid work to 205 home manufacturers.
13% of funds raised will go directly to our home manufacturer network
45% of funds is used to pay for the natural raw ingredients and recycled packaging
18% of funds pays for the delivery of bide boxes
24% of funds will be used to set-up a distribution centre and develop our infrastructure so that we can reach more people.
The Impact
Every bide box sold represents an unemployed or marginalised person who is picking themselves up out of their situation.
bide has partnered with Working Chance, a work-place charity that supports women with convictions rebuild their lives.
We provide them with remote training and support to make our eco cleaning products.
By pledging to support bide you are:
<ul>
<li>
Changing people's lives - our target means 205 people will earn a living
<li>
Eliminating plastic waste - one bide eco cleaning box eliminates all plastic waste from your cleaning cupboard.
<li>
Supporting local industry - everything in our boxes has come from UK suppliers
<li>
Reducing toxins in your home - we do not use toxic ingredients in our cleaning products
<li>
Addressing imbalance - helping people to rebuild, reduces the cavernous gap between the haves and the have-nots.
Supporting the planet and the people who inhabit it
bide is a B Corp pending, Social Enterprise founded to address rocketing unemployment expedited by the pandemic.
We are a team of people dedicated to finding solutions to support the marginalised, to lessen the gap between the haves and the have nots.
We also believe that the Climate Crisis is calling for mass adoption of sustainable lifestyles.
We have launched a decentralised manufacturing ecosystem which produces eco cleaning products.
By supporting bide today, you can make a meaningful change to someone's life and take a step forwards on your sustainability journey.
As Featured in:
bide Customers Love our Boxes
We receive outstanding 5-star reviews from our customers.
They love that every box has been designed to be an effective sustainable cleaning solution.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't make a pledge, no worries. But please do shout about bide from the rooftops.
You can share on your social media posts using Indiegogo's sharing buttons.
Support bide to support the planet and the people who inhabit it.

Update: We're Live

Look out Shell! You've got a new neighbor: The People's Platform. Last Friday we anchored the People's Platform in Elliott Bay just a few hundred yards from Terminal 5, Shell's new base of operations. We were at the center of the Paddle in Seattle kayak armada and were honored to host dozens of Coast Salish nations from the Pacific Northwest for a Native American jam session and speak out against Shell on our stage. 

In a direct rebuke to Shell's massive drill rig, Polar Pioneer, folks have begun referring to the People's Platform as the Solar Pioneer. Until Shell leaves port we'll be lighting up the nights, projecting videos and elevating the voices of folks from all over the world who take issue with Shell's destructive practices. 

Please chip into our Indiegogo and help us keep the People's Platform shining brightly on the water, bearing witness to Shell's crimes against the climate. 

Thanks!!
<hr/>
The Lowdown
Shell is bringing its oil rigs into Seattle before heading up to the Arctic Ocean to begin exploratory drilling this summer.

So, we want to show Shell what safe energy production REALLY looks like. That's why we're constructing the ""People's Platform"", a floating showcase of energy solutions that are a whole lot less STUPID than Shell's proposed drilling plan.

We're turning an ordinary marine barge into the People's Platform with solar panels and wind turbines to energize our incredible show of people power. We'll light up the night with massive projections exposing Shell's horrendous track record in the Arctic and around the world.

Help us make the People's Platform a reality. It's going to help unite folks from all over the Salish Sea who care about the climate. We're creating a powerful platform (literally) for those who don't want to stand on the sidelines while the Pacific Northwest becomes an giant export corridor for dirty oil, gas, and coal.
Perks

$5: Deckhand
Welcome aboard! You'll be publicly listed on the Mosquito Fleet and Other 98% websites as an official crew-member of the People's Platform.

$10: Give Shell Hell
We blast your personal message to Shell onto our giant projection screen. The shorter and pithier your message, the better. Example: ""SUCK it Shell! ...but not outta the Arctic."" Once you have made your contribution, send us a direct message on Indiegogo with some fresh hell for Shell.
$25: Mosquito Fleet Sticker
The Mosquito Fleet is a volunteer armada of kayaktivsts that are swarming against Global Warming in the Salish Sea. Get your sticker and fly the flag, mateys!!

$50: Mosquito Fleet T-Shirt
The Mosquito Fleet has formed to paddle Big Oil's dirty rigs and tankers out of the Seven Seas. Get your t-shirt and join the Fleet. Arrrrrgh!

$50: Solar Power to the People!!
What the Hell Shell? Next time try solar.

$100: Mosquito Fleet Hoodie
Let the whole world know that you're rolling deep with the Mosquito Fleet. Our Mosquito Fleet logo, but on a hoodie!

$100: Solar Power Hoodie
Why the sHell are we drilling the Arctic full of holes when we can have free unlimited energy from the Sun until the end of time?
Take the clothes off our backs. You get both hoodies and both t-shirts.
$500: The Captain's Pack
Get 2 First Mate's Packs. Just think of how many folks you know that would love to get these t-shirts and hoodies as a gift.

$1,000: Fancy Dinner on the Platform
Ambiance? We got your ambiance right here. We'll make you and your +1 the fanciest dinner for 2 that you've ever experienced on an industrial barge.

$5,000: Big Night Out on the Barge
Delicious dinner for 4 served to you by the Mosquito Fleet's finest safety coordinators out on the People's Platform. Dine al fresco, then enjoy hours of fun at Shell's expense.

$10,000: A Night on the Platform
The People's Platform will be one of the most romantic residencies in Seattle while it's out there. What better place to spend the night with someone you love. Remember: What happens on the People's Platform stays on the People's Platform.
Budget

Our budget powers the People's Platform for two weeks. We're contracting with some of the most innovative, future-minded engineers in the entire Pacific Northwest. If we don't meet our goal we can still use this money to get the People's Platform out for as long as we can. All other proceeds will go to benefit sHellNo movement building in Seattle.
<div>
<ul>
<li>
Barge Rental -- 40 ft x 100 ft Marine Barge anchored off Alki for 1 month w/ insurance -- $15K
<li>
Barge Energy -- Solar Arrays, Wind Turbines, Inverters and Batteries -- $45K
<li>
Barge Build Out -- Projectors, Light-show, Floating Dock, Sound System, etc. -- $25K
<div>
Recent Press Coverage
<ul>
<li>
Grabbing Paddles in Seattle to Ward Off an Oil Giant, The New York Times, May 11, 2015.
<li>
Mayor: Port needs new permit to host Shell oil-drilling fleet, The Seattle Times, May 4, 2015, Front Page.
<li>
Kayaks vs. Shell Face Off In Seattle, Al Jazeera America, Apr. 29, 2015
<li>
'Cold welcome' for Arctic drilling rig's arrival, The Seattle Times, Apr. 17, 2015, Front Page.
<li>
Can a Flotilla of Kayaks Block Shell's Arctic Drilling Rigs in Seattle?, The Stranger, Apr. 8, 2015, Front Page.
<li>
'Kayaktivist' teachers train for Shell protest, KING 5 News, Apr. 23, 2015
<li>
Shell Oil Arctic Drilling Rig Arrives Off Port Angeles, KUOW (NPR) News, Apr. 17, 2015

The problem
column5: >Invasive species are wreaking havoc in every corner of the world, causing $1.4

column1: trillion in damage annually. In the United States, 42%
of Threatened and Endangered Species are at risk due to invasive species, and
the situation is only getting worse.
Invasive species are
organisms that have been introduced into an area where they don’t belong, and
are negatively impacting the ecosystem, the economy, and human health. Pythons
are gobbling up birds and alligators in the Everglades, Zebra mussels are
clogging up the Great Lakes, and Africanized honey bees (aka killer bees) are
attacking people and pets alike. And that’s just to name a few.

The solution

Clearly, invasive species are a monumental problem. Control is tricky – how can
we simply remove entire populations of harmful plants and animals? Fortunately,
community-based grassroots control methods are showing promise: local
eradication projects are three times more likely to succeed than regional
projects, and eight times more likely to succeed than nationwide projects.
People are getting creative. Whether it’s serving invasive
lionfish on restaurant menus, marketing nutria fur as a fashionable new
product, or involving school kids in weed removal programs, Americans are
developing unique approaches to getting rid of these pesky invaders.
Unfortunately, most local management is isolated – few people outside of the
community are aware of these inventive techniques.
That’s where the Invasive Species Initiative comes in.

My plan 

I want
to highlight innovative approaches to invasive species management. In each stop
on the Millennial Trains Project, I will interview locals who are taking the
problem into their own hands, one invasive species at a time. I’ve identified
six different invasive management projects in each of the six stops on the
journey. These projects involve chefs, storeowners, professors, school kids,
and more. I want to tell their stories.
I will photograph and record each of my interviewees, and
blog about my experiences along the way. The interviews will emphasize A) How
they got involved with invasive species management, B) Their plans for
management in the future, and C) Advice for others interested in making a
difference in their own communities. I’ll also be tweeting/posting/instagramming
every step of the way, and be available to answer any questions followers might
have. The project will culminate in a large photo series and a number of
articles about my findings that I will send out to (hopefully!) get published.
To learn more about my work, check out The Lionfish Project
– a 2012 project supported by a National Geographic Young Explorers Grant that
looked at local responses to invasive lionfish in the Florida Keys. It’s just
one example of the extraordinary measures taken by locals to protect their
native ecosystems from invaders.
<b>Vision for the

future 

Invasive species are here to stay, and it’s up to us to make sure
they don’t destroy our native ecosystems. <b>Invasive species management is an
incredible way to have a hands-on role in conservation, and concerned citizens
all over the country are doing their part. By highlighting the stories of
individuals on the forefront of invasive management, I hope to educate others
about the threats of invasive species and inspire them to help protect their
own communities.
Note:
If my campaign is among the first 20 to reach its $5,000 goal, all funds raised
will go to MTP, which is a 501(c)3 organization (aka they will be
tax-deductible). These funds help to underwrite the costs of the journey
and its associated programming, transportation, and hospitality costs. If I am
not among the first 20 applicants to reach their crowdfunding goal, none of my
supporters will be charged.

<div>
Who said science does not happen in Mexico?
GenetiX is a high-performace science  and research group. Our ultimate goal is to create solutions to actual problems, which last and create a positive impact, using biotechnology.

At the moment, we are developing a biosensor through a genetically-modified bacteria. The purpose: saving Xochimilco lake, one of the most important biological and cultural factors in our community. Its function is to detect critical levels of oxygen and heavy metals in the water, in order to enhance a better development and preservation of life in the ecosystem.
To achieve our goal, we need enough resources to fund our investigation: by buying materials, carrying on trials, and getting the appropriate spaces and mentoring
We believe in science. Do you?

0,"
Our work helps create viable and environmentally sustainable economies for indigenous Amazon communities as an alternative to extractive industries. In this way, they can continue to be stewards of the forests, ensuring the health of the planet. Once an indigenous community has been disrupted by extractive industries, they are often left with no means to adjust to a new way of life and are unable to continue to live solely in their traditional way. Our work supports their culture, livelihood and self-determination. We develop lasting relationships and work in collaboration with artisans to ensure their needs are addressed. We co-create and bring to the world beautiful traditional and contemporary collections of fine organic and handmade Amazon eco fashions, accessories and home products made with sustainable rainforest materials, based on each community's traditional artistry. We currently work with the Cofán in Ecuador and the Awajún in Perú. www.orgbyvio.com

Your support makes our mission possible, as we grow organically and address the needs of the artisans and communities.
The more funds we have to do our work, the more communities we can reach out to.
CONTRIBUTIONS ARE ACCEPTED WORLDWIDE.
<h3>Our Work &amp

• Assess a community's strengths and traditional livelihood to jointly develop a sustainable industry based on their traditional artistry.

• Set up traditionally built facilities for artisans to have a place to develop and produce their goods.

• Work with indigenous Amazon artisans to develop products and open markets that generate a sustainable economy for the communities, while protecting their culture and rainforests.

• Design and develop products based on their traditional arts and local materials.

• Train in quality and production to ensure consistency.

• Train in business and marketing to run their own businesses independently.

• Train in computer and internet.

• Supply communities with materials, laptops, internet, electricity through sustainable sources, etc., where needed and available.

• Fund production of goods.

• Pay artisans a fair wage for samples and production of goods, as well as share 50% of profits from the sale of goods (after all costs and expenses) with producing communities to use in varied ways through projects that enhance their livelihood, while maintaining their cultural identity.

• Connect with luxury markets and designers looking to source the artisans' work for their collections.

• Exhibit and sell collections and traditional goods through wholesale, trade shows and our online Shop.

• Ensure that artisans and youth continue cultivating their arts and culture.

• Promote the protection of indigenous Amazon culture and the rainforest within the communities, domestically and abroad.

• Share sustainable solutions that harmonize with indigenous Amazon culture to enhance their way of life and address a community's needs.
<div>
The Impact

We work with women-run artisan associations in the Amazon. Their success impacts their lives, that of their families and communities by using their own creative resources to generate sustainable means to address their needs and thrive in their own communities.

Their success in their own communities also means that they can live where they feel most alive, surrounded by nature and ancestral wisdom they have protected for centuries.

Protected Amazon rainforests benefit all of us and the planet.
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help
Buy the artisans' exquisite high-quality Amazon eco fashion and products at www.orgbyvio.com.
Write about the artisans and our work in your blog, magazine, and in social media.
<div>
Invest in our mission.
For a tax-deductible contribution, please visit www.amazonwatch.org and donate, in Additional Comments write “VIOLETA’S AMAZON PROJECT”.
We'd love your support, if you like our work, mission and seeing the people of the Amazon thriving, as we, together, protect the rainforests for us and the planet.
Thank you!

PaTS stands for Partnership and Technology for Sustainability. ""PATS means EARTH in the YANESHA dialect. PaTS has twelve years working in the Palcazu Valley, in the Central Peruvian Amazon, with  the Yanesha ethnic group as partners, in five Native Communities along this exquisitely beautiful lush valley.

PaTS program increases the value of one tree, from US$30 to $1,800 of economic sustenance for the forest inhabitants.  This allows them not to have to harvest many trees to live sustainably, and allows for their forests to be managed easily.  Only two trees per hectare were harvested, on average, last year, 2011.

Artisans are able to work in their own home.  We aim to keep them employed only three weeks a month, so they may also tend their farms and live their family lives.  PATS is a Peruvian non-profit organization still receiving financial sponsorship from foundations until sales reach a Sustainability break even volume, forecasted to be reached by the end of 2013. www.patsperu.org

column1: Traditional Ashaninka Cushma Robe Ecotribal $350+
<div class=""template asset"">

For $350+ you receive this traditional Ashaninka cotton robe, or cushma, woven by Ashaninka women for the men of their tribe. The organic cotton is grown in small forest gardens within the Peruvian Amazon rainforest.

Dyed with plant dyes, Cushmas are an Ashaninka's most prized possession and there is a very long tradition of giving and exchanging cushmas and cloth with nyomparis (or trading partners), which linked distant Ashaninka villages into cycles of meetings, collaboration and resource sharing. Each Cushma is unique. Yours will be similar to the one pictured above.
5 Available.

<div class=""template asset"">

For $100 or more, you receive an Ashaninka Shoulder Bag from Ecotribal. Made from organic cotton fibers and natural plant dyes in a white, brown and black striped pattern with single strap. Each bag is unique. Yours will be similar to the one above.
10 Available.

Ecotribal's basic mission is to collaborate with indigenous peoples in a way that provides them with an income from sustainable products that support their culture and autonomy as well as territorial and environmental integrity.

Ecotribal has been established in 2004 after a long period of gestation, including 28 years traveling and working in South America, accumulating experience in anthropology, sustainable development, teaching, tourism and journalism. This work has led to strong direct links to rainforest communities, particularly in the Peruvian Amazon. www.ecotribal.com


Tambopata Research Center, Rainforest Expeditions $1,500+
Click on Parrot Clay Lick photo below to watch on YouTube or watch in the Gallery tab above.
column2: feature=plcp"" rel=""nofollow noopener"" target=""_blank"">

column1: <div class=""template asset"">

For $1,500 or more, you receive an expedition at Tambopata Research Center from Deep in Forests partner Rainforest Expeditions. 6 days/5 nights. TRC has been working with macaws for over 20 years. A huge claylick lays less than a kilometer from TRC.
Photos by Jeff Cremer.
Airfare not included.

Rainforest Expeditions is a recipient of The Rainforest Alliance 2012 Sustainable Standard-Setter award. This Peruvian ecotourism company shares with visitors in a sustainable manner the miracles of the Tambopata-Candamo Reserved Zone, 1.5 million hectares of pristine, still wild, tropical rainforest encompassing an area of land the size of Connecticut and stretching from the Andean highlands to the Amazon lowlands. It includes the Tambopata National Reserve, a 275,000-hectare conservation unit created by the Peruvian government in 1990 to protect the watersheds of the Tambopata and Candamo rivers. It is adjacent to the 1-million-hectare Bahuaja Sonene National Park. Conservation and ecotourism is helping to protect some of the last untouched lowland and premontane tropical humid forests in the Amazon.

Since 1989, guests of first one and now three Rainforest Expedition eco-lodges have added value to the region’s standing tropical rainforest. A sensitively conceived and managed (in some cases by native communities) touristic infrastructure creates a competitive alternative to such unsustainable economic uses as clear cutting the forest for timber or for cattle grazing. The partnerships Rainforest Expeditions has forged with local people eager to share Amazonian traditions with guests provide connection, expertise, adventure and access to wildlife in the jungles of Tambopata. Rainforest Expeditions has been verified and certified “a sustainable tourism business” by the Rainforest Alliance. www.perunature.com

The Hawai'i GMO Justice Coalition is dedicated to ending the GMO chemical warfare against our 'aina from 25 years of GMO field trials. We need your help to continue our work in educating the public and evicting Monsanto from the Hawaiian Islands.
<ul>
• Over 40,000 views in 5 months on “Stop Monsanto From Poisoning Hawai’i” film

• Our film targeted the largest private landowner on Hawai’i, Kamehameha Schools, to evict Monsanto from 1,033 acres of land. They own 363,000 acres of land, which is 11% of all 9 Hawaiian islands, plus a $9 billion endowment
• We coordinated the largest GMO labeling rally in state history with over 300 people on a Tuesday afternoon at the Hawai'i State Capitol
• Produced a Yes on Prop. 37 video featuring Russell Simmons
• We continue to shed light on the problem that 90% of the food on Hawai'i is imported. 5,000 open field GMO research tests and seed corn is on 40,000 – 60,000 acres of land.
Plans for 2013:
Kamehameha Schools Evict Monsanto Campaign
<ul>
• Continue social media campaign and ground campaign to pressure Kamehameha Schools (KS). Our campaign will ensure that KS will not lease any more of their 363,000 acres to Monsanto
• Flyers, bumper stickers, on the ground events
• 2nd installment of Kamehameha Schools Evict Monsanto film series

Even the smallest contribution will help us continue our work. PLEASE DONATE NOW!

column2: >Imagine You are 8 Years OldBy the time you're in your mid-40s:

column1: • the ocean may by flooding your city's streets.
• many of the animals you love may be extinct.
• there will be almost 10 billion human beings on the planet -- 38% more than there are today.
This unprecedented moment in our history needs to be documented. We're traveling the country to ask kids and teens:
• How are you making sense of the massive environmental challenges you'll inherit?
<li>What are you worried about? What are you
hoping for?
• What does ""nature"" mean to you?
• How do you think adults should be treating the world you'll be inhabiting after we're gone?
Click to hear:
• Lia, 11
• Danny, 17
• Karely, 17
• Indiana, 11
• Eliza, 12
• Donnie, 16
• the inspiration for this project
• audio resume for producer Amy Martin

column2: >Why We Need to Listen to Kids

column1: We're making Learning Their Place because we believe the next generation ought to be consulted about decisions that
will affect their lives forever. In the words of Carolyn Sevier, the president of the Montana Environmental Education Association, <b>“If we really believe that we are borrowing the earth from our
children, then we have a responsibility to them, and to the earth, to
hear their voices.”

In short, kids and teens deserve a seat at the table.

They also have a lot to teach us. Our environmental issues are urgent,
but the public discourse around them is often dysfunctional. <b>We need young people to help us cut through distractions and get into the heart of
the problems we face.
Why We Need Your Help
The key to this project will be the

diversity of the voices we're able to feature. Your contributions will allow us to meet kids on ranches and reservations, in suburbs and small towns, in well-known cities and little towns no one's heard of. A multitude of voices is what will make this documentary rich and rewarding to listen to, and we can't spend the time, buy the equipment, or book the plane tickets without your help.
What the Final Product Will (and Won't)
Sound Like
Let's start with what this won't be. We're not making Kids Say the Darndest Things. We're not into cutesy or

overly sentimental stuff. On the other end of the spectrum, we're not interested in a heavy-handed, doom-and-gloom sort of piece either.

We are committed to creating nuanced,
respectful and real portraits of the young people we interview. We
take kids seriously as thinkers. Just as we would with adults, we'll be looking for interview subjects who are living in the
complexities of the world we've made for them -- the confusing grey areas with no easy answers -- who can share

their thoughts and feelings about that experience.

Our goal is to present an intimate look into the lives of young people who are growing up under the weight of imminent environmental change. Learning Their Place
won't be an advocacy piece or a science lesson. It will be an unflinching look at what we're passing on to our children.
column2:
>What Other People Are Saying
""It's our children and grandchildren who are going to have to deal

column1: with the consequences of the actions we are and are not taking now. <b>This

project gives the children a chance to have their voices heard.""
-- Steve Running, co-recipient of the 2007 Nobel Peace Prize as a member of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change

""Nature, we tell kids, is a place to be quiet. But sometimes,
the natural world needs kids to speak up. And that’s what Amy Martin is asking
them to do in this documentary that requests adults listen, not to the birds,
not to the drills, not to the talk-show commentators, but to the inheritors of this beleaguered, beautiful place.

It is an exciting and necessary project.""
-- Kim Todd, author of Tinkering with Eden and Sparrow
“As
an organization dedicated to getting teachers and students connected
with nature in Montana, <b>Montana Environmental Education Association is
excited and honored to support the Learning Their Place radio
project — an ideal media space to listen to the stories of kids and their

experience with the environment from their own authentic perspective.”
-- Montana Environmental Education Association

""While we argue
with each other, the kids together look out at their future with justifiable
fear, but on fire to help create solutions if we only give them the chance, if
we only listen. <b>You are going beyond advocacy to
the heart of the matter, going deep. I

don’t see any other way out of this mess, or forward into all that is possible.""
-- John Friedrich, Climate Parents

""This project is really
important. It's important for us to save wild places, and if kids

don't see them, and enjoy them, we're much more likely to lose them.""
-- Tom Pedersen, 2012 Montana Teacher of the Year
""This project has the potential to show the world, especially adults,
what the
environmental damage we've caused has done to the psyche of America's
youth. That is, what it feels like to grow up with the certainty that
major environmental calamities will happen in their lifetime. I think

that's an interesting and important goal.""
-- Rachel Klein, Director of Student Advancement for Highline Public Schools

""I'm excited for this project. I have been hearing a lot of voices on the
importance of re-connecting kids to our natural world, but they are
always adult voices. It would be refreshing to hear young people speak

out on the subject."" -- Andrew Jay, Director of the Seward Park Audubon Center

""The
idea of hearing from kids directly is very profound. I want to hear what
young people have to say about growing up in this unprecedented time,
when the world is changing drastically and the effects of climate change

are noticeable and very real.""
-- Deb Fassnacht, Executive Director, Watershed Education Network

""In the international conversation
about environmental destruction and what we can do about it, <b>the
wisdom of children is often overlooked. Learning Their Place gives
voice to those who would inherit this world and gives hope to us

all.""

-- Carolyn Sevier, nature educator,
mother, and president of the Montana Environmental Education

Association

""Having this topic on our minds and as a part of the discussion in our country is a good thing.""

-- Shawn Sears, Executive Director, Vida Verde
If you think kids and teens should be part of the national conversation about their future,          please donate today.

Thank you!

","Imagine You are 8 Years OldBy the time you're in your mid-40s:
the ocean may by flooding your city's streets.
many of the animals you love may be extinct.
there will be almost 10 billion human beings on the planet -- 38% more than there are today.
This unprecedented moment in our history needs to be documented. We're traveling the country to ask kids and teens:
How are you making sense of the massive environmental challenges you'll inherit?
What are you worried about? What are you
hoping for?
What does ""nature"" mean to you?
How do you think adults should be treating the world you'll be inhabiting after we're gone?
Click to hear:
Lia, 11
Danny, 17
Karely, 17
Indiana, 11
Eliza, 12
Donnie, 16
the inspiration for this project
audio resume for producer Amy Martin
Why We Need to Listen to Kids
We're making Learning Their Place because we believe the next generation ought to be consulted about decisions that
will affect their lives forever. In the words of Carolyn Sevier, the president of the Montana Environmental Education Association, “If we really believe that we are borrowing the earth from our
children, then we have a responsibility to them, and to the earth, to
hear their voices.”
In short, kids and teens deserve a seat at the table. They also have a lot to teach us. Our environmental issues are urgent,
but the public discourse around them is often dysfunctional. We need young people to help us cut through distractions and get into the heart of
the problems we face.
Why We Need Your Help
The key to this project will be the

diversity of the voices we're able to feature. Your contributions will allow us to meet kids on ranches and reservations, in suburbs and small towns, in well-known cities and little towns no one's heard of. A multitude of voices is what will make this documentary rich and rewarding to listen to, and we can't spend the time, buy the equipment, or book the plane tickets without your help.
What the Final Product Will (and Won't)
Sound Like
Let's start with what this won't be. We're not making Kids Say the Darndest Things. We're not into cutesy or
overly sentimental stuff. On the other end of the spectrum, we're not interested in a heavy-handed, doom-and-gloom sort of piece either. We are committed to creating nuanced,
respectful and real portraits of the young people we interview. We
take kids seriously as thinkers. Just as we would with adults, we'll be looking for interview subjects who are  living in the
complexities of the world we've made for them -- the confusing grey areas with no easy answers -- who can share

their thoughts and feelings about that experience.Our goal is to present an intimate look into the lives of young people who are growing up under the weight of imminent environmental change. Learning Their Place

won't be an advocacy piece or a science lesson. It will be an unflinching look at what we're passing on to our children.What Other People Are Saying""It's our children and grandchildren who are going to have to deal
with the consequences of the actions we are and are not taking now. This

project gives the children a chance to have their voices heard.""-- Steve Running, co-recipient of the 2007 Nobel Peace Prize as a member of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change ""Nature, we tell kids, is a place to be quiet. But sometimes,
the natural world needs kids to speak up. And that’s what Amy Martin is asking
them to do in this documentary that requests adults listen, not to the birds,
not to the drills, not to the talk-show commentators, but to the inheritors of this beleaguered, beautiful place.
It is an exciting and necessary project."" -- Kim Todd, author of Tinkering with Eden and Sparrow

Short Summary
<div>
We are a Philippines based company that specialize in flood mitigation and sand supply for the local and international markets.
All our work is based on flood mitigation, environmental restoration, repatriation of the people along with returning lively hoods for the people.

During the monsoon season from June to November , the heavily silted rivers in the Philippines are prone to flooding. This flooding causes large scale damage within the local communities, bringing suffering to the local population and devastation to their livelihoods. One way to help alleviate this annual event is to implement large scale dredging (Flood Mitigation)
Projects that are aimed at removing excess material by dredging channels within the old river system and help guide the excess water out to sea.
The opportunity to dredge and de-silt is one of commercial viability as in Asia there is a large demand for this excess material to be used in land reclamation projects.

The Impact

Once again i reiterate the importance of your funding. By contributing to this cause you are helping to prevent major yearly flooding that sadly kills many people and destroys many more lives and property. It will also create a vast array of opportunities to the people of the philippines as well as the world. The sand that is dredged will be sold off to major companies for reclamation projects locally and internationally.
Risks &

Like anything you do there are risks involved , however we are a strong experienced team and we have a strict contingency plan put in place should any challenges arise. The contingency plan will be enforced in the event of natural disasters , malfunctioning equipment  or in the event of a safety emergency.
We also understand competition can come into the market place, how ever with our MOA with Local Government and the correct local people on our team we believe we can cover any challenge.
","Short Summary
We are a Philippines based company that specialize in flood mitigation and sand supply for the local and international markets.
All our work is based on flood mitigation, environmental restoration, repatriation of the people along with returning lively hoods for the people.

During the monsoon season from June to November , the heavily silted rivers in the Philippines are prone to flooding. This flooding causes large scale damage within the local communities, bringing suffering to the local population and devastation to their livelihoods. One way to help alleviate this annual event is to implement large scale dredging (Flood Mitigation)
Projects that are aimed at removing excess material by dredging channels within the old river system and help guide the excess water out to sea.
The opportunity to dredge and de-silt is one of commercial viability as in Asia there is a large demand for this excess material to be used in land reclamation projects.
DMCW as a company we will be involved in Corporate Social Responsibility programs which we will implement within the communities we operate in.

Dredge Masters & Civil Works is a newly formed SEC registered Philippine based Company (SEC CS200719514) that has been set up with our JV Partners to undertake Privately Funded Dredging and Civil Works projects in the Philippines. We have the expertise and modern equipment that is needed to address flood mitigation projects and their many requirements.

DMCW requires funding assistance to reach their true potential.This includes finalizing engineering designs for new dredges, infrastructure design as well as completing the final major investment package.

With your help we can achieve our dreams of dredging & de-silting rivers, returning rivers as near as possible to their original condition. This will allow the return of natural fisheries and the set up of professional fish farms, more opportunities will be created for local people to supply the local market as well as creating the demand for export.

(Done by another party) The 3rd component is reforestation planting special trees and deep rooted grasses to minimize new siltation entering the river system and destroying all the good work already done.      What We Need & What You Get Break down of what we need:
Design engineering & drawings for the new cutter suction dredges $150,000.
Project Site Engineering Design & Drawings $200,000
Lawyers and Bank fees for the full $40 million loan $400,000
Office and Warehouse space Subic bay Free Port Zone, tax free status. $100,000

Other funds will be used to pay for bankable core samples and laboratory testings and results. Specialized Sieving equipment to be operated by company personnel to maintain a required standard for the product.

The Impact Once again i reiterate the importance of your funding. By contributing to this cause you are helping to prevent major yearly flooding that sadly kills many people and destroys many more lives and property. It will also create a vast array of opportunities to the people of the philippines as well as the world. The sand that is dredged will be sold off to major companies for reclamation projects locally and internationally.
Risks & Challenges

Like anything you do there are risks involved , however we are a strong experienced team and we have a strict contingency plan put in place should any challenges arise. The contingency plan will be enforced in the event of natural disasters , malfunctioning equipment  or in the event of a safety emergency.

We also understand competition can come into the market place, how ever with our MOA with Local Government and the correct local people on our team we believe we can cover any challenge.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

My name is Katie Yacoub.  I am a 13 year old Girl Scout.  This is fundraising to help me earn a Silver Award Project, the Second Highest Award a Girl Scout could earn.
Plastic bags are a major problem for our environment.  Every year Americans alone use 100 billion
plastic grocery bags and only 5% are recycled. Many of these bags end up
killing aquatic animals and filling up landfills where toxins then seep into
ground water or water streams.  My Silver

Award project is to ban the retail use of plastic bags in Eastchester. 

I am raising money to buy at least 500 reusable bags.  The bags will be given to shoppers in town, so that people
can use them instead of the plastic bags that stores currently offer.
I am doing this project because I truly believe that
everyone is responsible for helping the environment. Every little thing we do affects the world so
if we help improve the environment in any community, then we are helping the world
as a whole. I want to get people to be
more aware of how they affect the environment and ban the retail use of plastic
bags, so they can use reusable bags for their shopping.<span>  Many other cities have banned the retail use of plastic
bags so I thought why not, in my hometown.
I believe in improving the environment.

That is why I started this project.

If you are not able to donate you can still help me with my project ...
<ul>
• Avoid using plastic bags.
• Sign my online petition.  http://petitions.moveon.org/sign/ban-plastic-bags-in-eastches
• Spread the word through my Facebook page on the project  https://www.facebook.com/eastchesterbanplastic
• Feel free to share this on all your social media

Short Summary

La Tortuga Viva (‘Living Turtle’ in Spanish) is a sea turtle sanctuary on the southern Pacific coast of Mexico run by 14 volunteers from the local community of Juluchuca, Guerrero, Mexico. La Tortuga Viva works for the preservation of 3 endangered sea turtles species - the Olive Ridley, the Leatherback (highly endangered) and the Black Turtle. The volunteers vigilantly patrol the beach every night of the year and safely transplant the vulnerable turtle eggs that would otherwise get stolen by poachers (people), devoured by predators (dogs, badgers and other animals) or washed away by high tide. Relocating nests into the sanctuary is crucial to the survival of these baby sea turtles.

The camp runs on donations from visitors to the area, however, it is not enough. The local volunteers have been clearing the new area (just across from the old one) for weeks and are ready to get started on constructing the new sanctuary ahead of the peak nesting season starting in July.
What We Need
Supplies needed for a 30m x 20m sanctuary::
<ul>
• Fence: $500
• Mosquito netting: $80
• Roof mesh: $2000
• Wire: $8
• Tape: $30
• Wooden poles (80): $300
• Operation cost for running campaign (includes fees, perks purchases etc): approximately 30% of funds raised.
Impact

Every year, thousands of mama sea turtles come to nest on Juluchuca’s beach. Each mama can lay between 60-100 eggs several times in a season. Each $20 donation will help 10 of these vulnerable baby sea turtles make it to the sea.
Please contribute. Your generous donation will help preserve this ancient and incredible species. Any amount will help us get closer to that goal.
