Short Summary

Hi!  My name is Jen Frey and I have dedicated my life to the Plants.  I am the founder of Brigid's Way, www.brigidsway.com.  As part of my work, I help to connect people with Nature, guiding them to find true healing.

I searched for years to find Land where I could create a center to teach my classes and create a Sanctuary.  We found the perfect place (or perhaps the Land found us) and moved here in May 2017.  Since that time, I have been working with the Nature Spirits to create our next steps for this Sanctuary.
Heart Springs Sanctuary has recently become a member of the United Plant Savers' Botanical Sanctuary Network.

This Land is unique because it has several different ecosystems.  Heart Springs Sanctuary is a little over 4.5 acres with 3 ponds and a small creek.  There is currently a huge field of Milkweed and other wild native species.  We plan on simply enjoying this area.
About 1/3 of the Land is a huge grassy expanse.  We are turning this area into gardens and wild areas with walking paths and planting more Trees along the creek.

The smallest pond is on the edge of this grassy area.  We are converting the grass to a Wetlands Sanctuary.  The northern section of the Land is partially wooded, we are planting more Trees and Shrubs here and creating a Woodland garden filled with native woodland Plants like Trillium, Dutchman's Breeches, Trout Lily, and more (these will come later).  The Western section of the Land is where we are building a Labyrinth and is also the area where we bring people to experience the Nature Spirits.

We have been working with the Nature Spirits to determine how best to serve the Land and Beings.  Our first step is to plant approximately 70 Trees and Shrubs.  (This is only a small part of the Plants that we will be planting next year.)

We are asking people to sponsor the planting of these.  I was inspired by Judy Dench in ""My Passion for Trees"".  I have always honored my Loved ones who died through the planting of a favorite Plant.  In this film, Judy did the same and had a plaque with her Loved ones' names by the Tree.  She would then refer to the Trees by this name.  For those who choose to sponsor a Tree or Shrub, we are offering to plant them in honor of your Loved one.  While we are the stewards of this Land, we will greet these Plants during our walks referring to them by the name of your Loved one.  Or maybe you want to name one after yourself to be honored on our walks.
<h3>What We Need &amp
<ul>
• The total amount we need for this first step is $1270.
• ALL of the money (except for the Indiegogo fee) goes directly to purchasing Plants for Heart Spring Sanctuary.  If we surpass the $1270, we will buy more Plants who are on our LONG list.
• You get to impact the Earth through the planting of a Tree or Shrub and if you choose, honor a Loved one (or yourself) by having this Plant named after them.
The Impact

As humans we have taken much from Nature and continue to destroy habitats.  Our very lives depend on the health of the environment.  Creating a Sanctuary is one small act in trying to give back to the other Beings with whom we share this Earth.

These Plants will provide shelter and food for the wildlife and Nature Spirits who currently live here and invite more to join.  The students and public who visit the Sanctuary will have the opportunity to develop a relationship with these Plants and who knows what could come from that.  Plus, the Loved ones for whom these Plants are named after will be continually thanked and remembered.
We hope that Heart Springs Sanctuary will be a model to encourage others to create Sanctuaries and demonstrate what can happen when we work co-creatively with Nature.
<h3>Risks &amp
We have found sources for all of the Plants.
If we do not reach our goal, we will buy and plant as many of the Trees and Shrubs that we can, having the vision of bringing all of these here.

There is a slight risk that the Trees and Shrubs will not survive.  However, we have worked with the Nature Spirits and human experts to find the best Plants for the different locations.  The Plants will receive plenty of Love and attention as they grow.
We do have deer here, though so far they stay back by the large ponds, where there is plenty of food and shelter for them.
Other Ways You Can Help:
<ul>
• Share our campaign!
• Help us plant the Trees and Shrubs
• If you have Plants to share, please let us know (we do have a long list of other Plants for the Land)
• Create your own Sanctuary!

Thank you!

You get to impact the Earth through the planting of a Tree or Shrub and if you choose, honor a Loved one (or yourself) by having this Plant named after them.
The Impact

As humans we have taken much from Nature and continue to destroy habitats.  Our very lives depend on the health of the environment.  Creating a Sanctuary is one small act in trying to give back to the other Beings with whom we share this Earth.

These Plants will provide shelter and food for the wildlife and Nature Spirits who currently live here and invite more to join.  The students and public who visit the Sanctuary will have the opportunity to develop a relationship with these Plants and who knows what could come from that.  Plus, the Loved ones for whom these Plants are named after will be continually thanked and remembered.
We hope that Heart Springs Sanctuary will be a model to encourage others to create Sanctuaries and demonstrate what can happen when we work co-creatively with Nature.
Risks & Challenges
We have found sources for all of the Plants.
If we do not reach our goal, we will buy and plant as many of the Trees and Shrubs that we can, having the vision of bringing all of these here.

There is a slight risk that the Trees and Shrubs will not survive.  However, we have worked with the Nature Spirits and human experts to find the best Plants for the different locations.  The Plants will receive plenty of Love and attention as they grow.
We do have deer here, though so far they stay back by the large ponds, where there is plenty of food and shelter for them.
Other Ways You Can Help:
Share our campaign!
Help us plant the Trees and Shrubs
If you have Plants to share, please let us know (we do have a long list of other Plants for the Land)
Create your own Sanctuary!
Thank you!",3.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Washington Boro, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/planting-heart-springs-sanctuary--2/pica

>A bold mission to shine a global spotlight on the destruction of the last place on Earth where orangutans, rhinos, tigers and elephants still live together in the wild, and produce the tools that will enable the action to save it!


As man-made wildfires dubbed “the biggest environmental crime of the 21st century” (1) tear through Indonesia, they continue to destroy some of the world's most biodiverse forests and pour millions of tonnes of carbon pollution into our atmosphere. Wildlife Asia is teaming up with Racing Extinction, Oceanic Preservation Society (OPS) and Rainforest Action Network (RAN) to launch Racing Extinction in the Leuser Ecosystem, a bold mission to shine a global spotlight on the destruction of the last place on Earth where orangutans, rhinos, tigers, and elephants still live together in the wild, and produce the tools that will enable action to save it.

column1:
#SaveLeuserEcosystem

The Leuser Ecosystem is a global priority for tropical forest protection. Stretching over 6.5 million acres, the Leuser Ecosystem is a vast, teeming, ancient landscape on the island of Sumatra and considered to be one of the most important forests left in Southeast Asia. But this priceless ecosystem is under assault right now by Conflict Palm Oil. The most widely used vegetable oil in the world, palm oil can be found in over half of all packaged goods in a local supermarket. The blind growth in demand for palm oil has recklessly pushed massive, industrial-scale plantations into the heart of Indonesia's rainforests, including the Leuser Ecosystem.

column1: We have a plan!

Right now there is a diverse team comprised of the world's most talented investigators, communicators, videographers and corporate campaigners ready to go undercover and expose the culprits driving extinction in the Leuser Ecosystem. We can’t do this alone. We need you to have our back.
#StartWith1Thing

With your help we will raise $50,000- these funds are needed to provide essential equipment to enable our team to conduct field investigations and expose the culprits on the frontlines of forest destruction. The team will follow the supply chain so that we can expose the connections between this destruction and the irresponsible practices of brands that use Conflict Palm Oil in their products stocked in our supermarkets. We will bring the fight to protect the Leuser Ecosystem to the global stage, and with your help we will stop extinction in its tracks. With your help, we will WIN.

Join us

Join us now as this story unfolds, sign up for our newsletter, like us on facebook, follow us on Twitter, tell your friends about Racing Extinction in the Leuser Ecosystem and dig deep to give as much as you can give to this critical mission, every dollar counts.
If we exceed our goal, additional funds will go toward scaling up research and increasing global action against Conflict Palm Oil as we fight to promote, protect and restore the Leuser Ecosystem.
The threats are real and the stakes couldn’t be higher, and we can’t turn this around without your help.
Join us.
Meet the Team
<div>

Director of Wildlife Asia, Clare Campbell has been leading conservation initiatives across South East Asia for well over a decade, driving funding support to the protection of critically endangered species and their habitat. Wildlife Asia has years of experience of connecting local communities to global science leaders to support grass roots driven solutions which become sustainable showcases of species protection. Clare originally studied Zoology and Marine Biology and worked at Perth Zoo but now works on board multi partner engagement strategies for wildness protection focused on key habitats of some of the worlds most iconic and exotic megafauna.
Website: www.wildlifeasia.org.au
<div>
The Executive Director of OPS, Louie
Psihoyos, is widely regarded as one of the world's most prominent still
photographers. He has circled the globe dozens of times for National Geographic
and has shot hundreds of covers for other magazines including Fortune Magazine,
Smithsonian, Discover, GEO, Time, Newsweek, The New York Times Magazine, New
York Magazine, Sports Illustrated, and Rock and Ice. His work has also been
seen on the Discovery Channel, National Geographic Television and the History
Channel. His imagination, wit, and iconic imagery have helped illustrate a wide
array of complex subjects and is carried over to his filmmaking.
Website: www.racingextinction.com
<div>
Gemma Tillack directs Rainforest Action
Network’s agribusiness campaign that is addressing one of the main drivers of
rainforest destruction and human rights abuses in Indonesia: Conflict Palm Oil.
The campaign is focused on shifting demand away from socially and
environmentally irresponsible palm oil, creating incentives for the production
of responsible palm oil and transforming global supply chains. RAN’s campaigns
create the market leverage necessary to improve both corporate and government
policies and practices.
Website: www.ran.org

","A bold mission to shine a global spotlight on the destruction of the last place on Earth where orangutans, rhinos, tigers and elephants still live together in the wild, and produce the tools that will enable the action to save it!As man-made wildfires dubbed “the biggest environmental crime of the 21st century” (1) tear through Indonesia, they continue to destroy some of the world's most biodiverse forests and pour millions of tonnes of carbon pollution into our atmosphere. Wildlife Asia is teaming up with Racing Extinction, Oceanic Preservation Society (OPS) and Rainforest Action Network (RAN) to launch Racing Extinction in the Leuser Ecosystem, a bold mission to shine a global spotlight on the destruction of the last place on Earth where orangutans, rhinos, tigers, and elephants still live together in the wild, and produce the tools that will enable action to save it.

#SaveLeuserEcosystemThe Leuser Ecosystem is a global priority for tropical forest protection. The blind growth in demand for palm oil has recklessly pushed massive, industrial-scale plantations into the heart of Indonesia's rainforests, including the Leuser Ecosystem.
#CutConflictPalmOil

Public outcry has convinced many of the world’s biggest companies to commit to cut Conflict Palm Oil, but the fact is these paper promises alone will not stop the imminent threat of extinction eating away at the Leuser Ecosystem. We are in a race against time, but together we will turn this around. By naming names and exposing the actors destroying the #LastPlaceOnEarth, we will hold corporations accountable for their actions, inspire the world to take action to #CutConflictPalmOil and protect the Leuser Ecosystem for generations to come.
We have a plan!

Right now there is a diverse team comprised of the world's most talented investigators, communicators, videographers and corporate campaigners ready to go undercover and expose the culprits driving extinction in the Leuser Ecosystem. We can’t do this alone. We need you to have our back.

The threats are real and the stakes couldn’t be higher, and we can’t turn this around without your help.
Join us.

Short Summary
In Malawi, 30,000 people die every year because of waterborne diseases. That includes Diarrhea, Cholera, you name it.
Crystal Water Solutions offers affordable clean water solutions for homes and communities in Malawi.

During the British protectorate, the British set up a primitive plumbing structure designed for small, limited communities. After independence, instead of modernizing the plumbing system, our government took that rudimentary structure and made it the standard. This has come back to bite us. 50 years later!
City water is unsafe: Imagine wanting to wash your hands in your house but can’t because the water is filthy due sewer lines mixing with the water pipes. You can’t drink such water.

Home developers can’t get water immediately: Imagine if you were building a house outside the business district and having to wait a year or more to get access to water. Even after that, the water is unsafe.
Most Villages don’t have access to safe water. They take their water from unprotected streams and shallow boreholes.
So we are going to solve this water problem in 3 ways
<ul>
• Provide water filtration products
• Well repairs for villages
• Drilling wells for new development and villages

Bottled water is expensive and makes people dependent. Our bio-sand filters are economical and very efficient. Our filter makes water 99.9% bacteria free and safe for drinking. On top of that, our filters can last up to 10 years!

Crystal Water is an award-winning clean water solutions company, started by four Malawian businessmen. We grew up with these water dangers. We are familiar with the most urgent needs and have experience drilling wells. We offer Malawians safe water, education and independence to maintain it themselves.
We are optimistic in our financial projections showing profits in our first year.
With the prize money that we got from Oxford University for winning Project ENSIGO’s business competition, we are going to register our company and process necessary documentation by October 2017.
What We Need
<ul>
• $14k: buying a portable drill rig, safety work kits, equipment to make our bio-sand filters.
• $7k: will be invested in creating and buying inventory
• $9k: Operation costs for the first year
If we do not reach our entire goal, we shall start but at the less desired level.
For every 1$ you give, you contribute to saving a life off that 30,000 people that die every year because of waterborne diseases.
The Impact
Our 5-year goal is to make safe water accessible to the million people living in the capital of Malawi. When this is achieved, we will then go to the rest of Malawi.
<ul>
• Each dollar contributed is a brick laid down to make sure that we build this vision and save lives in Malawi.
• Our business model won an Oxford University funded business competition, and was thought to be the most promising and most likely to roll out.
Risks &
Most people in Malawi are still new to water filtration technologies. They would need to be convinced that they’re in need of water filters. However,
Our team is innovative in marketing strategy. All founding members have had formal business training and have designed a well thought branding exercise at the start of 2018.
We will educate and sell our filters using our door-to-door marketing campaign.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you cannot make a financial contribution, you can still save lives with us by:
<ul>
• Getting the word out to people you know can make a financial contribution
• Share this campaign using the Indiegogo tools
• Pray for us and the many lives we are going to reach and save.

My name is Lesley. I have worked and lived with farming most of my life. Mostly, involved in more traditional mixed farming, but for the last 28 years have lived on our own homestead while working also with the Environment and rural development offices as a translator and consultant.

column1: OUR ""GIFTS"" /   PERKS FOR YOU.
We want to offer something that lasts.
The
<ul>
• The Sponsorship (a tree - a square metre of land /hedgerow) the certificates are beautiful and all these sponsorships are UNDER OUR PROTECTION -they are on our land.
• The Certificate ""my home"" Make beautiful gifts, or FOR COMMUNITY or SCHOOL garden projects MAKE THEM STARS. (Ideal for   anniverseries or birthdays)

• The  addition of gifts from the Ecolonomic Action Team - which is a branch of the Institute of Ecolonomics (originally set up by Denis Weaver and his wife to promote eco-farming and nature protection) www.ecolonomics.com.  They want to show their support for this project. Together these make some amazing gifts, that will give joy and incredible knowledge for years!! For yourself or as gifts for gardeners, nature lovers, or as a gift to build a memory.
For more information on the perks please visit http://bit.ly/2mHQ9OC
If we do not reach our goal?

I don't believe that we won't reach our goal..But, as we have taken the flexi-offer, ANY money we raise will first go to getting the company formed. Everything else will be done as money is available. But, the more we raise now the faster we can move forward. Anyone contributing in the first  7 DAYS of this opening will also receive a very special ""surprise gift"".On confirmation of your contribution we will send a thank you notice and the details to the  special video  donated by Dr Wayne Dorband of the Institute of Ecolonomics.
The Impact
Sign up for our newsletters and blog on naturesfootfall.org
This PROJECT, because it is being done at a time when International Organizations are focused on a sustainable future for food and farming
column2: and that for the first time small farmers are being given a voice in how the future can look. Our template to how farmer can be funded without bank loans etc. is very important, You will be part of a massive change. Our website will have a founders page (apart from the picture galley etc. ) once a name is entered there..it is there for posterity.

column1: <ul>

• The pilot project here will not only ensure this valley will be secured as farming and woodland. Biodiversity for wild life and sustainable food.But, it will also be a place used for teaching at the same time as offering secure jobs for the local community . Beyond the local impact. The Carbon to Soil study , and study of soil regeneration and of that effect on the water cycle will be important for future projects in all areas of the world.
• We already have interest from South Africa, South America, and India , in creating a similar community project surrounding small farmers. using our template.

While neither my son nor myself have ever done a crowdfunding. To have the backing of such as EAT and encouragement from others in the business. We know our project is important, and they believe in us. Please help us turn this dream into a reality.
Risks &
<ul>

•  With any project to do with land, there are always the possibilities of hitting a problem. I have spent the last 18 months talking to government offices, land owners and International bodies. 99% of the possible problems, with their assistance, have been looked at and we have negotiated a way forward. Every thing is in place. The final KEY is the not for profit company registration! This background work -  is what I usually do for clients. This time WE are the client.  .
•  As my late Mentor used to say. We are now at a   position where ""there are now no longer any problems..there are only solutions!""
Other Ways You Can Help:

<ul><li>We know that it is not always possible to do what you may want to. If you would like to help but funds are impossible. Please let people you know about this crowdfunding. Use the Indiegogo sharetools and you can also sign up for our newsletter on <a href=""http://www.naturesfootfall.org"" rel=""noopener nofollow""><u style='font-family: ""Benton Sans"", Helvetica, sans-serif
column3: '>Naturesfootfall and share more of our story with people. If you are interested in helping in other ways, please contact us through the email on our webpage. Let's  get the word out and make some noise  TOGETHER WE CAN DO IT!.

column1: ","Who are we?

My name is Lesley. I have worked and lived with farming most of my life. Mostly, involved in more traditional mixed farming, but for the last 28 years have lived on our own homestead while working also with the Environment and rural development offices as a translator and consultant.

​Toni, my son has spent his whole life working with the land. He not only works here but on numerous properties locally. Working both in the farming and with the Dept. of Forestry teaching land owners how to ensure private forest zones can be managed safely. He is also a mechanic and does maintenance and full installation of SOLAR systems.

Naturesfootfall has been created to make it possible to save OUR area from being turned into an urban over-spill. As more properties become derelict or are put up for sale, so the developers have more chance of getting the land and then bulldozing both forest and farmland. Once it is gone - it is gone forever. This MUST not happen. With your help Naturesfootfall can ensure this area  IS KEPT and through restorative and regenerative agriculture, proper forest management and community working together, keep a very important area from destruction. We are already a zero carbon area, and thus Carbon Farming and Ecological agro-tourism will also make this a very important area for teaching how to live a cleaner more natural life and still be productive..

Your contributions will help us to get the not for profit  opened . This  allows us to  complete registration with both the EBBC ( European Business Biodiversity Campaign) and the 4p1000 Initiative, Naturesfootfall is developing a mechanism to channel Biodiversity Offset funds to small farmers to assist them change to more sustainable and regenerative farming, while improving soil, creating more sustainable water systems and strong community businesses. We are already ""community members"" of these international bodies.

We need the company to become full members and open the possibility of funding. Your contributions will make this possible and you will be recognized as part NOT ONLY of the PILOT PROJECT, BUT ALSO part of the future projects across the world - based through this not for profit that YOU are helping create...
What we need.
We are asking you help to raise 10,000€
This will enable us :
5,000€ - pay all legal costs and open the non for profit company/foundation. - 50 %
1,500€ - commissions - 15%
1,500€ -  full website and online shop -creation.  -  15%
1,000€ -media/marketing  - 10%
1,000€ - POLY TUNNEL and seed starting containers etc.-10%

If we reach that figure it will also help us to get more seedlings started using our ""seed bank"". Above that amount extra funds would allow us to pay specialist to help open the doors into the corporate biodiversity funding: 6,000€ . Then start legal contracts, Lease of land long term, thus keeping it from Developers, and start work! This would also give more trees and land to offer for sponsorship.
OUR ""GIFTS"" /   PERKS FOR YOU.
We want to offer something that lasts.
The Naturesfootfall Certificates:
The Sponsorship (a tree - a square metre of land /hedgerow) the certificates are beautiful and all these sponsorships are UNDER OUR PROTECTION -they are on our land.
The Certificate ""my home"" Make beautiful gifts, or FOR COMMUNITY or SCHOOL garden projects MAKE THEM STARS. (Ideal for   anniverseries or birthdays)

The  addition of gifts from the Ecolonomic Action Team - which is a branch of the Institute of Ecolonomics (originally set up by Denis Weaver and his wife to promote eco-farming and nature protection) www.ecolonomics.com.  They want to show their support for this project. Together these make some amazing gifts, that will give joy and incredible knowledge for years!! For yourself or as gifts for gardeners, nature lovers, or as a gift to build a memory.
For more information on the perks please visit http://bit.ly/2mHQ9OC
If we do not reach our goal?

I don't believe that we won't reach our goal..But, as we have taken the flexi-offer, ANY money we raise will first go to getting the company formed. Everything else will be done as money is available. But, the more we raise now the faster we can move forward. Anyone contributing in the first  7 DAYS of this opening will also receive a very special ""surprise gift"".On confirmation of your contribution we will send a thank you notice and the details to the  special video  donated by Dr Wayne Dorband of the Institute of Ecolonomics.
The Impact
Sign up for our newsletters and blog on naturesfootfall.org
This PROJECT, because it is being done at a time when International Organizations are focused on a sustainable future for food and farming
column2: and that for the first time small farmers are being given a voice in how the future can look. Our template to how farmer can be funded without bank loans etc. is very important, You will be part of a massive change. Our website will have a founders page (apart from the picture galley etc. ) once a name is entered there..it is there for posterity.

column1: The pilot project here will not only ensure this valley will be secured as farming and woodland. Biodiversity for wild life and sustainable food.But, it will also be a place used for teaching at the same time as offering secure jobs for the local community . Beyond the local impact. The Carbon to Soil study , and study of soil regeneration and of that effect on the water cycle will be important for future projects in all areas of the world.
We already have interest from South Africa, South America, and India , in creating a similar community project surrounding small farmers. using our template.

While neither my son nor myself have ever done a crowdfunding. To have the backing of such as EAT and encouragement from others in the business. We know our project is important, and they believe in us. Please help us turn this dream into a reality.
Risks & Challenges

With any project to do with land, there are always the possibilities of hitting a problem. I have spent the last 18 months talking to government offices, land owners and International bodies. 99% of the possible problems, with their assistance, have been looked at and we have negotiated a way forward. Every thing is in place. The final KEY is the not for profit company registration! This background work -  is what I usually do for clients. This time WE are the client.  .
As my late Mentor used to say. We are now at a   position where ""there are now no longer any problems..there are only solutions!""
Other Ways You Can Help:

We know that it is not always possible to do what you may want to. If you would like to help but funds are impossible. Please let people you know about this crowdfunding. Use the Indiegogo sharetools and you can also sign up for our newsletter on Naturesfootfall and share more of our story with people. If you are interested in helping in other ways, please contact us through the email on our webpage. Let's  get the word out and make some noise  TOGETHER WE CAN DO IT!.",2.0,1,"1 Campaign
|","Tarragona, Spain",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/naturesfootfall-nature/pica

Get to know Matt and watch his video TedX Talk, ""Tales from the ocean's garbage patch"" to learn more about the problems with plastics in our oceans. In the video you learn that Matt appreciates the marine environment and has spent a lot of time in the ocean, as the 1st to solo non-stop circumnavigate the Americas and he introduces his program, Ocean Research Project (ORP) and the marine debris research the program is currently focused on. 

We are excited to announce our upcoming 1st Trans-Pacific Plastic Pollution Survey Project that is run in collaboration with our partner 5 Gyres, and it will commence in April 2014.  Director and Explorer Matt Rutherford leads his team in advancing knowledge of marine debris located on the ocean's surface and exploring potential impacts to human and environmental health with the help of colleague and scientist Nicole Trenholm.  The duo, on a new, specially equipped sailing vessel will travel 7,000 miles from San Francisco to Japan, using a high speed trawl to collect vital data for evaluation of our oceans. 

As the Ocean Research Project confirmed last summer on a 80 days project in the North Atlantic Ocean, there are many ways plastic debris get outs to sea. Realistically, once released plastics cruise the natural highways at sea, currents that will take them everywhere. It looks like plastic does not only wind up suspended in garbage patches or gyre accumulations zones alone. “Like great explorers that know no bounds plastic occupies our entire ocean planet. The collision of natural life behavior amongst the foreign unnatural inhabitants is a real killer and we must monitor this problem.” Trenholm reports.

Our fundraising goal will directly support the expedition cost for the two team members to sail and survey from California to Japan this April. 97.5% of the total project budget has already been successfully obtained from in-kind scientific and navigation equipment sponsorship! Help us obtain the last 2.5% of funding needed to conduct and capture this environmental research.

The team will sample the waters of the California Current, the North Pacific Gyre, Japan's Kuroshio Current and transitional areas.  Samples will be collected for toxin analysis
column2:
persistent organic pollutants (POP) including PCBs and pesticides and analyzed by the University of Tokyo and bacteria analysis by a lab in Baltimore BUGSS. Students in schools throughout the USA will interact with the research team from afar to question the observations the team faces by communicating via satellite email and in hands on sample analysis in though BUGSS and an MD public school STEM Program.


This Pacific expedition will be the second plastics survey successfully completed by ORP.  In the summer of 2013, the team completed a total of 80 days of similar research in the North Atlantic Gyre.  The 2013 Atlantic data is currently being evaluated, and the 2014 Pacific Survey will complement that research.  An adventure based educational documentary film involving both projects is underway which will be entered into the environmental film circuit and be incorporated into lesson plans to educate Maryland school system students in late 2015. Check us out or follow along as we survey the Pacific at oceanresearchproject.org

Help us to track the amazing, long-distance journey of the Broad-winged Hawk from space, using satellite telemetry technology. This study is the first of its kind, with oversight by a well-qualified team:
column2:
>The Project Staff
Hawk Mountain Sanctuary biologists and collaborators will begin work in April 2014 when the Broad-winged Hawk returns from South America. Introducing the Broad-winged Hawk Project crew:
column5:
/>

Dr. Laurie J. Goodrich, Senior Monitoring Biologist at Hawk Mountain Sanctuary will co-direct and coordinate field work. Laurie will lead donor communications and reports, help analyze data, and provide public outreach throughout the migration journey. Laurie has observed migrating Broad-winged Hawks in Pennsylvania and Mexico for more than 25 years. Together with our collaborators and donors, she looks forward to uncovering answers to the many mysteries of broadwing migration. Laurie conducted independent Ph.D. research on Sharp-shinned Hawks a decade ago and is seen above releasing a radio-tagged bird.
column7:
/>

Dr. Keith L. Bildstein, Sarkis Acopian Director of Conservation Science at Hawk Mountain, will co-direct with Laurie. Keith is the author of Migrating Raptors of The World: Their Ecology and Conservation
column8: >published by Cornell Press (2006) and a world-renown raptor biologist recognized by scientists for his leadership in raptor migration study. He directs long-term studies on migration ecology and conservation of vultures and caracaras around the world, including a long-term study of Striated Caracaras in the Falkland Islands. He is seen above tagging one of his study birds.
column10:
/>

David Barber, Research Biologist and GIS Analyst at Hawk Mountain will place the telemetry units on birds, archive and manage the migration data, and work with others to produce maps of the migration for donors and on the internet. David once counted 7,000 Broadwings passing over Hawk Mountain. He has marked and studied migration in Turkey and Black Vultures throughout North America and assists with studies of Striated Caracaras in Falkland Islands and vultures elsewhere.
column12:
/>

Rebecca McCabe, a Hawk Mountain Graduate Student, will conduct the bulk of field work and data analyses assisted by Keith and Laurie. She will oversee a team of student volunteers from nearby universities in nest searching and observations, and compile findings and weekly reports for donors and for use in her Master's thesis. Rebecca spent last summer observing a Broad-winged Hawk nest at Hawk Mountain and is 'hooked' on learning more about these secretive hawks.

The Purpose
column14: > nests in large, unbroken forests of eastern and central North America. Each autumn they vacate North America and travel thousands of miles to winter in Central and South America. Although highly secretive and rarely seen during nesting, broadwings are conspicuous on

column1: migration, forming impressively large

flocks, numbering thousands of birds. Nearly the entire world's population will pass through eastern Mexico and Central America on their way to southern wintering areas, and all concentrated into a two-week period.
column3:
/>

Because of this amazing concentration and the many different cultures and landscapes they encounter during their journey, broadwings are face multiple threats during migration and on the wintering grounds, including shooting, deforestation, and contaminants. Moreover, despite the abundance of data on migration numbers recorded by hawkwatchers in North America, very little is known about their habitat use, migration, wintering and nesting behavior, and their conservation threats. Such data are critical to the long-term conservation of this iconic migrant and its migration spectacle.

The Broad-winged Hawk Project has three main goals:

column1: • Identify Broad-winged Hawk migration routes and migration behavior in autumn and spring, identify the stop-over and over-wintering sites, overall range, and habitat used during winter.

• Compare nesting behavior, migration patterns and timing of birds from within the same nest and from nests of the same region, including departure and arrival times, distance traveled daily, migration routes, and wintering region.

• With data gathered, publish and publicize results, work with government officials, local residents, and conservation organizations across the regions used by the birds to protect critical migration and wintering habitats.
Hawk Mountain also intends to use the project as a tool to educate
the public on the value and beauty of Broad-winged Hawks and other
long-distance migrants.
column3:
/>

We need to learn more about the Broad-winged Hawk and its ecology during the breeding, migration and wintering periods in order to protect this secretive yet common woodland raptor, and to conserve its amazing migration for future generations. Hawk Mountain follows the guiding principal of its founder Rosalie Edge, who stated: ""The time to save a species is while it is still common.""

Guided by this philosophy, biologists can protect species *before* a population declines and to avert conservation emergencies--which ultimately become difficult and costly to remedy.

The Broad-winged Hawk currently nests throughout northeast and northcentral forests, but faces threats and challenges throughout its life cycle and may be in decline in some regions. By expanding our understanding of this amazing long-distance migrant, we can ensure it continues to fill the skies each autumn and spring.

Project Schedule and Plan:
May through July 2014: Locate two nesting pairs of Broad-winged Hawks in or near Hawk Mountain and conduct daily observations. 

July: Trap the young birds and affix light-weight telemetry units on each juvenile to  track movements after they leave the nest.

August through November: Track four or more juvenile Broad-winged Hawks as they migrate south through North America, Mexico, Central America and possibly South America. Routes and locations will be mapped online and shared with schools and donors.

Winter 2014-2015: The wintering range of each bird will be mapped, and in spring we will follow birds as they return north, assessing where they choose to spend their first winter. Transmitters may last several years so data will be collected and analyzed as long as possible.
column9:
What You Get

Funding for this project would support tagging two juvenile Broad-winged Hawks from one nest, the associated data download fees, and cost of field support and supplies. Two additional Broad-winged Hawks will be tagged using funds already provided by a private donor. If additional funds are located we may tag as many as six juveniles from three nests allowing us to compare behavior between siblings and among nests from same region.

Budget:    

GSM-GPS satellite tracking units...................$4,000 each  x 2 = $8,000

Satellite tracking data downloads...................$1,200 each  x 2 = $2,400

GIS Analyst time migration/winter...................$500/month  x 3 = $1,500

Field Assistant stipend...............................$600.00/month x 2 = $1,200

Field Supplies (trapping, blind, etc.).........................................= $1,100

Travel  (0.40/mile x 1000)........................................................= $   800

Total...................................................................................= $15,000

Hawk Mountain Sanctuary is a non-profit organization with a mission of conserving raptors worldwide. Every dollar donated to this project will directly support this exciting investigation. Hawk Mountain will support the project by providing housing and graduate student stipend, office support, and covering project co-director's salaries.

Supporting a great cause is rewarding on its own, but who doesn't love supporting a cause that provides great perks?!? We have created several project sponsorship levels, all with donor benefits in thanks for their generous contribution. From visits to the world-famous Hawk Mountain Sanctuary, to naming a bird and following it through its life cycle, there are opportunities for everyone. Check out the ""Select a perk"" section on the right-hand side of the page for a full listing of donor levels and benefits.

If the project goal of $15,000 is not met, all funds will be

column1:
applied to cover project costs and other field supplies, although less birds may be marked.

The Impact

Although the Broad-winged Hawk can be observed by the thousands during their migration, little is known about their ecology and conservation needs.  As deforestation continues throughout its range and other potential threats heighten, it is important we understand more about its biology and ecology throughout its life cycle.

Hawk Mountain Sanctuary is well-suited to successfully implement this exciting project. We are a non-profit organization with a mission of conserving raptors worldwide and an 80-year history of successful wildlife conservation and outreach (see www.hawkmountain.org). We manage 2,500 acres of Appalachian forest and host education programs for 70,000 visitors annually. Our successful international conservation science trainee program boasts more than 300 graduates across the world, who in turn offer global collaboration for the outreach component of this project. We have former trainees in nearly every country traversed by broadwings. In the past decade, we have tracked Black and Turkey Vultures across similar landscapes and shared data through online and print publications.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us reach our goal by sharing this link with friends, family and fellow conservationists or bird lovers!   Help us to spread the word!

It might seem like an uninspired chapter of a dull script on economic recovery, but the latest move for the solution of Greek crisis is based on the privatization of its beaches and the ability to widely construct on its shores with very few regulations.

In other words, this might be the last summer when the unique and largely unspoiled shores of Greece can be freely enjoyed!


Help us to produce this viral video by contributing and become a producer  in order to raise more awareness and stop this catastrophe .


We are two Greek filmmakers, based in Barcelona with a trajectory in video art, fiction film, creative documentary, advertisement, viral video marketing and corporate video in Greece, Europe and beyond. We use cinematic language to communicate a wide range of messages of social and political context at a growing and expanding audience.


------THE BILL


Right now the Greek government is preparingthe second version of a bill to sell off public beaches to private companies. According to this bill, Greece will be left with cemented, overdeveloped beaches and access will only be allowed to those who can afford it.


In its current form the draft law would allow unrestricted exploitation of what is widely regarded as one of the most unspoiled coastlines on the continent of Europe: simplifying building permits for beachside hotels
column2:
allowing businesses to pay fines to legalize buildings deemed illicit and permitting vendors to litter shorelines with umbrellas and sunbeds. Free access to public beaches, a right enshrined in the Greek constitution and mentality, would also be severely limited.

Finally, the rich but vulnerable biodiversity of the coastal areas is at risk with this bill as it could convert protected areas into lots for sale and constitutes a violation of natural resources with serious environmental consequences.


-----THE CAMPAIGN


When the bill was proposed there was a first successful movement against it based on petitions and awareness actions that managed to freeze the bill, but not scrap it altogether. Knowing that many governments use the period of summer to pass laws in an unperceivable way, we realized it is our turn to act as conscious citizens. We feel the urge to use our craft to widen and enhance these actions with the means we have at hand. For this reason we plan to create a viral video of compelling content and cutting edge visual strength.


-------VIDEO SHORT DESCRIPTION


Our idea is to collaborate with sand castle artists in order to create a time-lapse video of 2’ starting from present time and getting to the image of the future to come according to this law implementation, and propose active ways to prevent it. The main reason we need your funding is to be able to pay everyone properly and do this project in the most professional environment possible.


Synopsis:

We see the view of the sea and the horizon from a very low angle shot while we are listening a soothing breeze and soft see waves while in the very background some children playing with the water. A time-lapse begins of monstrous urban buildings, growing and crowding out the view to the sea. While the shot is filled with sand skyline, the sound fades to heavy construction and industrial scapes. When the skyline has filled the horizon a crowd of shoeless feet comes into shot demolishing the building and running care freely towards the sea. The sound of the sea and children returns, recuperated. The video finishes off with relevant text and a voice-over (in as many languages as we can).


Let´s join our voices to preserve this word natural heritage for the generations to come.


Production:

In Barcelona, where we live, there are sandcastle artists who construct entire miniature castles, cities and dragons. We need to collaborate with them in order to get a professional and impactful result to the video. Also, it is necessary that we do the shooting outside Barcelona in a beach nearby because there is high risk of civil problematics (fines) that stop our creative process. Moreover the sand of Barcelona´s city beach is artificial and not natural sand, making the work of the sand artists really difficult. Thus we will go further away on a beach outside the city. The artists believe that they could do it in one day apart from any unpredictable factors that has to do with sand castles (E.g.: a part of it falls and you have to do it all over again).

Timescale:

1/2 days of shooting

5 days of post production (image, sound, special effects, color correction)


Crew:

Director: Despina Ikonomopoulou

Assistant Director: Alessandro Di Renzo

Director of Photography: Philippos Vardakas

Producer: Juan Pablo Loyola

Sand Artists: Ilia, Nino, Jasan


Production Costs:

Transport: 30€

Food: 80€

Shooting Material (Camera, Lenses, Tripod and Grip): 200€

Director: 250€

Assistant Director: 200€

Director of Photography: 200€

Producer: 200€

Sand Artists: 150€

Editor: 300€

Special Effects: 150€

Sound Design: 150€

Extra fees (campaign costs, office costs, paperwork): 200€

Total: 2000€

  • If we do not reach our entire goal , our plan is to reduce main crew members and fees (Assistant Director and post production roles).The main intent is not to affect the fees of the sand artists and the external collaborators. In case we raise more money than our original goal , the rest of the money will become a donation to the organization MOm (The Hellenic Society for the Study and Protection of the Monk seal), a Greek non–governmental environmental organization with the legal status of a Non–profit association.
column3:
LANG=EN"" rel=""noopener nofollow"">http://www.mom.gr/

The Impact

Know  the difference YOUR contribution will make:

column1: • By contributing you will help us achieve a massive rise of awareness in a global level and help us stop this law to be implemented, thus preserving the Greek shores and enjoy their ‘virginity’.
• The mobilization of citizens will help to achieve the immediate withdrawal of the Ministry of Finance bill on the shoreline, preventing the destruction of Greek sea coasts
• By creating this video we will raise global awareness and help to protect the natural beauty of Greece for the next generations.
• It’s not only about our right to freely use the beach
column2: it’s about the intrinsic value of our natural environment, about the Greek landscape as an integral part of our identity and of a global point of reference of ´natural paradise´.

column1: • Illegal buildings, litter, and other abuses are sure some of the problems of the Greek sea shore that require strategic thinking and coordinated action. With the proposed legislation, the government purports to bring order to the chaos of current seashore policy. Instead, it invites immediate environmental disaster and undermines the medium-term prospects of the tourism sector itself.

• Stupidity is probably not too strong a word for this exercise in selling out Greece’s long-term advantage (it’s unique and largely unspoiled coastline) in the service of short-term targets cooked up by European and IMF technocrats whose deficiencies and narrow-mindedness are apparent to anyone who has visited a Greek unemployment office.

• Vangelis Paravas, president of the Hellenic Society for the Study and Protection of the Monk Seal (MOm) mentioned the still excellent condition of the natural environment in Greece, especially the coastline, where at least 50% of the world population of the critically endangered and threatened with extinction Mediterranean monk seal has found refuge. In other countries, especially in the western Mediterranean coasts, the species has become already extinct, due also to unregulated coastal development and destruction of its terrestrial habitat. Unfortunately the extensive construction activities aiming at the full exploitation and touristic development of the coastal Mediterranean zone has been one of the major factors during the second half of the 20th century, which significantly degraded the natural environment and the shorelines of the westerns Mediterranean basin.


But we have a chance to prevent this monstrosity before it's too late.

TWO NEW COLLABORATIONS have teamed with us in the campaign:

- MEDASSET (Mediterranean Association to Save the Sea Turtles), an international nonprofit organization working to protect marine and coastal habitats in the Mediterranean, with sea turtles as their flagship species. MEDASSET has offered to contribute to the perks, more info will be posted soon.  

http://www.medasset.org/en/

- Milk Audio Greece (award winning audio post production house based in Greece) through Alexandros Sidiropoulos has offered us to make the full sound design and mix of the video. Their collaboration is of huge importance to the quality of the final video. Thank you! Milkaudio becomes therefore Executive Producers with their collaboration!

http://www.milkaudio.co.uk/

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, doesn't mean you can't help:

column1: • Get the word out and make some noise about the campaign.
• Use the Indiegogo share tools!

","It might seem like an uninspired chapter of a dull script on economic recovery, but the latest move for the solution of Greek crisis is based on the privatization of its beaches and the ability to widely construct on its shores with very few regulations.In other words, this might be the last summer when the unique and largely unspoiled shores of Greece can be freely enjoyed!Help us to produce this viral video by contributing and become a producer  in order to raise more awareness and stop this catastrophe .We are two Greek filmmakers, based in Barcelona with a trajectory in video art, fiction film, creative documentary, advertisement, viral video marketing and corporate video in Greece, Europe and beyond. We use cinematic language to communicate a wide range of messages of social and political context at a growing and expanding audience.------THE BILLRight now the Greek government is preparingthe second version of a bill to sell off public beaches to private companies. According to this bill, Greece will be left with cemented, overdeveloped beaches and access will only be allowed to those who can afford it.In its current form the draft law would allow unrestricted exploitation of what is widely regarded as one of the most unspoiled coastlines on the continent of Europe: simplifying building permits for beachside hotels
column2: allowing businesses to pay fines to legalize buildings deemed illicit and permitting vendors to litter shorelines with umbrellas and sunbeds. Free access to public beaches, a right enshrined in the Greek constitution and mentality, would also be severely limited.Finally, the rich but vulnerable biodiversity of the coastal areas is at risk with this bill as it could convert protected areas into lots for sale and constitutes a violation of natural resources with serious environmental consequences.-----THE CAMPAIGN When the bill was proposed there was a first successful movement against it based on petitions and awareness actions that managed to freeze the bill, but not scrap it altogether. Knowing that many governments use the period of summer to pass laws in an unperceivable way, we realized it is our turn to act as conscious citizens. We feel the urge to use our craft to widen and enhance these actions with the means we have at hand. For this reason we plan to create a viral video of compelling content and cutting edge visual strength. -------VIDEO SHORT DESCRIPTIONOur idea is to collaborate with sand castle artists in order to create a time-lapse video of 2’ starting from present time and getting to the image of the future to come according to this law implementation, and propose active ways to prevent it. The main reason we need your funding is to be able to pay everyone properly and do this project in the most professional environment possible.Synopsis:We see the view of the sea and the horizon from a very low angle shot while we are listening a soothing breeze and soft see waves while in the very background some children playing with the water. A time-lapse begins of monstrous urban buildings, growing and crowding out the view to the sea. While the shot is filled with sand skyline, the sound fades to heavy construction and industrial scapes. When the skyline has filled the horizon a crowd of shoeless feet comes into shot demolishing the building and running care freely towards the sea. The sound of the sea and children returns, recuperated. The video finishes off with relevant text and a voice-over (in as many languages as we can).Let´s join our voices to preserve this word natural heritage for the generations to come.Production:In Barcelona, where we live, there are sandcastle artists who construct entire miniature castles, cities and dragons. We need to collaborate with them in order to get a professional and impactful result to the video. Also, it is necessary that we do the shooting outside Barcelona in a beach nearby because there is high risk of civil problematics (fines) that stop our creative process. Moreover the sand of Barcelona´s city beach is artificial and not natural sand, making the work of the sand artists really difficult. Thus we will go further away on a beach outside the city. The artists believe that they could do it in one day apart from any unpredictable factors that has to do with sand castles (E.g.: a part of it falls and you have to do it all over again).Timescale:1/2 days of shooting5 days of post production (image, sound, special effects, color correction)Crew:Director: Despina IkonomopoulouAssistant Director: Alessandro Di RenzoDirector of Photography: Philippos VardakasProducer: Juan Pablo LoyolaSand Artists: Ilia, Nino, JasanProduction Costs:Transport: 30€Food: 80€Shooting Material (Camera, Lenses, Tripod and Grip): 200€Director: 250€Assistant Director: 200€Director of Photography: 200€Producer: 200€Sand Artists: 150€Editor: 300€Special Effects: 150€Sound Design: 150€Extra fees (campaign costs, office costs, paperwork): 200€Total: 2000€If we do not reach our entire goal , our plan is to reduce main crew members and fees (Assistant Director and post production roles).The main intent is not to affect the fees of the sand artists and the external collaborators. In case we raise more money than our original goal , the rest of the money will become a donation to the organization MOm (The Hellenic Society for the Study and Protection of the Monk seal), a Greek non–governmental environmental organization with the legal status of a Non–profit association. http://www.mom.gr/The ImpactKnow  the difference YOUR contribution will make:

column1: By contributing you will help us achieve a massive rise of awareness in a global level and help us stop this law to be implemented, thus preserving the Greek shores and enjoy their ‘virginity’.
The mobilization of citizens will help to achieve the immediate withdrawal of the Ministry of Finance bill on the shoreline, preventing the destruction of Greek sea coasts
By creating this video we will raise global awareness and help to protect the natural beauty of Greece for the next generations.
It’s not only about our right to freely use the beach
column2: it’s about the intrinsic value of our natural environment, about the Greek landscape as an integral part of our identity and of a global point of reference of ´natural paradise´.

<td valign=""top"" width=""57%"">
I am Germán Rubio Luna, Colombian Mechanical Engineer, from the ""Indiana Institute of Technology"" (EU), and specialized in the U.S., Canada, Mexico, Belgium, Switzerland and Germany.
Exercising my career as an Engeneer, I have developed several producs of my own design. More than 20 of them are patented in diverse countries, like Colombia, Nicaragua,
Brazil, Chile, Argentina, Spain, England and Australia.
</tr>
<tr>
I am a founding member of the ""Colombian Bamboo Society"" and I
have had the opportunity of presenting my experiences in various national and international meetings
and conferences on Bamboo.
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan=""3"">

After more than 55 years of experience in mechanical engineering, I wrote the Guide ""Arte y mañas de la Guadua"" (Art and Tips of Bamboo Guadua I, ""A guide to the productive use of a giant bamboo"") in 2008 and finished one new book titled: Art and Tips of Bamboo Guadua II, ""Other uses to everyone. Seats and Re-engineering in construction"".

These two books are written in Spanish. If we could just publish this in English, hundreds of people, especially the ones in the poorest countries, will be able to benefit from this knowledge. However, due to my advanced age (I will be 84 in December) I do not have the time or energy to translate these books to English.
With the funds raised we can hire a professional translator.

With your help, ""Pre buying"" one or more copies of these books, we can translate these two books to English (more than 111,998 words and over 1400 Illustration), with the new services: print on demand (POD) we can reach everyone at very low costs.
Bamboo-Guadua
is an extremely cheap but also extremely resistant construction material. With
the translation of these books, to a globalized language as English is, the
less advantaged in South America, Africa, Asia, etc., will be able to learn how
to build earthquake resistant homes and diverse products for their own use, and

to create their own artisan industry, and thus increase their income.

With any of these books, you will learn step by step, in a very didactic and even fun way, to make more than 400 crafts, toys, tools, furniture and even buildings. In addition, the book teaches you how to start your own specialized micro industry (agricultural structure buildings, items for florists, making bamboo furniture, and many more).

If you belong to a Bamboo Association, we have very favorable rewards for your association: Books in English or Spanish, including the logo and details of your Bamboo Association in the book, and if the number of books prepurchased exceeds 200, we could include a special chapter regarding your association or company and its activities, achievements, and so on (you send us the text). As a Thanksgiving or Christmas gift, it will highlight the name of your association or company.
</tr>

</tr>

column5: >CROWN OF THE CONTINENT: THE WILDEST ROCKIES

column1: <b>BOOK | MULTI-MEDIA LECTURES |
CONSERVATION OUTREACH
The Rocky Mountains run for 250 miles between western
Montana and Alberta, Canada, in a special place called the Crown of the
Continent.  Rising up at its crest is the
Continental Divide, and its centerpiece is Waterton-Glacier International Peace
Park, a union of Canada’s Waterton Lakes National Park and Glacier National
Park in the United States. All told, the Crown holds 18 million acres of
unparalleled wild beauty. Known to Native Americans as “The Backbone of the
World,” it is one of the most intact ecosystems remaining in North America, one
that boasts a successful and inspiring history of conservation.
Crown of the Continent: The Wildest Rockies explores the
surprising connections between culture, history, communities, and the great
outdoors in one of the world’s most majestic regions.
The project will include a large-format photography book, multi-media lectures, and outreach
through conservation advocacy groups working in the area.
PROJECT GOAL: Showcase
the natural and cultural value of the Crown of the Continent region, inspiring
people in the region and beyond to take action to sustain healthy wildlands,
wildlife, and human communities together.

column3:
>Winter Sunset, Steven Gnam

We have already raised enough funding to publish the book,

column1:
which will be available in early May for $29.95. (Wahoo!)

// UPDATE // Check out a digital preview of the book!! >
Now, we need funding
for an outreach tour this summer and fall. The outreach tour is a critical part
of the project, bringing these unique images and stories to a wider audience.
Events will feature project photographer Steven Gnam sharing
an interactive, multimedia presentation with audiences ranging from 80-300.
Contributor Douglas Chadwick, wildlife biologist and acclaimed author, will
join Steven at several events. We will also leverage the events to gain media
coverage in each city, expanding the reach to millions.

column2:
>
Steven in the field, Steven Gnam

column1:
Our Team

Photographer Steven Gnam takes us into the very
heart and soul of the wildest Rockies. Having explored the area since he was a
young child, he’s traveled by foot,
ski, crampon, and bike—even at times snorkeling alongside trout under
bone-chilling water—across thousands of miles to showcase the wild spirit of
one of the last vestiges of the North American west.  Steven’s photographs have been used by
conservation organizations across the west, including the Nature Conservancy,
NPCA, and the Montana Wilderness Association. His work has been featured by
commercial and editorial clients, such as Patagonia, Backpacker Magazine,
National Parks, and Montana Outdoors. Steven lives with his wife, Alyson, in
the Pacific Northwest.
Wildlife biologist Douglas H. Chadwick has
traveled the globe reporting on wildlife and conservation, from the Congo
headwaters to Siberia to the Great Barrier Reef. He is the critically acclaimed
author of The Fate of the Elephant, A Beast the Color of Winter, and True
Grizz, as well as The Company We Keep: America’s Endangered Species
and Enduring America. Over two hundred of his articles have appeared
in such publications as National Geographic, to which he is a
frequent contributor, Audubon, Defenders of Wildlife, and Smithsonian
Magazine. A longtime conservationist, Chadwick spent seven years studying
mountain goats and other wildlife in Montana’s Bob Marshall Wilderness and
Glacier National Park. He lives with his family in northwestern Montana. He
contributes an essay on the area’s astonishing biodiversity and close proximity
to vibrant communities, and will join Steven to present at several events.
Longtime Missoulian journalist and now Crown of the
Continent program manager for National Parks Conservation Association Michael Jamison outlines the human
history in the Crown and the progress made that preserves both landscape and
livelihood.
Dylan Boyle, of
the Crown of the Continent Geotourism Council, contributes tips for visiting
ten natural and cultural sites within the region.
Karsten Heuer,
executive director of Yellowstone to Yukon Conservation Initiative, provides an
epilogue that encourages conservation and lends a personal voice to the
Canadian region of the Crown.
Publisher: Braided
River, the conservation imprint of Mountaineers Books, combines photography
and writing to bring a fresh perspective to key environmental issues facing
western North America’s wildest places. Crown of the Continent will be our
twelfth project to date. Our projects reach beyond the printed page as we take
these distinctive voices and vision to a wider audience through lectures,
exhibits, and multimedia events. Our goal is to build public support for
maintaining healthy wildlands, wildlife, and human communities together.

column2:
>
Autumn leaves, Steven Gnam

Why We Do Events and

column1: What It Takes
If you’ve ever thrown a party, you know that hosting an
event can be time-consuming and expensive. Sometimes you wonder if all the
effort is worth it, right? But inevitably you will throw another party. <u>Because
getting people together and sharing something you have in common is really rewarding.</u>  These shared experiences give us lasting
memories that make all the hassles worth it. Even if you do have to clean-up
afterwards.
Here at Braided River, we work hard to coordinate events
that change perspectives. We lure folks in with beautiful photos and
interesting stories
column2: we send them home ready to become stewards working to

column1: protect the landscape they’ve just travelled across through the presentation.
To create Crown of
the Continent, we had an incredibly talented and hard-working team, and the
final product is an exquisite call to action to protect this special wild place.
(The Crown is home to more than 1,000 native plants, 70 mammals, and 260
species of birds!) You can help us make sure that plenty of people hear this
call, and respond to it!
Planning the events and coordinating with our partners takes
time, roughly $500 and $1,000 in staff time per event. Then there are the venue
rental expenses which range from $250 to $1,000+. Earning strong media coverage
and creating publicity materials takes more time (there’s another $1,000.) And,
then you have to get there
column2: depending on where the event is and where our

column1: authors happen to be and how many will attend this runs another to $250 to
So, you see, hosting a great public outreach event typically
runs us between $3, 500 and $5,000. And, it’s worth every penny when we send
400+ plus people home all geared up to protect wildlands and reach thousands
more through media coverage of the event.
Our Goals
Here are the events we hope to host this year and next:
<li>
<span style=""line-height: 1.45em
column2: >4 regional events in Seattle, Montana, and Canada

column1: with the photographer and an author in 2014
<li>
<span style=""line-height: 1.45em
column2: >2 regional events in  Montana and/or Canada with the photographer

column1: and an author in 2015
<li>
<span style=""line-height: 1.45em
column2: >2 national events with the photographer and an author

column1: in 2015
<li>
<span style=""line-height: 1.45em
events with the Photographer in 2015
Our goal is to raise $5,000 through this campaign, which we
can use alongside gifts from foundations, sponsorships, major gifts, and ticket
sales to make this event series happen. If we raise more, we could host more
events and reduce or eliminate ticket prices.
Bottom line, the more
we raise, the more events we can host. And, more people hearing these stories
and seeing these images = more people acting to save the Crown!

column3:
>Sleeping grizzly, Steven Gnam

We need YOUR support

column1: to make these events happen. Help us tell the story of this magnificent wild
place so that it will be there for the next generation. You can make a
difference for the Crown of the Continent today!
Thank you in advance for supporting this campaign,
Steven Gnam
Douglas Chadwick
Michael Jamison
Dylan Boyle
Karsten Heuer

Braided River staff and board

P.S. In addition to the perks listed, all crowdfunders will be invited to attend an exclusive pre-launch-party-party in Whitefish, MT!

author of The Fate of the Elephant, A Beast the Color of Winter, and True
Grizz, as well as The Company We Keep: America’s Endangered Species
and Enduring America. Over two hundred of his articles have appeared
in such publications as National Geographic, to which he is a
frequent contributor, Audubon, Defenders of Wildlife, and Smithsonian
Magazine. A longtime conservationist, Chadwick spent seven years studying
mountain goats and other wildlife in Montana’s Bob Marshall Wilderness and
Glacier National Park. He lives with his family in northwestern Montana. He
contributes an essay on the area’s astonishing biodiversity and close proximity
to vibrant communities, and will join Steven to present at several events.
Longtime Missoulian journalist and now Crown of the
Continent program manager for National Parks Conservation Association Michael Jamison outlines the human
history in the Crown and the progress made that preserves both landscape and
livelihood.
Dylan Boyle, of
the Crown of the Continent Geotourism Council, contributes tips for visiting
ten natural and cultural sites within the region.
Karsten Heuer,
executive director of Yellowstone to Yukon Conservation Initiative, provides an
epilogue that encourages conservation and lends a personal voice to the
Canadian region of the Crown.
Publisher: Braided
River, the conservation imprint of Mountaineers Books, combines photography
and writing to bring a fresh perspective to key environmental issues facing
western North America’s wildest places. Crown of the Continent will be our
twelfth project to date. Our projects reach beyond the printed page as we take
these distinctive voices and vision to a wider audience through lectures,
exhibits, and multimedia events. Our goal is to build public support for
maintaining healthy wildlands, wildlife, and human communities together.
Autumn leaves, Steven GnamWhy We Do Events and
What It Takes
If you’ve ever thrown a party, you know that hosting an
event can be time-consuming and expensive. Sometimes you wonder if all the
effort is worth it, right? But inevitably you will throw another party. Because
getting people together and sharing something you have in common is really rewarding.  These shared experiences give us lasting
memories that make all the hassles worth it. Even if you do have to clean-up
afterwards.
Here at Braided River, we work hard to coordinate events
that change perspectives. We lure folks in with beautiful photos and
interesting stories
column2: we send them home ready to become stewards working to

column1: protect the landscape they’ve just travelled across through the presentation.
To create Crown of
the Continent, we had an incredibly talented and hard-working team, and the
final product is an exquisite call to action to protect this special wild place.
(The Crown is home to more than 1,000 native plants, 70 mammals, and 260
species of birds!) You can help us make sure that plenty of people hear this
call, and respond to it!
Planning the events and coordinating with our partners takes
time, roughly $500 and $1,000 in staff time per event. Then there are the venue
rental expenses which range from $250 to $1,000+. Earning strong media coverage
and creating publicity materials takes more time (there’s another $1,000.) And,
then you have to get there
column2: depending on where the event is and where our

column1: authors happen to be and how many will attend this runs another to $250 to
So, you see, hosting a great public outreach event typically
runs us between $3, 500 and $5,000. And, it’s worth every penny when we send
400+ plus people home all geared up to protect wildlands and reach thousands
more through media coverage of the event.
Yellow-headed blackbird, Steven Gnam
Our Goals
Here are the events we hope to host this year and next:
4 regional events in Seattle, Montana, and Canada
with the photographer and an author in 2014
2 regional events in  Montana and/or Canada with the photographer
and an author in 2015
2 national events with the photographer and an author
2 national
events with the Photographer in 2015
Our goal is to raise $5,000 through this campaign, which we
can use alongside gifts from foundations, sponsorships, major gifts, and ticket
sales to make this event series happen. If we raise more, we could host more
events and reduce or eliminate ticket prices.
Bottom line, the more
we raise, the more events we can host. And, more people hearing these stories
and seeing these images = more people acting to save the Crown!
Sleeping grizzly, Steven GnamWe need YOUR support
to make these events happen. Help us tell the story of this magnificent wild
place so that it will be there for the next generation. You can make a
difference for the Crown of the Continent today!
Thank you in advance for supporting this campaign,
Steven Gnam
Douglas Chadwick
Michael Jamison
Dylan Boyle
Karsten Heuer
Braided River staff and boardP.S. In addition to the perks listed, all crowdfunders will be invited to attend an exclusive pre-launch-party-party in Whitefish, MT!",6.0,0,"1 Campaign

We are the people of North End Barra in Gambia and parts of our coastline has  a lot of rubbish . We have built a  lovely centre for  tourists and the local people to use but the surrounding area is used daily as the place to throw rubbish and rubbish is brought in from the sea too. There is no rubbish system in the village and we want to start one that will inspire the other sections of the village to start theirs too and turn our village into a place to be proud of.
This project is lead  by Sini N'joba, local children and youth from Barra Gambia and Deasy Bamford , from the UK. We have  built ""The Black Cow  Centre"" over the past 20 years. We have cleaned the beach right outside our centre, but the tide of rubbish is constant and we know that we need to instigate a system.This will help people have a place other than the beach to throw thier rubbish, build dumping places ,hire a lorry to come reguarly to take the rubbish to the local landfill and start to create opportunities for recycling  jobs, with metal and plastic.
 
This will transform our area and make it somewhere for the local children to safely play, for local people to enjoy the beauty of thier natural surroundings,and give a boost to our visitors from other parts of West Africa and Europe.
 
The idea is to make this a self sustaining project which will be able to continue after the initial outlay and we hope to make it such a success that the other areas in the village will start thier own systems and the village council will make it a permanent part of the way the village is looked after.

 With your help we can start a rubbish revolution , that will have a lasting effect on this village and will spread to other villages too .
Our side of the river, and indeed most of Gambia has not got rubbish system and  people have got used to living with an unnacceptable  state of rubbish management  ( ie no management) for too long , help us change this  forever .



What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

The initial clean sweep of up to half a mile of coast line  10 people for 4 days  £200

and removal of  about 5 tonnes of rubbish . 4 trips £80 per trip                         £320 

 The building of 4 main dumping places  with plastic bottle filled bricks, wire netting  and wood creating an easy to use cage . labour and  materials                        £200

Monthly Collections with a lorry  to take to the  nearest landfill

15 miles away £80  x12                                                                                      £960

Working with 2 local people to separate the metal and recyclable plastic

and selling it to start a business  that presses plastic

  to create bricks for building  etc .               2 x £30 x 12 months                       £720

Total needed for the year                                                                                  £2400

We hope to make income obver the year from selling the  waste we can , that will contribute towards the monthly collections in the future and build a business case with the village so  that they will contribute the rest .

We can share our happiness with you and  send you perks of lovely photographs and cards taken of the beach and local events such as  the sports day we held on the newly cleaned section outside our centre .  

 These images will brighten your walls  and help us to brighten our lives too .

 If we dont make the full amount of money we will scale down our ambitions to  a quarter of a mile but still initiate the system .

 Tackling rubbish  can seem like an insumountable  problem for poor communities and this project will help us to show that a lot can be done with some organisation and  some initial funding , and that this  can last for a lifetime. Children will grow up  recognising that they CAN live in a rubbish free environment, that some rubbish can be useful and even lead to a livleihod, in an area of so little employment this is vital.

Also we hope to introduce courses and workshops that show how once the rubbish is in manageable places , all sort of ideas can be  implemented, from energy production to making toys or cheap stoves .

 One day we would like to start an art project wirth the local school using the washed up rubbish  further along the coast  to  inspire  ingenuity and creativity, but first we want to clean up our doorstep.

 We have been working in the area for many years and have managed to create  festivals and events that have brought  different  local and international cultures together to celebrate life  and inspire young people to make a difference in thier lives.

Other Ways You Can Help

spread the word and send this link to people  who you think would be up for contributing something to make this happen. Use the  indiegogo share tools.

Like our facebook page  and  come and visit us if you are in The Gambia
