column1: ","MISSION
The mission of ZUVUYA is to offer a sensory, multi-media experience focused on reconnecting us to our ocean home and to inspire stewardship and healing for the oceans and ourselves.
VISION

The vision of ZUVUYA is to merge science and art to increase awareness that the health of the ocean is critical to all life on earth, to inspire action to protect and sustain the ocean for future generations, and to catalyze community members to launch regional ocean initiatives.      www.zuvuyaproject.com
Photo of OCEAN Installation Kona Hawaii 2014
http://westhawaiitoday.com/news/local-news/underwater-understanding-multimedia-art-installation-increases-ocean-awareness
Zuvuya is the Mayan word for the circuit by which everything returns to its source, connecting memory to the future as well as the past.
WHO WE ARE
We are a group of renowned international artists and scientists collaborating to increase awareness that the health of the ocean is
critical to all life on earth through bringing the beautiful and awe-inspiring sculpture installation OCEAN to seven locations on the Pacific Rim.
Our project is a call for action to protect and sustain the
ocean for future generations. Contributions will help launch ZUVUYA on its Pacific Rim
Tour 2014 to inspire local citizen ocean-protection
initiatives.
THE ART: OCEAN LIVING SCULPTURE

A total immersion experience, OCEAN is comprised of huge sails stretching from floor to ceiling creating multi-layered shapes that surround viewers on all sides and overhead. Projected on the sails are Lisa Denning's extraordinary film images of whales and dolphins with Susan Alexjander's haunting bio-acoustic soundtrack of rare marine-life voices.
THE SCIENCE & EDUCATION
Exhibits from each Pacific Rim location will accompany the installation. They will showcase the cultural relationships of each region, and their particular environmental challenges.
Thaïs Mazur,  PhD Project/Artistic Director
Susan Alexjander,  Composer
Lisa Denning,  Ocean Filmmaker/Photographer
Michael Stocker,  Executive Director of OCR
Wallace J Nichols,  PhD Ocean Scientist
DL Marrin, PhD  Water Scientist
We need $5,000 to purchase the exhibit and sculptural installation
materials for the centerpiece of this tour: the inspiring sculpture, OCEAN, and support the marketing efforts and outreach to the Pacific Rim nations.",8.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Mendocino, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/zuvuya-reconnecting-to-our-ocean-home/pica

column1: Christian Geels.  I am an artist, writer and lover of nature.  I have
given myself the blessing of an extensive education.  I most recently
completed a graduate degree in international environmental policy at the
Monterey Institute of International Studies in 2011.  During my studies I
focused on ocean policy and marine protected areas.
on the occasion of my 40th birthday, I received an invitation to assist the Hui
Ho'olana Center with a reforestation project located on the Hawaiian island of
Moloka'i.  I ask your help to make my dream of assisting on this project a
reality.  By helping me you will help the Hui Ho'olana's ongoing efforts
to restore the native plant life to the island of Moloka'i and thereby enhance
the preservation of indigenous Hawaiian culture.

residential learning intensive facilitated by my mentor Dr. Pamela
Colorado.  Dr. Colorado is founder of the Worldwide Indigenous Science Network.

just an important Pacific Ocean island ecosystem but a culture whose history
and traditions have touched the lives of countless people throughout the
world.  Here is an explanation of
the spirit of Aloha that resonates with my own experience:
of all, and all being a part of me. When there is pain - it is my pain. When
there is joy - it is also mine. I respect all that is as part of the Creator
and part of me. I will not willfully harm anyone or anything. When food is
needed I will take only my need and explain why it is being taken. The earth,
the sky, the sea are mine to care for, to cherish and to protect. This is
Hawaiian - this is Aloha!

","My name is Bernd
Christian Geels.  I am an artist, writer and lover of nature.  I have
given myself the blessing of an extensive education.  I most recently
completed a graduate degree in international environmental policy at the
Monterey Institute of International Studies in 2011.  During my studies I
focused on ocean policy and marine protected areas.
On September 14, 2013,
on the occasion of my 40th birthday, I received an invitation to assist the Hui
Ho'olana Center with a reforestation project located on the Hawaiian island of
Moloka'i.  I ask your help to make my dream of assisting on this project a
reality.  By helping me you will help the Hui Ho'olana's ongoing efforts
to restore the native plant life to the island of Moloka'i and thereby enhance
the preservation of indigenous Hawaiian culture.
I first journeyed to the
Hawaiian island of Maui in November, 2003.  At the time I was a student of Naropa University.  I traveled to Maui to participate in a
residential learning intensive facilitated by my mentor Dr. Pamela
Colorado.  Dr. Colorado is founder of the Worldwide Indigenous Science Network.
I need to raise
approximately $2000.00 (by the end of September) to pay for my
travel expenses and fund any miscellaneous supplies I may need while on the
island of Moloka'i.  I am willing to refund the money to my contributors
if I do not reach my goal.
Here is a description
of the project:
I will assist in the
Hui Ho’olana’s ongoing reintroduction of native plants to the island.  Reintroducing
native species is more than a matter of simply restoring the ecology of a
place.  As noted on the Hui website Hawaiian culture is intimately
intertwined with its flora and fauna.  Plants were used for a variety of
purposes including canoe and house building, dyeing and traditional medicine.  To
protect and restore a culture one must protect and nourish its valued plants
and animals and the land on which they depend.
My project will consist mainly of
the following tasks:
§  +  Seed tray
preparation and planting
§  +  Transplanting
seedlings into pots and transplant bags
§  +  Field clearing
§  +  Out-planting
of seedlings into designated planting areas
§  +  Assist with
tool management and other related tasks as needed
My particular role will be approximately one month long, from October 3rd to November 1st.
By helping me give my time and
heartful energy to this project you will contribute to the preservation of not
just an important Pacific Ocean island ecosystem but a culture whose history
and traditions have touched the lives of countless people throughout the
world.  Here is an explanation of
the spirit of Aloha that resonates with my own experience:
Aloha is being a part
of all, and all being a part of me. When there is pain - it is my pain. When
there is joy - it is also mine. I respect all that is as part of the Creator
and part of me. I will not willfully harm anyone or anything. When food is
needed I will take only my need and explain why it is being taken. The earth,
the sky, the sea are mine to care for, to cherish and to protect. This is
Hawaiian - this is Aloha!
- www.huna.org
If you
are are unable to contribute to my campaign but nonetheless feel passionate
interest in this work please consider sharing my story and fundraising request
with like minded and ""like-hearted"" people.  I realize I am
making my fundraising request with little notice
as quickly as I can.
Thank
you so much for your consideration!
Aloha!
Bernd",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns
|","Minneapolis, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/restoring-the-plant-life-of-moloka-i-island/pica

Hello

We are the Horn-Danino family,

Hanoch, Yael and Amots.

Two years ago we started building our dream- an ecofriendly life on our own piece of land.

We bought and old bus from a scrap yard in order to transform it into our home,

Amots, our baby joined us 6 months ago and brought in many joy and light into our lives. But along all the blessings also a few difficulties in fulfilling our project.

we wish to finish the inner modeling and continue bringing our dream to life.

We kindly ask your support in the building project.

we would love it if you would look around our facebook page and bring up ideas on how to remodel and tackle the challenges ahead.

לפני שנתיים התחלנו בהגשמת חלום.

חיי קיימות על פיסת אדמה שלנו.

קנינו אוטובוס ממגרש גרוטאות כדי להסב אותו למגורים.

אמוץ, התינוק שלנו, הצטרף אלינו לפני חצי שנה, הוא הכניס הרבה אור ושמחה לחיים שלנו אבל יחד איתו , קשיים בהשלמת הפרויקט.

אנחנו רוצים לסיים את השיפוץ הפנימי ולהמשיך לרקום את החלום.

אנו מבקשים את תמיכתכם בפרויקט השיפוץ.

נשמח אם תשוטטו בפייסבוק של האוטובוס ותתנו לנו רעיונות לשיפוצים ופתרונות לבעיות שבדרך.

המטרה היא שהחורף הבא יהיה חם.

מבטיחים לארח אתכם אצלנו.

חנוך, יעל ואמוץ

","Hello We are the Horn-Danino family, Hanoch, Yael and Amots. Two years ago we started building our dream- an ecofriendly life on our own piece of land. We bought and old bus from a scrap yard in order to transform it into our home, Amots, our baby joined us 6 months ago and brought in many joy and light into our lives. But along all the blessings also a few difficulties in fulfilling our project. we wish to finish the inner modeling and continue bringing our dream to life.We kindly ask your support in the building project. we would love it if you would look around our facebook page and bring up ideas on how to remodel and tackle the challenges ahead.https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=1000096... the goal is to make it through next winter nice and worm. promise to have you over at our dream home. Hanoch, Yael and little Amotsשלוםאנחנו משפחת הורן דנינוחנוך, יעל ואמוץ.לפני שנתיים התחלנו בהגשמת חלום.חיי קיימות על פיסת אדמה שלנו.קנינו אוטובוס ממגרש גרוטאות כדי להסב אותו למגורים.אמוץ, התינוק שלנו, הצטרף אלינו לפני חצי שנה, הוא הכניס הרבה אור ושמחה לחיים שלנו אבל יחד איתו , קשיים בהשלמת הפרויקט.אנחנו רוצים לסיים את השיפוץ הפנימי ולהמשיך לרקום את החלום.אנו מבקשים את תמיכתכם בפרויקט השיפוץ.נשמח אם תשוטטו בפייסבוק של האוטובוס ותתנו לנו רעיונות לשיפוצים ופתרונות לבעיות שבדרך.https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=1000096...המטרה היא שהחורף הבא יהיה חם.מבטיחים לארח אתכם אצלנו.חנוך, יעל ואמוץ",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

<li><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column3: >Partir à la rencontre de l'Europe en vélo, depuis Dijon jusqu'à Budapest au mois d'août.

column1: • Sensibiliser les populations que nous allons rencontrer à la problématique du développement durable mais aussi et surtout à celle de L'Europe !
• Monter un reportage sur le trajet afin de le présenter ensuite dans les collèges/lycées pour transmettre l'idée européenne aux plus jeunes.
<h3><b style=""letter-spacing: 0px
<h3><b style=""letter-spacing: 0px

column2: >Un groupe de 10 étudiants de Sciences Po venant des quatre coins de l'Europe tous très intéressés par les problématiques que pose l'Europe aujourd'hui. A force de nous côtoyer nous avons pu découvrir que l'Europe n'est pas seulement un projet politique et économique, elle a aussi une dimension culturelle très impressionnante. Aujourd'hui, tout le monde connaît l'aspect politique et économique de l'Europe, mais l'aspect culturel... C'est une autre affaire. Notre projet vise à faire découvrir l'Europe sous un autre angle : celui de la culture !

>Soucieux de l'environnement, mais aussi un peu téméraires, nous avons décidé de nous lancer un défi sportif pour découvrir l'Europe : partir en vélo de Dijon (où est basé le campus européen de Sciences Po), jusqu'à Budapest. Le vélo a été envisagé comme un moyen de transport propre et rapide, mais aussi assez intriguant pour éveiller la curiosité des personnes que nous allons rencontrer et les inviter à nous faire part de leur vision de l'Europe.

>Grâce à ces rencontres, aux visites des villes que nous traverserons, nous allons construire un reportage sur le thème ""L'Europe : unité dans la diversité ?"". De retour en France nous présenterons ce reportage dans des collèges et lycées et organiserons des débats entre jeunes pour les sensibiliser à l'Europe.
>Pour plus de précisions retrouvez nous sur notre blog, en cliquant ici !

column1: ","Bicycl'Est en Bref c'est :
Partir à la rencontre de l'Europe en vélo, depuis Dijon jusqu'à Budapest au mois d'août.
Sensibiliser les populations que nous allons rencontrer à la problématique du développement durable mais aussi et surtout à celle de L'Europe !
Monter un reportage sur le trajet afin de le présenter ensuite dans les collèges/lycées pour transmettre l'idée européenne aux plus jeunes.
Plus précisément Bicycl'Est c'est :

Un groupe de 10 étudiants de Sciences Po venant des quatre coins de l'Europe tous très intéressés par les problématiques que pose l'Europe aujourd'hui. A force de nous côtoyer nous avons pu découvrir que l'Europe n'est pas seulement un projet politique et économique, elle a aussi une dimension culturelle très impressionnante. Aujourd'hui, tout le monde connaît l'aspect politique et économique de l'Europe, mais l'aspect culturel... C'est une autre affaire. Notre projet vise à faire découvrir l'Europe sous un autre angle : celui de la culture !

Soucieux de l'environnement, mais aussi un peu téméraires, nous avons décidé de nous lancer un défi sportif pour découvrir l'Europe : partir en vélo de Dijon (où est basé le campus européen de Sciences Po), jusqu'à Budapest. Le vélo a été envisagé comme un moyen de transport propre et rapide, mais aussi assez intriguant pour éveiller la curiosité des personnes que nous allons rencontrer et les inviter à nous faire part de leur vision de l'Europe.

Grâce à ces rencontres, aux visites des villes que nous traverserons, nous allons construire un reportage sur le thème ""L'Europe : unité dans la diversité ?"". De retour en France nous présenterons ce reportage dans des collèges et lycées et organiserons des débats entre jeunes pour les sensibiliser à l'Europe.
Pour plus de précisions retrouvez nous sur notre blog, en cliquant ici !
On compte sur vous !",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns
|","Dijon, France",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/bicycl-est--3/pica

Howdy! My name is Luke McLaughlin. You might recognize me from the Discovery Channel's hit shows, ""Naked and Afraid"", and ""Naked and Afraid: XL"".  I have done well in these extreme survival challenges because I have dedicated my life to deep Nature connection and mastering indigenous skills.
I believe ALL humans are meant to have a deep Nature connection.
I have over 400 days of primitive living in the wild and my background as an educator has equipped me to help people reconnect to the land.
My partner Natalie and I are starting Holistic Survival School (HSS). We are committed to helping people connect to Nature.
We need your help: we are planting our business near Grand Rapids, Michigan. We chose Grand Rapids because of the great community, and access to natural resources.
We will be purchasing land for HSS.  Your contribution will:
-Help bring a Nature based school to the Midwest/Michigan/Grand Rapids community
-Help children and adults learn how to live with a deep Nature connection
-Create a space for people to learn more about themselves and our natural environment.
-Create a community of environmentally based thinkers

The funding you contribute will go directly toward buying land to start Holistic Survival School. We have been searching for an ideal place to start HSS and have narrowed it down to a couple of plots.  

The plots are 20-40 acres, contain old growth forests that are secluded, and are within 30 minutes of the Grand Rapids. Help us grow and restore native land and wildlife while helping people get in touch with themselves and the natural world.

Like all healthy relationships, it's reciprocal!  We have some cool perks for your donations!  Most of our rewards are hand made by Luke himself and come from Nature.
<ul>
• Make fire from Sticks!  We have several perks that will give you everything you need to make friction fire!
• Personally decorated Bison skulls (humanely killed for herd management)
• Opportunities to hang out with Luke (and other Naked and Afraid: XL stars) in the wilderness and learn some things!
• Buckskin fanny packs (pictured below) and hobo bags made by Luke
• Weekend Get-aways on our purchased land
All of  the money will used toward purchasing property for HSS in the greater Grand Rapids area.
So what's the big deal?!  Why is this important to me?
I truly believe that if we are to save life on this Earth and save ourselves as a species, we need to make some sudden, drastic changes.
This land will be the space where we as a community can return to the land.  The land will be the epicenter for learning tangible, earth-based skills that help us establish a relationship to Nature.
Be the change you wish to see. Nature connection is critical!
• Help the community shift from an ""ego-centric"" mindset to ""eco-centric""
• Help people find wellness and wholeness in Nature
• Inspire people to live in harmony with their surroundings
• Re-establish a relationship with the local ecosystem
Testimonials from past Holistic Survival School participants:

“An information filled weekend, with generous and thoughtful hosts. I have camped hundreds of times, but I have never experienced the land, the life growing on the land, or myself quite this way before. It was a blessing, and the start of a new way to experience my surroundings and the gifts that grow all around us ""
<div>

“I am a middle aged ‘mom’ that hadn’t been camping in many years–that signed up for a ‘Survival Training Class’…kind of funny. But Luke (and all the others) were so kind and welcoming. Everyone seemed to lay aside their experience and came ready to learn more. I had a wonderful time, learned a lot and yet walked away feeling more at peace than I had felt in a long time. I brought along my 13 year old niece, and she had a wonderful time as well. Nice job guys, we look forward to more.""
<div>
“A great experience with great people! All about getting back in touch with mind, body, soul and the earth!”
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)

I understand if you are not able to contribute toward the cause, BUT YOU CAN STILL HELP!  As they say ""Sharing is caring"".  Please share this campaign to anyone who is willing to listen!  Talk about it at work, share this page on your social media (use the indiegogo share tools!).  Our World and its inhabitants need more time in the wild.  Keep ReWilding.

THE FOREST VOICES TOUR 2015

I am a passionate film maker, who has just left his day job to per-sue my dream of filming around the world.

   ""The Baka Beyond"" are a band I have listened to since I was little. ""Inspired by the Baka People of Cameroon's rainforest and the joy that resonates through their music, they are now dedicated to saving this vulnerable people using their magical music to reach into people's hearts"" as well as creating awareness about the trouble the Baka people face. Watch the videos for more information.

   The tour is due to go ahead from the end of November for 3 weeks, touring around 15 different communities playing with the Baka people for the Baka people as well as share stories and watch films to raise issues that they face.

   I will hopefully be filming the whole tour as well as some interviews with the band and local so that the music and message can go further than just the audience at the time. This is extremely important to help save the Baka people's heritage and culture, as the more awareness the better!

   So this is where you come in. The project is not about profit, although any extra money that we do raise will go straight back into the Baka community. Past ventures and albums from The Baka Beyond have funded a recording studio and instruments. (http://www.theecologist.org/siteimage/scale/800/600/394191.png)  

  There has already been quite a lot funded for this project and will be more at ""The Baka Beyond's Grand Charity Ball"" in Bath on October 3rd. I believe this is a great project to be involved in, but unfortunately can't do it all on my own.  So all that I need is enough funding to insure my equipment, pay for my stay while away (accommodation is around £3-£4 per night! and food is around £1 per meal!). 

   I have experience in a vast array of film, from extreme sports to theatre and visual projection and plan to combine several aspects from these different mediums to produce a film that is unique and interesting both visually and in content.

   Not only will you be supporting the Baka people of Cameroon, but you will also be supporting and helping to protect the rainforest. As I'm sure some of you know, rainforests are rich with plants and minerals full of medical purpose that could help you, me and the rest of the world. Due to deforestation and the Baka people not being allowed to exercise their right to the forest, these precious healing properties of the rainforest could be lost forever!

   Please help us to give them a voice and spread the word around the world!

We have a dream and with your help we intend to make it a reality.

Come and join us in creating a world first eco friendly castle in the Australian Outback which will comprise of a state of the art education facility for the local community in rural Northern Territory

Enthusiast in Castle Architecture, Neil Henson has found the perfect outback location for a castle in the Northern Territory of Australia which will house the education facility and we would love to share it with you all so jump on board and help us to create our dream
Why are we building an education facility?

The creation of this education facility is a lifelong dream of businessman Neil Henson, a retired soldier who brings a wealth of disciplined experience into his business activities. Neil has been acknowledged for his efforts by being presented 2 awards this year by the REINT for Innovation and communication ahead of 200 other Companies in the NT.
Neil says

‘’This castle will provide classrooms for teachers and students with facilities for all to benefit from, the castle walls provide protection where everyone can enjoy our education facility as well as all of what the territory has to offer and feel completely safe at the same time. 100 new job opportunities will be created from this project and we intend to plant over 2000 trees to assist the sustainability of the area. Built using 21st century technology, the castle will consist of classic 14th-20th century design features built on Finniss River which will flow naturally around the castle walls.’’

There isn’t a location within 100km of the Darwin CBD for locals or visitors to go to a luxury outback (affordable) education facility or nature reserve in a retreat complex. The only choices are 2 star resorts or having to fly interstate or overseas.

This outback oasis will be a short 55 minute journey from the city of Darwin where you are surrounded by nature in this unique and wild area with lots to see and do! It truly is ‘Beauty and the Beast’ with its vast bushland and landscape views, rivers teeming with crocodiles and other animals such as wild horses and boars, kangaroos and wallabies, birds and insects. The birdlife is extraordinary and the nature land near to the castle has wading birds and a large variety of finches, kingfishers and bee eaters to name just a few.
Be a part of it and help support us in building a world first! Keep an eye on us during construction with webcam views and on completion we welcome you to come and see what you have helped create!

Every little helps and if you don’t want to purchase a tier option highlighted we appreciate any support at all so please share with all of your friends, any donation big or small will assist us to achieve our goal!
http://www.hardcastleresort.com.au/
Im Outback des Northern Territory von Australien bauen wir das welterste Öko-Schloss-Resort mit Bildungszentrum. Ein ökologisch aufgebautes Schloss mit Sonnenenergie und Regenwasserversorgung:
<ul>
• Bepflanzung 2000+ bäume.
• Erstellen 100+ beschäftigungsmöglichkeiten .
Wir bedanken uns für deine Spende, egal ob klein oder groß.

Promoting honey production in rural Zambia

The iAfrica Foundation supports sustainable development in rural Zambia. Through our ZayoHub project (www.zayohub.com), we are working with communities in the remotest parts of the country. Both iAfrica and ZayoHub are non-profits, focused on using market based approaches and social enterprise to achieve development goals.

Honey production is a great option for villagers in the south-west of Zambia. Honey generates a good income, while preserving the extensive hardwood (teak) forests. The great taste of our organic forest honey is popular in European and US markets, and the potential for expansion is vast. There are few other good options for improving local incomes, especially as climate change means that annual rainfall is increasingly unreliable.

Traditional methods mean that a tree is felled for every traditional bark hive. The population is scattered through extensive forests, and have always had ample access to timber products. But as we promote increased honey production, this needs to change. The hidden environmental cost of expansion is otherwise too high to contemplate. The women and men we train in bee keeping and honey production will be obliged to adopt the use of improved hives, made from wood from sustainable forests, to engage with our programme.

Honey adds significantly to household earnings, without a huge demand for labour. It's not hard, and there is already considerable traditional knowledge. Someone who own five hives can expect to earn the equivalent of half a years' supply of staple food for a family of five
column2: as they scale up, there is ample opportunity to build a good income.

column1: <h3>What We Need &amp
In the first year, we want to train 250 women and men, and get them started with two hives each. The improved hives cost £20 each, so that's £10,000 in all.

The villagers are not inclined to spend £40 each on improved hives - they can just as well cut down trees, and that money (if they have it) is needed for other basic needs. On the other hand, we don't want to hand out hives for free
column2: we can't afford to do that, and it's generally not the right way to go.

column1: So we are looking for support to help get the farmers going.
For each £20:
<ul>
<li>
The new honey producer gets the hive, which belongs to him / her for as long as they remain enrolled in the programme*
<li>
The iAfrica Foundation will train the producers, visit them regularly, and provide a market for their money
<li>
The funder (you!) will get a delicious pot of honey, sent to you by post, from the first harvest.
• And a tree is not cut down
(* We retain the right to reallocate the hive if the farmer ceases to producing honey)
Sponsoring more than one hive? We'll send you a pot of honey for every hive you sponsor, plus a bonus pot too!
The Impact
The project brings benefits at every level:
<ul>
• The producer gets to build a new, sustainable, climate change resilient livelihood
• The hardwood forest is preserved, with local and global benefits
• The Zambian economy benefits from increased exports
• The consumer enjoys delicious healthy organic honey

The local producer needs to expand his / her business. The global community needs the forests to be preserved. This opportunity is about sharing the costs of conserving the forest, by helping impoverished communities to adopt sustainable hives.
Overcoming Challenges

There are many challenges to working in rural Zambia. It is remote, roads are poor, and communications can be difficult. Fortunately, our team has been working in Zambia for many years, and we have built relations with the local community. We can never say there won't be challenges, but we can certainly say that we have ample experience in getting our diverse projects and programmes to work.
Other Ways You Can Help
Please share our campaign with others!
","Promoting honey production in rural Zambia

The iAfrica Foundation supports sustainable development in rural Zambia. Through our ZayoHub project (www.zayohub.com), we are working with communities in the remotest parts of the country. Both iAfrica and ZayoHub are non-profits, focused on using market based approaches and social enterprise to achieve development goals.

Honey production is a great option for villagers in the south-west of Zambia. Honey generates a good income, while preserving the extensive hardwood (teak) forests. The great taste of our organic forest honey is popular in European and US markets, and the potential for expansion is vast. There are few other good options for improving local incomes, especially as climate change means that annual rainfall is increasingly unreliable.

Traditional methods mean that a tree is felled for every traditional bark hive. The population is scattered through extensive forests, and have always had ample access to timber products. But as we promote increased honey production, this needs to change. The hidden environmental cost of expansion is otherwise too high to contemplate. The women and men we train in bee keeping and honey production will be obliged to adopt the use of improved hives, made from wood from sustainable forests, to engage with our programme.

Honey adds significantly to household earnings, without a huge demand for labour. It's not hard, and there is already considerable traditional knowledge. Someone who own five hives can expect to earn the equivalent of half a years' supply of staple food for a family of five
column2: as they scale up, there is ample opportunity to build a good income.

column1: What We Need & What You Get
In the first year, we want to train 250 women and men, and get them started with two hives each. The improved hives cost £20 each, so that's £10,000 in all.

The villagers are not inclined to spend £40 each on improved hives - they can just as well cut down trees, and that money (if they have it) is needed for other basic needs. On the other hand, we don't want to hand out hives for free
column2: we can't afford to do that, and it's generally not the right way to go.

column1: So we are looking for support to help get the farmers going.
For each £20:
The new honey producer gets the hive, which belongs to him / her for as long as they remain enrolled in the programme*
The iAfrica Foundation will train the producers, visit them regularly, and provide a market for their money
The funder (you!) will get a delicious pot of honey, sent to you by post, from the first harvest.
And a tree is not cut down
(* We retain the right to reallocate the hive if the farmer ceases to producing honey)
Sponsoring more than one hive? We'll send you a pot of honey for every hive you sponsor, plus a bonus pot too!
The Impact
The project brings benefits at every level:
The producer gets to build a new, sustainable, climate change resilient livelihood
The hardwood forest is preserved, with local and global benefits
The Zambian economy benefits from increased exports
The consumer enjoys delicious healthy organic honey

The local producer needs to expand his / her business. The global community needs the forests to be preserved. This opportunity is about sharing the costs of conserving the forest, by helping impoverished communities to adopt sustainable hives.
Overcoming Challenges

There are many challenges to working in rural Zambia. It is remote, roads are poor, and communications can be difficult. Fortunately, our team has been working in Zambia for many years, and we have built relations with the local community. We can never say there won't be challenges, but we can certainly say that we have ample experience in getting our diverse projects and programmes to work.
Other Ways You Can Help
Please share our campaign with others!",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

Who We Are

The road to Silver Star Trailhead is in woeful disrepair. Massive ruts keep most passenger cars from reaching the trailhead, cutting off access to the beautiful sub-alpine meadows and ridges of Silver Star Mountain. Hoping to one day take his sons hiking up the mountain he loved,  in 2019 Jeremy VanGelder arranged two volunteer workdays to fix the road, and Friends of Road 4109 was born.

Last year we proved that volunteers can repair a road by creating waterbars and filling potholes along a 1/2 mile stretch of the road. This year our goal is to improve another mile of the road and lay gravel to preserve our improvements.
What We Need and What You Get

Volunteer road repair is hard work. But the list of necessary supplies is pretty simple. We rent traffic control devices, we buy diesel for our tractors, and then we pay for gravel to be delivered to the site. If we reach our funding goal of $1,000, we will be able to buy about 30 tons of gravel to place on the road.
When you show the world that you are a Friend of Road 4109 you will receive one of a variety of items picturing the outline of Silver Star Mountain. All artwork is courtesy of Mythros Studios.
<h3>Risks &amp
As with any construction project, safety needs to be a priority when working with machinery. This is why we rent traffic control equipment and implement safety briefings before every work event.

We don't know what the weather will be or how COVID-19 may change how we are able to interact. We are prepared to implement social distancing measures and will keep our schedule fluid. If we are unable to do the project, we will donate all profits from this campaign to Washington Trails Association and Citizens for Forest Roads. If we don't reach our goal of $1,000, we will not be able to buy gravel. But the money raised in the campaign will cover diesel and rentals of safety equipment.

Other Ways You Can Help

Low on cash but rich in elbow grease? Come join us as a volunteer on August 22 for our next work party! Check out our Facebook page for more details.

<h3><span class=""Apple-style-span"" style=""font-size: 14px
mBoo is a line of ultra soft and environmentally friendly toilet paper made from natural bamboo fiber.
Our Story

Every year, Americans waste more than 5 million trees on toilet paper alone. While recycled toilet paper has always been an option, they've never been widely available on the market due to their lack of popularity. This is because recycled toilet paper is often harsh and gives off an unsanitary impression.

The solution to this problem is bamboo. Bamboo is one of the world's most abundant and easily renewable resources because it is able to reach a maturity height of 75 feet in a matter of two months. The process of manufacturing toilet paper is also environmentally friendly and, thanks to some of bamboo's basic properties, yields an ultra soft end product.
The Impact

Since bamboo is primarily grown in developing countries, bamboo made products will bring notable economic improvements to those countries and communities. For example, the farmers of bamboo farms in Moganshan, China, are seeing their annual incomes grow at a 20% rate thanks to the growing demand for bamboo. Their lives serve as hope for many poor bamboo farmers in other parts of China, South Asia, as well as Africa.
So make a difference, and advocate for bamboo.
<h3>What We Need &amp

We are asking for a total of $20,000 to help us bring this product to the general market. With this money, we would be able to conduct the proper research and development, secure a contract with a trusting manufacturer, and pitch the product to major retail outlets.
Here's a more detailed look at how your money will be spent:
1. Web developer to create a retail website for mBoo
2. Consultant to find proper manufacturing partner and to help develop mBoo product line.
3. Legal fees
4. Advertising fees
5. Purchasing final products
6. Consultant to help get the attention of major retail outlets
For all donators, we will keep you updated on a weekly basis on our progress as well as on how your money is being spent.
Other Ways You Can Help

There are many other ways you can help besides making a monetary contribution. Please share this campaign with your family and friends and ask them to do the same. We thank you for your interest and support.

My name is Xiuhtezcatl Martinez and I am an indigenous eco hip hop activist and the Youth Director of Earth Guardians. As a 14-year-old growing up in Colorado, I’ve seen the effects of climate change firsthand. Youth from around the world know that climate change is the defining issue of our time, and our generation will be the most affected. Many of us feel despair when it comes to dealing with climate change because we don't know where to start. We are ready to contribute to the solution, we just need the tools, confidence and momentum to get started.
<h3><span style=""font-size: 16px
<div>
<div style="""">
<h3><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px

column2: >Our schools are not offering us the kind of education we need to deal with the world we are going to be left with. RYSE (Rising Youth for a Sustainable Earth) a project of Earth Guardians will train young solutionaries to take a leadership role in the climate movement instead of waiting for others to lead. RYSE trainings will give youth the tools, skills and support to implement sustainable projects and transform their communities. This is an opportunity for youth to turn fear and despair about the kind of world they are inheriting into momentum and progress. Your contribution will help over 500 youth become active climate leaders.
>            Leadership training at the launch of Earth Guardians Australia in 2013

column1: <h3 style=""letter-spacing: 0px
<div>
<ul>

• Empowered young leaders will lead projects, campaigns, and collective actions that disrupt the global leadership status quo. We will prove that our generation is not interested in waiting for others to take action. We are the ones we’ve been waiting for.
<li>
<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column3: >We will share our progress at the UN Climate Talks in Paris in December of 2015, demonstrating that we will protect our future no matter what.
column5: >Our message to world leaders: JOIN US!

column1: <blockquote><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >                     UN Talks at the Rio+20 in Rio, Brazil in 2013

column1: <ul>
<div style=""letter-spacing: 0px
RYSE Councils
The RYSE Youth Council is made up of 13 exceptional youth leaders from diverse backgrounds
column2: w=1"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" target=""_blank"">We are still welcoming applications for the Youth Council.

column1: The Youth Council will develop their skills as organizers, facilitators, and community leaders while working together as the principal decision makers for the RYSE movement.

The RYSE Wisdom Council is made up of 13 seasoned leaders and activists from diverse geographic, ethnic, cultural, and socioeconomic backgrounds. With experience in arts, sciences, social justice, movement-building, and climate solutions, this multifaceted council will support the youth-led shift toward a healthy, just and sustainable planet.

column2: >         Van Jones, Wisdom Council Member, with Xiuhtezcatl and Itzcuauhtli

>In March of 2015, the impressive movement builders of the Wildfire Project will facilitate 4 days of workshops and trainings for the RYSE Youth Council. Wildfire is a democratic, front lines, action-oriented team of organizers and facilitators. They recognize times of crisis as vital opportunities for improving life on earth. They fuse political education, skills training, group development, and direct organizing. Their team leader is the global trainer for 350.org. They have supported a diverse range of social and ecological justice movements: from Tar Sands Action and PowerShift to Dream Defenders and the Divest Student Network. The training will take place around the third weekend in March at Frost Valley in the Catskill Mountains.

column1: In April of 2015, Youth Council Leaders will unite to collectively carry out and lead an organized national action: RYSE and Shine. This powerful, unified action will mobilize and inspire participants in addition to jump-starting the momentum of the movement.
Youth leaders coming together at Arise Festival in Colorado in 2013
Phase 3: Community Solutions Activation Trainings

In Summer of 2015, RYSE Youth Council Leaders across the country will put their new skills to use and organize local trainings and events within their communities. Day 1 of their trainings will focus on analysis of key issues, organizing, and leadership strategy. Day 2 will be dedicated to collaboratively crafting a plan for climate solutions using innovative facilitation techniques to implement in their communities. Below is a budget for 20 trainings across the country with an average of 25 people per training.
<blockquote>
<span style=""font-size: 24px

Time to RYSE! Leaders and communities will put their climate solutions into action. Shovels will be in soil planting trees and gardens, solar panels will cover school rooftops, and new solar-powered lights will line park sidewalks. We anticipate ingenuity and never-before-seen solutions. Youth leaders will discover the creative, collaborative leaders within. With the tools and connections from RYSE, youth will recognize themselves as leaders, catalysts for change and a part of our greater global community.
At the launch of the Earth Guardians Protect Our Future campaign,                             youth leaders from 20 countries planted thousands of trees.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute financially here are some other ways you can help:

Thank you for your support.

","My name is Xiuhtezcatl Martinez and I am an indigenous eco hip hop activist and the Youth Director of Earth Guardians. As a 14-year-old growing up in Colorado, I’ve seen the effects of climate change firsthand. Youth from around the world know that climate change is the defining issue of our time, and our generation will be the most affected. Many of us feel despair when it comes to dealing with climate change because we don't know where to start. We are ready to contribute to the solution, we just need the tools, confidence and momentum to get started.
The Opportunity

Our schools are not offering us the kind of education we need to deal with the world we are going to be left with. RYSE (Rising Youth for a Sustainable Earth) a project of Earth Guardians will train young solutionaries to take a leadership role in the climate movement instead of waiting for others to lead. RYSE trainings will give youth the tools, skills and support to implement sustainable projects and transform their communities. This is an opportunity for youth to turn fear and despair about the kind of world they are inheriting into momentum and progress. Your contribution will help over 500 youth become active climate leaders.
Leadership training at the launch of Earth Guardians Australia in 2013
The Vision

Empowered young leaders will lead projects, campaigns, and collective actions that disrupt the global leadership status quo. We will prove that our generation is not interested in waiting for others to take action. We are the ones we’ve been waiting for.
We will share our progress at the UN Climate Talks in Paris in December of 2015, demonstrating that we will protect our future no matter what. Our message to world leaders: JOIN US!
UN Talks at the Rio+20 in Rio, Brazil in 2013
RYSE Councils
The RYSE Youth Council is made up of 13 exceptional youth leaders from diverse backgrounds We are still welcoming applications for the Youth Council.
The Youth Council will develop their skills as organizers, facilitators, and community leaders while working together as the principal decision makers for the RYSE movement.

The RYSE Wisdom Council is made up of 13 seasoned leaders and activists from diverse geographic, ethnic, cultural, and socioeconomic backgrounds. With experience in arts, sciences, social justice, movement-building, and climate solutions, this multifaceted council will support the youth-led shift toward a healthy, just and sustainable planet.
Van Jones, Wisdom Council Member, with Xiuhtezcatl and Itzcuauhtli
Phase 1: Wildfire Training

In March of 2015, the impressive movement builders of the Wildfire Project will facilitate 4 days of workshops and trainings for the RYSE Youth Council. Wildfire is a democratic, front lines, action-oriented team of organizers and facilitators. They recognize times of crisis as vital opportunities for improving life on earth. They fuse political education, skills training, group development, and direct organizing. Their team leader is the global trainer for 350.org. They have supported a diverse range of social and ecological justice movements: from Tar Sands Action and PowerShift to Dream Defenders and the Divest Student Network. The training will take place around the third weekend in March at Frost Valley in the Catskill Mountains.
Phase 2: RYSE and Shine

In April of 2015, Youth Council Leaders will unite to collectively carry out and lead an organized national action: RYSE and Shine. This powerful, unified action will mobilize and inspire participants in addition to jump-starting the momentum of the movement.
Youth leaders coming together at Arise Festival in Colorado in 2013
Phase 3: Community Solutions Activation Trainings

In Summer of 2015, RYSE Youth Council Leaders across the country will put their new skills to use and organize local trainings and events within their communities. Day 1 of their trainings will focus on analysis of key issues, organizing, and leadership strategy. Day 2 will be dedicated to collaboratively crafting a plan for climate solutions using innovative facilitation techniques to implement in their communities. Below is a budget for 20 trainings across the country with an average of 25 people per training.
Phase 4: Activation

Time to RYSE! Leaders and communities will put their climate solutions into action. Shovels will be in soil planting trees and gardens, solar panels will cover school rooftops, and new solar-powered lights will line park sidewalks. We anticipate ingenuity and never-before-seen solutions. Youth leaders will discover the creative, collaborative leaders within. With the tools and connections from RYSE, youth will recognize themselves as leaders, catalysts for change and a part of our greater global community.
At the launch of the Earth Guardians Protect Our Future campaign,                             youth leaders from 20 countries planted thousands of trees.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute financially here are some other ways you can help:
Tell your friends about this campaign-- click the share links to share on social media
Share the video and spread the word about #GenerationRYSE
Nominate a youth leader for our RYSE youth council
Love, Peace, Movement.
Thank you for your support.",8.0,0,"1 Campaign

column5:
>Short Summary

This project aims to help Igor - a local Ecuadorian farmer - to reforestate his farm and thus preserve the unique Ecuadorian cloud forest. The ultimate aim is to turn this part of Ecuador into a national park.

column1: My girlfriend and I were traveling through Ecuador this summer and were fortunate enough to spend a few days with Igor Overtchenko. He moved to Ecuador a few years back and bought a piece of land in the Ecuadorian cloud forest, just 3 hours north of the capital Quito. Like so many others, his previous owners had cut down the forest to replace it with more profitable animal pastures and sugar cane fields. Igor has spent last years reforestating his estate. He has already planted 3,000 trees - all by himself.

The goal of this project is to plant the next 3,000 trees by employing local workers who can help Igor with this tough task. Supporting Igor means supporting local change. He is a driving force who can convince other local farmers to also protect their most valuable resource - the cloud forest.
What Is Needed
column2: >6,000 USD are need to plant 3,000 trees (2 hectares)

column1: Costs come from:
<li><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column2: >Employing workers (~100 USD per worker per week)

column1: <li><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
<div>

Igor And His Vision

Igors vision is to establish a national park in this area. He wants to convince other farmers to follow his example and present his plan of a national park to the Ecuadorian government. Igor is an inspiring individual to us - a caring, heart-warming man with a strong determination to have an impact. Supporting Igor means supporting a local force that can move much more than we from the outside ever could.

Why It Will Work

Igor knows how it's done. He has already planted 3,000 trees, he lives ON the project (literally!) and he knows his way around the area. His heart is at the right place and he is dedicated to his work like hardly any other person I know.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread this project to your family and friends! Publicity is always needed!

But if you happen to be in Ecuador, then go an plant some trees yourself! Igor will be more than happy to have a helping hand! In return you get food, a place to sleep and breathtaking views. These were the most tranquil days of our trip and we wish Igor all the best!
Contact him directly: www.fincafigaro.wordpress.com

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><h3><span style=""font-size: medium
column3: >Please Help Protect and Preserve Our Important Coral Reefs

column1: <div><strong><span style=""font-size: small
<h3><span style=""font-weight: normal
column3: >Dive Tribe is a group of divers formed in 2009 to take care and educate the public in Thailand to the importance of our Marine Environment and how to protect and preserve it.

column2: >We now have a talented group of committed divers with a diverse range of talents drawn from a range of nationalities.

>As a result of our campaigning efforts we currently have well over 11,000 active members, a figure which is growing daily, on social networking sites.
Dive Tribe also has 35 partner stores in Thailand and total of 70 across Asia.
They actively engage in our conservation projects .
>Our innovative approaches to marine conservation have prompted growing and positive media interest in Asia, Europe and North America.
>We worked very hard to secure sufficient funding to initiate a couple of smaller, but nonetheless important projects in the past 6 months.
><span class=""s1"">The first involved the largest release of captive sharks in Asia. See Link: <span style=""color: #676767
column5:
type=3"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" target=""_blank"" title="""">Here
Our second, held over Chinese New Year, engaged 20 of our colleagues in diving with sharks at the Underwater World Marine Center here in Pattaya.
The purpose was to wish several hundred visitors a Happy Chinese New Year, whilst asking them to take the pledge to abstain from consuming Shark Fin Soup.
Again, this attracted a lot of public and media attention. See Link:

column1: <h3><span style=""font-size: medium
<ul>
<li><span style=""font-size: small
column5: >Coral reefs are among the oldest ecosystems on Earth.

column1: <li><span style=""color: #333333
column4: >Coral reefs support a phenomenal diversity of species and provide irreplaceable sources of food and shelter. Tropical rain forests play a similar role on the land.

column1: <li><span style=""color: #333333
column5: >Coral reef ecosystems support a variety of human needs. They are important for subsistence, fisheries, tourism, shoreline protection, and yield compounds that are important in the development of new medicines.

column1: <li style=""color: #333333
column8: >Coral reefs form natural barriers that protect nearby shorelines from the eroding forces of the sea, thereby protecting coastal dwellings, agricultural land and beaches.

column1: <li><span style=""font-size: small
column5: >Coral reefs have been used in the treatment of cancer, HIV, cardiovascular diseases, ulcers, and other ailments.

column1: <li><span style=""color: #333333
column6: >Although coral reefs cover less than 1% of the Earth’s surface, they are home to 25% of all marine fish species.
column7: >At least 500 million people rely on coral reefs for food, coastal protection, and livelihoods

column1: <li><span style=""color: #333333
column7: >Estimates are that 20% of the world’s coral reefs have been effectively destroyed in the last few decades and an additional 20% or more are severely degraded, particularly in the Southeast Asia

column1: <div><span style=""color: #000000
column3: >Coral Reefs need our help and simply restoring the reefs doesn’t solve the problem of the constant damage and abuse that they suffer.

column1: <span style=""font-size: small
column4:
>Anchor damage is the most preventable form of damage caused by humans. 
There is very little doubt that mooring buoys placed in coral areas reduce the amount of coral damage caused by anchors in these areas, in most cases by more than 80%
Mooring buoys are also an important management tool in that they are useful in controlling the usage of certain areas by somewhat restricting the boat usage at the dive sites and encouraging boats to move to another site.
column8: >We have observed and collected data that existing damage would benefit from the additions of fixed moorings.
column9: >Dive Tribe have worked on and researched several systems and believe the Helix Ground Tackle with a marker buoy to be the best solution, it has proven its self suitable and has been installed in the Philippines, Egypt and Australia’s special coral areas. We are against using concrete blocks or tying straight to reefs as these in there own way have proved more damaging in the long run.
column14:
>In the past the inclusion of mooring buoys into areas has often meant the use of unsightly concrete anchoring blocks or tying directly to reefs. There are several drawbacks with using large concrete weights as the ground tackle for mooring buoys. These include the area under the block, the degrading of the visual aesthetics of the area and the need for a large crane for deployment which is inaccurate and can damage the reefs below.
Tying directly to reefs can also damage the reef it is trying to protect and is not recommended

column2:
>
The Helix Anchoring system is a worldwide tried and proven method of anchoring in ecological sensitive marine areas. The Helix system offers many unique advantages over the traditional methods of using concrete blocks or permanently drilled anchors in rock or other hard substrata found in coral areas.

column1: These Advantages Include:
1. Easy to install.  The Helix anchor can be installed from a small (<
column2: 4M) boat with a draught of less than 30 cm. Weighted anchors require the use of a barge and crane that is able to lift the weight of the block. The draught of such vessel may be several meters when taking the leaning factor when the weight is being lowered to the seabed. Many of the corals in Pattaya are in shallow water areas and may not have the necessary depth to carry out the concrete anchor installation without damaging the corals.

column1: 2. A small footprint with a large holding capacity. Traditional concrete or weighted ground tackle requires large areas of the seabed to be covered by the weight material. For example a 5 ton concrete anchor requires almost a 2m sq of seabed to be consumed by the anchor after installation. This means that 2m sq of seabed area will be lost and all sessile benthic animal residing there will be killed. A 5 ton Helix anchor only requires an area of 30 cm diameter during installation and 4 cm diameter after the installation.
3. Centimeter accuracy when it comes to location.

Divers in the water can safely install the Helix anchor on the seabed with centimeter accuracy. This is very important to ensure the anchor does not damage any corals during installation. Since a lot of corals in Pattaya’s reefs do not stop abruptly but rather thin out at their perimeters, most of the anchors will need installment among coral colonies. Such accurate placement would be almost impossible using large concrete blocks.
These Buoys will be fitted with an Anti Theft design and protected by Thai maritime law.

column2: >The budget for the project as a whole is $100,000 usd and in simple terms breaks down like this:

(1) paired hydraulic hose (75')             $1,500.00 USD   (45,000 Baht) Paid
All the above items have been paid for by our sponsor.

We now require 50 Helix Sand Screws with Buoys, Line and Tackle.
Each Buoy will cost in the region of 1,000 usd which brings the total value of buoys alone to $50,000
We also have to organise the logistics, divers, boats &
column2:
ongoing maintenance etc
If the campaign does not reach its target we will still be going ahead with the funds available to install the mooring buoys

","Please Help Protect and Preserve Our Important Coral Reefs

column1: About Us
Dive Tribe is a group of divers formed in 2009 to take care and educate the public in Thailand to the importance of our Marine Environment and how to protect and preserve it.
We now have a talented group of committed divers with a diverse range of talents drawn from a range of nationalities.

As a result of our campaigning efforts we currently have well over 11,000 active members, a figure which is growing daily, on social networking sites. Dive Tribe also has 35 partner stores in Thailand and total of 70 across Asia. They actively engage in our conservation projects .
Our innovative approaches to marine conservation have prompted growing and positive media interest in Asia, Europe and North America.
We worked very hard to secure sufficient funding to initiate a couple of smaller, but nonetheless important projects in the past 6 months.

The first involved the largest release of captive sharks in Asia. See Link: Here Our second, held over Chinese New Year, engaged 20 of our colleagues in diving with sharks at the Underwater World Marine Center here in Pattaya. The purpose was to wish several hundred visitors a Happy Chinese New Year, whilst asking them to take the pledge to abstain from consuming Shark Fin Soup. Again, this attracted a lot of public and media attention. See Link: Here
Why Are Coral Reefs Important ?
Coral reefs are among the oldest ecosystems on Earth.
Coral reefs support a phenomenal diversity of species and provide irreplaceable sources of food and shelter. Tropical rain forests play a similar role on the land.

Coral reef ecosystems support a variety of human needs. They are important for subsistence, fisheries, tourism, shoreline protection, and yield compounds that are important in the development of new medicines.
Coral reefs form natural barriers that protect nearby shorelines from the eroding forces of the sea, thereby protecting coastal dwellings, agricultural land and beaches.
Coral reefs have been used in the treatment of cancer, HIV, cardiovascular diseases, ulcers, and other ailments.

Although coral reefs cover less than 1% of the Earth’s surface, they are home to 25% of all marine fish species.At least 500 million people rely on coral reefs for food, coastal protection, and livelihoods
Estimates are that 20% of the world’s coral reefs have been effectively destroyed in the last few decades and an additional 20% or more are severely degraded, particularly in the Southeast Asia
Coral Reefs need our help and simply restoring the reefs doesn’t solve the problem of the constant damage and abuse that they suffer.

Anchor damage is the most preventable form of damage caused by humans. There is very little doubt that mooring buoys placed in coral areas reduce the amount of coral damage caused by anchors in these areas, in most cases by more than 80%Mooring buoys are also an important management tool in that they are useful in controlling the usage of certain areas by somewhat restricting the boat usage at the dive sites and encouraging boats to move to another site.We have observed and collected data that existing damage would benefit from the additions of fixed moorings. Dive Tribe have worked on and researched several systems and believe the Helix Ground Tackle with a marker buoy to be the best solution, it has proven its self suitable and has been installed in the Philippines, Egypt and Australia’s special coral areas. We are against using concrete blocks or tying straight to reefs as these in there own way have proved more damaging in the long run.The Project Equipment (see picture above)In the past the inclusion of mooring buoys into areas has often meant the use of unsightly concrete anchoring blocks or tying directly to reefs. There are several drawbacks with using large concrete weights as the ground tackle for mooring buoys. These include the area under the block, the degrading of the visual aesthetics of the area and the need for a large crane for deployment which is inaccurate and can damage the reefs below.Tying directly to reefs can also damage the reef it is trying to protect and is not recommended
The use of coral friendly HELIX sand screws solves these issues.

They are small compact construction and when placed take only 20cm of space.Minimum Damage During InstallationImmovable Ground TackleAesthetically suitable for inclusion in Marine ParksReliable Easy & obvious to use5 Ton HoldingEasy To MaintainProven & used all over the world on some of the largest marine parks and marinas

The Helix Anchoring system is a worldwide tried and proven method of anchoring in ecological sensitive marine areas. The Helix system offers many unique advantages over the traditional methods of using concrete blocks or permanently drilled anchors in rock or other hard substrata found in coral areas.
These Advantages Include:

1. Easy to install.  The Helix anchor can be installed from a small (< 4M) boat with a draught of less than 30 cm. Weighted anchors require the use of a barge and crane that is able to lift the weight of the block. The draught of such vessel may be several meters when taking the leaning factor when the weight is being lowered to the seabed. Many of the corals in Pattaya are in shallow water areas and may not have the necessary depth to carry out the concrete anchor installation without damaging the corals.

2. A small footprint with a large holding capacity. Traditional concrete or weighted ground tackle requires large areas of the seabed to be covered by the weight material. For example a 5 ton concrete anchor requires almost a 2m sq of seabed to be consumed by the anchor after installation. This means that 2m sq of seabed area will be lost and all sessile benthic animal residing there will be killed. A 5 ton Helix anchor only requires an area of 30 cm diameter during installation and 4 cm diameter after the installation.
3. Centimeter accuracy when it comes to location.

Divers in the water can safely install the Helix anchor on the seabed with centimeter accuracy. This is very important to ensure the anchor does not damage any corals during installation. Since a lot of corals in Pattaya’s reefs do not stop abruptly but rather thin out at their perimeters, most of the anchors will need installment among coral colonies. Such accurate placement would be almost impossible using large concrete blocks.
These Buoys will be fitted with an Anti Theft design and protected by Thai maritime law.
The Project Budget
The budget for the project as a whole is $100,000 usd and in simple terms breaks down like this:
The install equipment for Square Shaft anchors includes:
(1) submersible torque motor             $5,000.00 USD  (150,000 Baht) Paid
(1) portable hydraulic power pack      $4,000 USD  (120,000 Baht) Paid
(1) paired hydraulic hose (75')             $1,500.00 USD   (45,000 Baht) Paid
All the above items have been paid for by our sponsor.

We now require 50 Helix Sand Screws with Buoys, Line and Tackle. Each Buoy will cost in the region of 1,000 usd which brings the total value of buoys alone to $50,000We also have to organise the logistics, divers, boats & ongoing maintenance etcIf the campaign does not reach its target we will still be going ahead with the funds available to install the mooring buoys

All we ask is if you believe coral reefs are worth saving please donate as much a you can spare.Every dollar the public give us will go towards buying the Helix Sand Screw and Buoy which will protect the reef.

We are also collecting sponsors from well known companies that have a corporate responsibility programme.A Company can sponsor a buoy for approx 1,000 usd and have its name/logo on that buoy and will receive regular updates on the reef below also that companies name will appear in all our international and national media outlets. Studies on these reefs after protection will be carried out by Students at Mahidol University Marine Biology Department.
So please help us protect the reefs, any donation however little will go towards preserving what we as divers and as human beings know is the life support system for this planet !

Short Summary

I am Dr. Richard Komp, a solar scientist, and I
have worked since 1977 empowering rural
communities around the world through providing both hands-on teaching and resources for solar energy projects. Access to
electricity generated by the sun can make a huge difference in these people's
lives, but it is not enough to bring technology there and leave it. We take an
approach that provides a deep level of understanding and expertise so these
communities can create, install, maintain, and
even sell solar products, a model of sustainable development. Our solar
sailboat will be able to provide workshops and resources to coastal
communities in the Caribbean that cannot be reached by roads, and also make it
easy to follow-up and provide additional support necessary for real change to

occur.

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

We need funds to refurbish a donated sailboat that can serve as our floating solar workshop center. Funds are also needed to set up and sustain the project by purchasing solar cells and other products that are not locally available. We are hoping to raise $18,500 for this first phase of the project.

Check out our donor perks below, that include a universal solar cell phone charge made by workshop participants, or even a spot on the boat (with sailing lessons) to one of our Caribbean destinations.

The Impact

column1: Our floating solar workshops can make a real impact: solar energy can cook food, leading to less deforestation and time
women spend gathering fuel
column2: solar chargers can power cell phones, improving communication and providing small business opportunities
column3: solar-heated water can bring hot, desalinized water to coastal communities, rural hospitals and health clinics
column4: PV modules can sanitize medical equipment or light a room so a

column1:
child can study at night. 

Our approach, developed through years of work with communities in countries such as Nicaragua, Peru and Mali, combines bringing technology into reach with community development and empowerment. In the past 25 years, I have seen many successes -- the work of Grupo
Fenix in Nicaragua
column2: AfriqPower in Mali (featured in the award-winning

column1: documentary ""Burning in the Sun"")
column2: and the LED streetlights made in

column1: Haiti that lit streets and helped create impromptu survival camps after

the earthquake. Nothing is just given for free -- participants must agree to also contribute and become capable of maintaining the technology themselves. For that reason we provide hands-on workshops on building, installing, maintaining and repairing solar technologies. One key to successful implementation of solar technologies such as solar cookers is to follow-up -- our sailboat will enable regular, repeated visits to areas that are often not accessible by road.

Your contribution can be part of this exciting new project. We already have community partners in place who are waiting for the solar sailboat to provide important work for sustainable development in the following places: San Andrés, Colombia (a small island that is home to a Garifuna community)
column2: the Miskito Coast in Nicaragua and Honduras
column4:
and coastal communities in Jamaica, Haiti, Trinidad and the Dominican Republic.

Imagine -- your donation can help to empower communities, create sustainable development, and increase the availability of solar energy -- all at once!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this widely -- I'm sure if people hear about this wonderful project, they will want to help!

Last Saturday April 16th, 2016 the coastal region of Ecuador was struck by a massive 7.8 earthquake. There are many families affected and devastation all around. The most affected areas are in the provinces of Manabí and Esmeraldas.

The Ecuadorian government reports 655 deaths, 17,638 injured and 100,000 affected people thus far, but these numbers are expected to rise in the coming days. Right now there is an immediate need for resources primarily for rescue, food and medicine.

Our Elastix team and a group of young professionals in Ecuador has started a campaign to transport potable water to those provinces most affected by the earthquake. This is completely volunteer driven and we are putting money from our own pockets to get started. However, we need the help of the Ecuadorian and International community to make a dent on this problem.

The Goal of this Campaign

We are coordinating the transport and storage of potable water for the people who lost their homes during the earthquake. The water will be delivered via tanker trucks and it will be distributed across several near the cities most affected by the catastrophe. The water will be conserved in 55-gallon containers.

Our commitment is to coordinate the water sourcing, transport and delivery from Guayaquil and other cities that will become part of the campaign.

""It is essential to distribute water, and more important to store and conserve water""

How to Contribute?

This campaign requires great Logistics planning and the volunteer team of “Ecuador Water Relief” is funding these efforts but we need more resources to be effective. You can contribute directly through this campaign with any amount.

column2: >the ability to plant trees for free, right from their computer, while having fun.

column1: Get smarter with quizzes like English, famous people, animals, geography, science, and more... all while making a difference in the world.
How
When you get an answer right, ads pay to plant real trees in Africa.(Like Freerice.com but for trees!)
We are a small boot-strapped team that has never taken funding. We have run out of money and need your help to continue!
<div align=""center"">

column11: >Read This is real game-play from our app. Check out JohnnyAppl.com and try out the Beta yourself.

column1: <div><span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
<h3 style=""text-align: center
column2: >We are endorsed by the UNCCD and Eden Projects

column1: <center>
<hr/>
Plant trees for Earth Day 2015 and save lives.
The trees you plant don't just offset CO2 - they save lives! Watch this award-winning short-film by our partner Eden Reforestation Projects.
Filmed by our planting partner: Eden Reforestation Projects.
</center>
<hr/>
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
<div>Every
time you get an answer right, we send the ad money on to tree planters.
<div>
Come try the game out for yourself at JohnnyAppl.com. We are sorry for all the bugs andwe  are working hard to fix them.
A million trees in 12 Days
Our model was pioneered by the highly successful Freerice.com. So far, Freerice has funded the donation of over 99 billion grains of rice.

Our goal is simple: we want to plant one million trees. We estimate that, with 26,000 play sessions per month, we could accomplish that goal in one year. If we were to achieve the same peak usage rates as Freerice, we could plant one million trees in only twelve days.
We
have over a dozen quizzes so far, with many more to come. Have a quiz idea? Send us the answers and we'l put it up!
<div>
<div>
<ul>
<div>
2. Earn real-world achievements
We
track exactly how your tree planting makes an impact. Offset the
pollution from a continental road trip, or restore land from desertification.
<div>
3. Play together as a community to plant faster
Work
together to plant trees in real time. Invite your friends and see who can get
the highest score.
<div>
<div>
4. Track your offset CO2 and go Carbon Neutral
Each time you get an answer right, some CO2 is offset. We but this into a timer so you can track when you are carbon neutral.
<div>
<hr/>
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
Why Madagascar?
More than 90% of Madagascar’s original forests have been destroyed, Our partner, Eden Reforestation Projects is making a real difference.

Entire mangrove estuaries are gone, leaving the bare earth to wash away into the sea. And now the Malagasy people have no choice but to go into debt or sell themselves and their families into slavery just to survive.
<div>
<div>
Mangrove
The Eden Projects began planting in Madagascar since 2007. The mangrove project is replenishing the enormous Malagasy mangrove forests at a rate of approx 1.4 Million trees/month.
<div>
Sarobidy Maternity Center
Your tree donation also biulds The Sarobidy Maternity Center which provides compassionate and competent free prenatal care and education throughout the duration of pregnancy.
United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification
The UNCCD fights desertification, which happens when too much vegetation is removed from the ground. We work with them to reclaim land from desertification by planting trees.
<hr/>
<div>
Our Story

Anton Doos spent six months in the Amazon living with the Shuar indigenous group when he was 19. The problem is, they were cutting down trees for money to survive.

Several years later, Mike and Anton met up in China. Mike stumbled on Freerice.com, a game that donates ten grains of rice every time you get an answer right. That gave Anton an idea: could we fund tree planting in the same way?
Then they spent more on slow but steady progress in their spare time coding, testing, and refining the site... which brings us to today.

Anton Doos is a designer, project manager, and hardcore traveler. Born in the US Virgin Islands, Anton has spent a decade in Asia, honing his design chops and successfully launching several small companies. Anton made JohnnyAppl beautiful.

Michael Hogan is a former neuroscientist and current data dude. After leaving his job in academia, he went on to collaborate with Anton on several web-based projects. He's responsible for game mechanics, accounting, and communication.

Zeeshan Khalid is a programmer-of-all-trades who single-handedly made every aspect of JohnnyAppl seamless and easy. Who you gonna call when a traffic spike crashes JohnnyAppl's servers? You gonna call Zee.
<hr/>
We need your help to crowd-fund reforestation!
JohnnyAppl is almost finished, but we need one last push to get it up and running.
