What if you could transform our planet with the touch of a button?
JohnnyAppl.com gives anyone the ability to plant trees for free, right from their computer, while having fun.
Get smarter with quizzes like English, famous people, animals, geography, science, and more... all while making a difference in the world.
How
When you get an answer right, ads pay to plant real trees in Africa.(Like Freerice.com but for trees!)
We are a small boot-strapped team that has never taken funding. We have run out of money and need your help to continue!
Read This is real game-play from our app. Check out JohnnyAppl.com and try out the Beta yourself.
We are endorsed by the UNCCD and Eden Projects
Plant trees for Earth Day 2015 and save lives.
The trees you plant don't just offset CO2 - they save lives! Watch this award-winning short-film by our partner Eden Reforestation Projects.
Filmed by our planting partner: Eden Reforestation Projects.
How JohnnyAppl works
Every
time you get an answer right, we send the ad money on to tree planters.
We are OPEN BETA
Come try the game out for yourself at JohnnyAppl.com. We are sorry for all the bugs andwe  are working hard to fix them.
A million trees in 12 Days
Our model was pioneered by the highly successful Freerice.com. So far, Freerice has funded the donation of over 99 billion grains of rice.

Our goal is simple: we want to plant one million trees. We estimate that, with 26,000 play sessions per month, we could accomplish that goal in one year. If we were to achieve the same peak usage rates as Freerice, we could plant one million trees in only twelve days.
1. Get smarter with educational quizzes
We
have over a dozen quizzes so far, with many more to come. Have a quiz idea? Send us the answers and we'l put it up!
2. Earn real-world achievements
We
track exactly how your tree planting makes an impact. Offset the
pollution from a continental road trip, or restore land from desertification.
3. Play together as a community to plant faster
Work
together to plant trees in real time. Invite your friends and see who can get
the highest score.
4. Track your offset CO2 and go Carbon Neutral
Each time you get an answer right, some CO2 is offset. We but this into a timer so you can track when you are carbon neutral.
Without trees, there are no humans.
Why Madagascar?
More than 90% of Madagascar’s original forests have been destroyed, Our partner, Eden Reforestation Projects is making a real difference.

Entire mangrove estuaries are gone, leaving the bare earth to wash away into the sea. And now the Malagasy people have no choice but to go into debt or sell themselves and their families into slavery just to survive.
Mangrove
The Eden Projects began planting in Madagascar since 2007. The mangrove project is replenishing the enormous Malagasy mangrove forests at a rate of approx 1.4 Million trees/month.
Sarobidy Maternity Center
Your tree donation also biulds The Sarobidy Maternity Center which provides compassionate and competent free prenatal care and education throughout the duration of pregnancy.
United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification
The UNCCD fights desertification, which happens when too much vegetation is removed from the ground. We work with them to reclaim land from desertification by planting trees.
Our Story

Anton Doos spent six months in the Amazon living with the Shuar indigenous group when he was 19. The problem is, they were cutting down trees for money to survive.Several years later, Mike and Anton met up in China. Mike stumbled on Freerice.com, a game that donates ten grains of rice every time you get an answer right. That gave Anton an idea: could we fund tree planting in the same way?
Then they spent more on slow but steady progress in their spare time coding, testing, and refining the site... which brings us to today.

Anton Doos is a designer, project manager, and hardcore traveler. Born in the US Virgin Islands, Anton has spent a decade in Asia, honing his design chops and successfully launching several small companies. Anton made JohnnyAppl beautiful.Michael Hogan is a former neuroscientist and current data dude. After leaving his job in academia, he went on to collaborate with Anton on several web-based projects. He's responsible for game mechanics, accounting, and communication.Zeeshan Khalid is a programmer-of-all-trades who single-handedly made every aspect of JohnnyAppl seamless and easy. Who you gonna call when a traffic spike crashes JohnnyAppl's servers? You gonna call Zee.
We need your help to crowd-fund reforestation!
JohnnyAppl is almost finished, but we need one last push to get it up and running.
Get in touch
Email Address
User Voice

column8: >Conservation Revolution in the Congo Basin Rainforest!

column1: Here at Wildlife Works we take the business of conservation seriously. Our revolutionary conservation model has been proven, with great success, to save endangered forests and wildlife, while uplifting rural communities.

We are up to big things! Your contribution today will help amplify our impact in the Congo Basin rainforest, allowing us to save highly endangered bonobos and forest elephants, while helping to protect forests that are 60 times larger than Costa Rica.
The Model

1. Protects highly threatened forests
2. Monitors and protects the wildlife within the forest
3. Provides sustainable development and job creation in forest communities
The model has been proven in the Kasigau Corridor of Kenya where:

<div>

Wildlife Works' mission is to harness the power of the global consumer to create innovative and sustainable solutions for wildlife conservation.

When you buy a Wildlife Works product, you become an agent for conservation. You're wearing the brand that says you won't sit quietly while forests disappear forever.
The jobs we create to make our products, and the money we invest into forest communities, has a direct impact on saving endangered and threatened forests and wildlife around the globe.
Offset Your Footprint- $50
We all have a carbon footprint that contributes to climate change. Do your part for the planet and offset the carbon footprint of an individual urban dweller for one year.
Wildlife Immersion Trip- $1,500

Immerse yourself in the conservation revolution! Join us for a week long excursion at our conservation site in Kenya. Wildlife Works effectively protects 500,000 acres in the Kasigau Corridor, an African elephant migration route. Before Wildlife Works' involvement, this land connecting  two nature reserves was unprotected, leaving wilderness, and wildlife exposed to danger. In the past 5 years the area has seen conservation transformation through Wildlife Works' unique model. Want to see how we did it? Come to Kenya with us to learn, connect with wildlife, and experience the impact. *Airfare is not included*
The trip includes:

Share &

#ConservationRevolution
","Conservation Revolution in the Congo Basin Rainforest!

Here at Wildlife Works we take the business of conservation seriously. Our revolutionary conservation model has been proven, with great success, to save endangered forests and wildlife, while uplifting rural communities.

We are up to big things! Your contribution today will help amplify our impact in the Congo Basin rainforest, allowing us to save highly endangered bonobos and forest elephants, while helping to protect forests that are 60 times larger than Costa Rica.
The Model
Wildlife Works' model is a holistic approach to conservation that:
1. Protects highly threatened forests
2. Monitors and protects the wildlife within the forest
3. Provides sustainable development and job creation in forest communities
The model has been proven in the Kasigau Corridor of Kenya where:
Over 500,000 acres of threatened forest is protected
Thousands of species are protected, including African elephants

Hundreds of jobs have been created, thousands of children's educations have been sponsored, and livelihoods enhanced by increased access to basic needs such as healthcare, water, food security and so much more...
Our next mission is in the Congo Basin rainforest, an area that is in desperate need of conservation revolution!
What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $50,000+ (the more we raise, the more impact we can have in threatened forests)! Our unique perks range from a week long, once in a lifetime, wildlife immersion trip at our protection site in Kenya, to stylish merchandise made in our fair-trade eco-factory, to sponsoring children in Africa to experience their own wildlife.
Wildlife Works Graphic T-Shirt- $25

Wildlife Works' mission is to harness the power of the global consumer to create innovative and sustainable solutions for wildlife conservation.When you buy a Wildlife Works product, you become an agent for conservation. You're wearing the brand that says you won't sit quietly while forests disappear forever.
The jobs we create to make our products, and the money we invest into forest communities, has a direct impact on saving endangered and threatened forests and wildlife around the globe.
Offset Your Footprint- $50
We all have a carbon footprint that contributes to climate change. Do your part for the planet and offset the carbon footprint of an individual urban dweller for one year.
Wildlife Immersion Trip- $1,500

Immerse yourself in the conservation revolution! Join us for a week long excursion at our conservation site in Kenya. Wildlife Works effectively protects 500,000 acres in the Kasigau Corridor, an African elephant migration route. Before Wildlife Works' involvement, this land connecting  two nature reserves was unprotected, leaving wilderness, and wildlife exposed to danger. In the past 5 years the area has seen conservation transformation through Wildlife Works' unique model. Want to see how we did it? Come to Kenya with us to learn, connect with wildlife, and experience the impact. *Airfare is not included*
The trip includes:
Transportation to/from Nairobi Intl. Airport
Private room with en suite bathroom and our eco-bed and breakfast
3 meals per day
Safari vehicle and tours
Guides & translators
Once in a lifetime experiences with local sustainable community initiatives
The Impact

In a nutshell, our model makes protected forests more valuable alive then dead by creating a structure that works for local communities and governments. By incentivizing those who historically rely on deforestation for survival, we empower people to take a stand and protect forests that would otherwise be destroyed. Our work has:
Uplifted forest communities containing over 150,000 people
Protected over 1.2 million acres of endangered forests
Protected thousands species of wildlife, including African elephants
Prevented over 15 million tons of emissions from entering the atmosphere
Why The Congo Basin Rainforest?
Saving the Congo Basin rainforest is like saving one of the lungs of our planet. It is second in scale to the Amazon rainforest and rapidly disappearing.

The Congo Basin rainforest is home to thousands of endangered species that only exist there including gorillas, chimpanzees, forest elephants, various birds, shrew, fish, and amphibians that are invaluable to the ecosystem.

This threatened forest is essential to mitigating climate change for the world by affecting rainfall patterns across the North Atlantic as well as reducing ocean acidification and storing billions of tons of carbon from the atmosphere.
Forest communities throughout these rainforests generate a flourishing economy that enhances their quality of life by monetizing conservation through this new model.
Share & Join the Conservation Revolution!

Help us get our message out there! Forwarding our campaign to friends, family, and fellow conservation enthusiasts through social media, email, and word of mouth is a great way to help us achieve our goal.The conservation revolution has begun. Join us.

Who We Are

Whale Scout is a non-profit organization serving Puget Sound and the Salish Sea. Our mission is to conserve Pacific Northwest whales through land-based conservation experiences. You may remember our campaign from last year. We are back to tell you what we've accomplished since then and why we need your help this year.

Since our last campaign just 13 months ago we have:

  • Trained and outfitted a team of 20 land-based whale watching naturalists
  • Hosted eight 'Whale Scout Helpin' Out Events' ensuring that the whales we love to watch have enough salmon to eat from our local rivers and streams
  • Produced 16 podcasts
• Stationed 13 volunteers on San Juan Island's Westside Preserve in association with the Salish Sea Association of Marine Naturalists and San Juan County Land Bank

• Formed a new partnership with Killer Whale Tales to get school kids outside protecting endangered salmon and orcas with support from the Rose Foundation

    • We are all about taking action right where we are to get our local Southern Resident orcas off the endangered species list. We do this by helping the public engage in land-based whale watching and inspiring them to take action to protect the whales they are seeing. The best way to do that is to feed the whales...not literally of course! We encourage others to join us in restoring salmon habitat in and around our local streams and forests at Helpin' Out events and by making small changes in their everyday lives.

Knowing that our programs make a difference in the world and to whales is important. This year we have:

  •  Assisted over 1,000 people in watching whales
•  Planted 520 trees, providing shade and improving water quality
• Spread 45 cubic yards of mulch retaining moisture for plants and conserving water
• Removed 45 cubic yards of  invasive species helping promote native, diverse plant species
Our programs inspire! See what people have to say about us:
<div>

""Without Whale Scout, I would never have the chance to watch whales in Puget Sound, as I do not live within sight of the water.  Getting a text when they are in an area, learning their direction of travel and receiving periodic updates as they move is awesome!  I hop in the car with my binos and camera, head to the water and wait for updates.  So fun when there is success!""  Betsey, Fan of Whale Scout
<div>
""Thank you for helping us restore the forest and support UW students. That was the best family oriented event ever!"" Jim Freese, Former Executive Director, Friends of North Creek Forest
<div>
Thanks for all you do to organize Whale Scouts and the community to help the whales and salmon! I'm so excited to donate to such a valuable, pro-active organization!"" Laure, Volunteer and Donor

Current Challenges

While we celebrate our successes over the past year we have also encountered some expected and unexpected challenges:

  • Our Director is taking some time off with her new baby and will need assistance keeping Whale Scout programs running at full speed.

• We received a grant helping cover equipment and supplies. While this is a huge help, one of the grant requirements asked us to obtain liability insurance which set us back about $700/year and cannot be covered by the grant.
• All non-profits depend on public support - we are no different!

These overhead expenses and staffing challenges are typical of a growing organization and we are confident that with careful planning and your help we can overcome these obstacles and provide even greater benefits to our community and the whales in the future. Hiring a temporary part time staff person also gives a young person an opportunity to gain experience in the environmental field.
<div>
<h3>What We Need &amp
Here's what we need to keep up the momentum and grow:
<ul>

• Last year's Indiegogo helped launch Whale Scout into a wonderful inaugural year! Your donation will help take us through 2016.  It will help pay for a part-time staff member to keep the ship sailing for two months this spring when Director Whitney takes a brief maternity leave, and will also help fund this year's summer program on San Juan Island!
<li>
<span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >Some of our very own Whale Scouts have provided unique ""perks"" to thank you for your donations including beautiful photos of orcas! Consider donating and then giving twice by gifting a ""perk"" to a friend for the holidays!

column1:
Other Ways You Can Help

Do even more! Tell your friends why this is important to you and why you are passionate about whales and Whale Scout:

  • Share this campaign on Facebook!
<div>
Thank you for all of your support!

DIGITIZE-A-NATION is small group of rocket scientists building ‘Apps’ that assess drowning islands as NASA does discovering a new planet. With ‘Apps’ as easy to use as ‘Candy Crush’ itself, DIGITIZE-A-NATION’s intent is to reach, engage, and empower all islanders across the planet and other coastal nations at risk.  Island Ambassadors want a Loud Voice in climate discussions and access to advanced economic and planetary data. Wall Street equally seek ‘Apps’ that reduce economic risks across the board. If island nations cannot access planetary data and ‘Apps’ to avoid catastrophes, Wall Street will lose billions that a few million now could protect, and island and coastal people lose their homes, nation, and culture.  We must do something!!  We need to DIGITIZE-A-NATION.

Short Summary

The point of this fundraiser to raise enough money to buy four boats (priced a $500 apiece) for Virachey National Park's rangers so that they can patrol the Sesan River to stop illegal loggers and wildlife poachers -two of the greatest threats that this magnificent park faces. Some background about myself and what our plan is:

• My name is Greg McCann and I have been involved with Virachey National Park  since early 2010 when I first traveled there to do my doctoral research on Animism and Bio-regionalism. I have returned every winter break since then, and I am not involved in an extensive wildlife camera-trapping survey there. I also helped to found the NGO Habitat ID,  which has helped sponsor the camera-trapping project. I also authored a book titled
column4: keywords=called+away+by+a+mountain+spirit"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Called Away by a Mountain Spirit. You can read the Taipei Times review of the book here.

column1: • The ongoing camera-trapping project has also received very generous support from several trekkers and concerned individuals, including Andreas Neunert, who lived and worked in Cambodia as part of the Doctors without Borders program. Andreas has contributed the excellent Reconyx cameras, and all of the great photos that you see down in the gallery that have the Reconyx label on the image the Park has thanks to him! Andreas trekked to the Veal Thom Grasslands in 2013 and will hopefully be participating in a 2015 expedition. Kurt Johnson and Keith Pawlowski also participated in the camera-trapping program, providing Bushnell Trophy Cams and participating in the 2014 expedition earlier this year.

• Virachey staff currently have no boats with which to patrol the Sesan River, which flows for over 100 kilometers through and along the border with Virachey. The river is a major conduit for transporting illegally felled timber and poached wildlife and it is essential that Virachey's rangers have boats to patrol the river and arrest perpetrators. If rangers can patrol the river not only will they make busts but their presence will serve as a major deterrent to loggers and poachers.
• The boats will be used to patrol the Ta Vang and Voen Sai sections of the Sesan River.

We understand that local people need to earn a living. However, poaching protected wildlife species and protected hardwood species is illegal and Virachey's staff need to be able to get out there on the water to do their job.

About Us

In 1983, Dr. Mariam Raqib left Afghanistan as a child refugee. When she returned for the first time in 2003 she found her country devastated by war. The trees that she loved and had once played happily under had been wiped out.

Determined to make a difference she set out to replace the trees lost by war. For the past 4 years she has perfected the skills and established nurseries required to produce high quality saplings in increasingly large numbers. Now these skills and knowledge are ready to take a big investment and expand the project to other provinces of Afghanistan and a wide-scale reforesation effort.

The Afghan Tree Project is a powerful and practical opportunity for everyone to help leave Afghanistan a better place, improving the environment, creating jobs and empowering women.  To do this we need your help.
<h3><strong>What We Need &amp

We need the funds to expand our nurseries which are the engine of the reforestation effort. By expanding the numbers of saplings produced we can provide fruit trees to individual families providing shade and fruit for nourishment. We can replace more of the traditional Deraa's shaded meeting places and begin our work to reform areas of forest which have been depleted by war.

In exchange we have made efforts to make our gift packages more generous than an average crowdfunding campaign. We've done this because we hope you'll come back and support us again one day and also because we'd like you to be champions of this work to others in your own community.

Our award-winning designer Johnny Selman based at Google's Creative Lab in New York designed our gift products and they are really stunning. We've designed our gifts around the principles of community and sharing. We want you to have fun flying our kites together and sharing cups of tea in our beautiful chai cups!

In an age when we are all aware of our carbon footprint, even if we don't do much to manage it, a donation to the Afghan Tree Project provides a multi-impact carbon offset option. The trees not only reduce carbon but make a huge impact to the Afghan people, providing shade, nourishment and employment in a fragile economy.   If this is your motivation we've produced some carefully designed home and car window stickers which will let people know you care about carbon.
We guarantee that no tree is double counted and the number of trees that you donate towards are the minimum that are planted on your behalf. If we do better we'll let you know that too.

At the higher levels we are producing hard back coffee table books and personalised products by Afghan craftsmen and women.  Everyone receives a wall certficiate and stickers for your fridge, wall or bike.
The Impact

Our work has great potential for the well-being of the country and the people.  We receive requests regularly from other communities in the neighboring provinces who know about our work and wish to collaborate with us.

The need is great, and yet our current funding situation does not permit us to explore options for growth.  We have spent years developing a successful working model for developing our projects, and these projects  are easily replicated elsewhere in the country.  We will use the funds from this campaign to develop and expand our projects.  We will do this in the following manner:
Plant larger quantities of seeds so that these seeds will then germinate and yield in greater number of tree saplings. The surplus saplings will be shared with communities in neighboring provinces.
The tree planting will mean the employment of additional nursery workers providing work, contributing to the economy and forming a workforce skilled in nurturing trees for the future.
Other Ways You Can Help

The best way you can help us other than by a donation is to spread the word of the Afghan Tree Project through word of mouth and social media. Please like us on our facebook pagehttps://www.facebook.com/AfghanTree where you'll find all the latest gift information, news and pictures. We'd love you to share our posts and follow us on twitter @afghantrees where you can retweet us to your networks. We'll always follow you back. Why not hold a kite flying event or other fundraiser at your school or community centre? We'll do everything we can to help you with raffle prizes from our list of gifts and promotional material as well as giving you a big mention on our facebook page and twitter.
Thanks for visiting the Afghan Tree Project, we're looking forward to our adventure together!
","About Us

In 1983, Dr. Mariam Raqib left Afghanistan as a child refugee. When she returned for the first time in 2003 she found her country devastated by war. The trees that she loved and had once played happily under had been wiped out.

Determined to make a difference she set out to replace the trees lost by war. For the past 4 years she has perfected the skills and established nurseries required to produce high quality saplings in increasingly large numbers. Now these skills and knowledge are ready to take a big investment and expand the project to other provinces of Afghanistan and a wide-scale reforesation effort.

The Afghan Tree Project is a powerful and practical opportunity for everyone to help leave Afghanistan a better place, improving the environment, creating jobs and empowering women.  To do this we need your help.
What We Need & What You Get

We need the funds to expand our nurseries which are the engine of the reforestation effort. By expanding the numbers of saplings produced we can provide fruit trees to individual families providing shade and fruit for nourishment. We can replace more of the traditional Deraa's shaded meeting places and begin our work to reform areas of forest which have been depleted by war.

In exchange we have made efforts to make our gift packages more generous than an average crowdfunding campaign. We've done this because we hope you'll come back and support us again one day and also because we'd like you to be champions of this work to others in your own community.

Our award-winning designer Johnny Selman based at Google's Creative Lab in New York designed our gift products and they are really stunning. We've designed our gifts around the principles of community and sharing. We want you to have fun flying our kites together and sharing cups of tea in our beautiful chai cups!

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div>
Short Summary

Hi, my name is Grace Sowaske and I am 18 years old. I am a current freshman at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. I haven't decided on a major yet but its definitely between Biology and Environmental studies. I am from Madison, Wisconsin and have never left the country. I come from a low income family, but that hasn't stopped me from achieving one of my life goals
column2: being accepted into the University of Wisconsin- Madison. I cant stand to be cooped up for much longer! That is why I found this awesome volunteer opportunity in the Mecca of biodiversity
column3: Australia. It has always been my dream to explore the wildlife in Australia- particularly the marine life. The Great Barrier Reef has always brought wonders to me and it being one of the 7 natural wonders of the world, I feel its worth the effort to try and conserve. My contributors will help me achieve my dream and help me explore a career in conservation biology.

column1: <div>
<h3>What We Need &amp

My program costs include my accommodations, most meals, project materials and support, ground transportation, and tour guidance in Australia. These costs will directly help me gain more knowledge and help with conservation efforts. You are making a direct contribution to my education and for conservation. The initial program cost is about $5,500 not including overseas airfare which is approximately an additional $2,000. I have saved about $1,500 on my own, but I need your help! If my goal is not reached, the money will go to ISV, a program that is an internationally recognized and awarded non-profit organization that appoints university students from the U.S., Canada, Australia and the U.K. to various countries around the world in an effort to impact entire communities and endangered habitats in need. So the funds will go to a good cause.
However, with the help of my Mom, we are able to add some perks. Look below to see what wonderful treats you can get just for helping me out.
<div>
The Impact

I want to be able to make a difference concerning the depletion of many natural ecosystems around the world and this program accomplishes that along with a better understanding of how I can achieve this goal. I see the oceans as the most beautiful part of our world and I am passionate to get involved in the efforts to conserve such natural beauty and this trip will help me expand my knowledge on how to do so, and will provide me with such rich conservation experience. This project is valuable because of the growing need for a conservation movement. If I can achieve this goal, I will be an addition to this movement and I will be helping the world. In turn, with your donation, you will be helping the conservation movement as well. Your contributions will allow me help conserve the natural world that is steadily becoming less and less a part of our world today.
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help

If you cant contribute a donation today there are other ways you can help. Spread the word! If not spreading the word of my specific campaign, spread the word of conservation! There is a greater and greater need everyday for conservation of natural things on this planet and your word can help. Simply sharing my campaign with others by using the Indiegogo sharing tools will help! The word needs to be spread, and you can make that happen.

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div>
What is New Ruins
New Ruins is an eco-conscious permaculture project on a beach in Oaxaca, Mexico. Our goal is to build a unique, creative space that embraces technology, permaculture and radical self-expression.
We are a mix of United States and Mexican founders. We feel that we represent a ""United Americas"". We have international ties and many vounteers from all over the globe.
We accept vounteers from helpx.net and host travelers on couchsurfing.
<div>
<h3>What We Need &amp

We are permaculturists and we need more fruit trees. Fruit is yummy and good for you. We think this is a unique way in which our friends, followers and fellow do-gooders can participate and make a postive impact on what we are doing.

So here's the deal. We made our wishlist of fruit trees. If you donate you can pick out which tree you want to buy us and name it. We will then plant it, love it forever, dedicate it to you, and hand paint a plaque with yours and the tree's names. We will also send you a photo and post about how awesome you are on our facebook page. And when you come visit us, you can have fruit. nom nom nom....fruit!
So here are the fruit trees that are either easily or somewhat available and can grow around here:
Ataulfo Mango
Haden Mango
Valencia Orange
Fremont Mandarin
Limon Persa
Eureka Lemon
Nanche
Icaco
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chrysobalanus_icaco
Passion Fruit
Chico Zapote
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manilkara_zapota
Plum
Avocado
Grapefruit
<div>
The Impact

We have been building our infrastructure for the last 6 months. We have just finished our first superadobe dome, so we can soon move out of the tents and into our little dome house. With the rainy season in full effect now is a good time to get young fruit trees in the ground. Money is low, but our energies are high.

The arborescent metaphor is so good it's almost cliche. But it's true. To plant a tree, for it to put roots deep into the earth and then for us to have a symboitic relationship of nurture and cohabitation is a powerful symbol of what we are trying to do with New Ruins.
We hope you can be a part of that same relationship.
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want or can't donate money, but still want to help out, there are so many things you can do. Come hang out with us and plant them. Or if you are not able to come and help physically, we are always in need of help from afar and constantly on the look out for like minded thinkers, artists, writers, builders, designers and many more.
Reach out to us to see who you can participate

<div id=""watch-description-text"">

Russian military and space research company Radiy has developed a revolutionary water purification system that is based on nano technology allowing to extract arsenics, metals and salt also and especially from artesian wells and keeping it fresh for up to 180 days without adding chemicals such as chlorine. Anti-bacterial agents make it a primary health supplement. The technology developed by Radiy is 40% more energy efficient than other reverse osmosis systems while the output is 50% higher. The Russian government actively supports the project as it grants access to clean, anti-bacterial, healthy water at affordable costs to all classes of society. The technology can also filter radioactive substances and therefore could be used in Japan. In Haiti a humanitarian project is under way to to install 300 machines in hospitals to help prevent cholera from spreading.
<div>
The Impact

once the technology is installed we can clear the contaminated waters in Japan, Haiti, Argentina, South Africa and whereever water is polluted. Governments are too slow to act and that's why we have to prove concept to these institutions by installing prototypes in the various region. Failing to reach our goal means to give up and let millions of people become subject to dreadful levels of contamination, in case of Japan even radioactive pollution.
<div>
<h3>What We Need &amp

One machine clearing 2000 cubic metres of heavily contaminated water per day costs 100,000 US Dollars. We need to send three proto-types to Haiti, Japan and South Africa in order to prove that we can effectively and economically efficiently fight against cholera and other diseases in poor countries, eliminate radioactive substances from water as well as clear Acid Mine Drainage (AMD) waters in South Africa, Argentina and many other countries. Governments will implement this technology as water autnonomy means energy autonomy which is a pre-requirement for a socially balanced society that lives in harmony with the environment. After all, this is about true democracy, human rights and saving the planet of the millenium, Earth.
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help:
please donate whatever you can afford and pass this around! For further information also check out this link:
http://ralphtniemeyer.com/spip.php?rubrique15

Remember: we all can change history's course by what we undertake to do and by what we refrain from doing. Become a part of the real revolution by supporting our grass roots water revolution. Major multinationals will hate us for that! All donators will be mentioned in the book being published about this grass roots revolution.
